PARA.TAB: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development agree with the view that to involve Australia in a GATT consistent free trade agreement with the United States would be `naive' and `primitive'? Does he share the view that the United States `doesn't want us' when it comes to such an agreement? If he does not agree with these views, could he explain why the Prime Minister expressed them in his specially arranged interview of 6 September?

—The Prime Minister, quite rightly, labels proposals to negotiate with NAFTA as naive, given that NAFTA legislation is not through the Congress, given that we do not know what is in NAFTA, and given that the details of NAFTA we have available do not do anything for us in respect of agriculture.
—So, it is naive, is it?

—Yes, it is naive; I have already said that. When you face the situation in bilateral negotiations, as I will again next Monday in Washington, and say to the Americans, `We have access to about 4 per cent of your beef market. We have access to a bit less than one per cent of your sugar market. We have access to a bit less than one per cent of your steel market. We have access to an almost negligible quantity of your dairy markets. We want to negotiate in these areas', they come back and whack you pretty heavily and say, `Yes, but we have only 50 per cent access to your telecommunications and broadcast market and, really, we want all this settled up first before we will do anything in other areas'. When you see NAFTA, which has nothing in it for agriculture, nothing in it for steel and nothing in it for the areas in which we have particular comparative advantage, it becomes rather silly and naive to think you can actually negotiate bilaterally with the United States to get a GATT consistent free trade arrangement when there is nothing in it for us.
—Why don't you try?
—The interjection is, `Why don't you try?'. For nine years, every time I have gone to Washington and every time I have gone to Tokyo, we have been discussing bilateral issues—every time.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition says that when the Prime Minister goes to Japan he should be talking about rice. We will always talk about rice. I was up there the week before last talking about rice. I am sure all agricultural Ministers in previous governments have talked about rice to the Japanese. But suddenly the Leader of the Opposition has discovered that the Japanese have massive barriers on rice—about 700 per cent. I simply point out that, if you think you can solve that one bilaterally, you have another think coming.

The United States has a $45 billion trade deficit with Japan. It provides the defence umbrella. Japan and America are each other's largest trading partners. With that massive trade imbalance, the United States cannot get anything out of the Japanese on rice. Even if it could, it would be blocked in the upper House in Japan.

We will raise it, and we will continue to raise it, but in many of these areas—for example, the areas of agriculture and natural resource products, where we have comparative advantage—it is best to continue on the multilateral path, because you will get these matters solved here and you will get a breakthrough there. Bilaterally, you can only get marginal gains. If you can get under the multilateral umbrella, you certainly will get a lot more bilateral access. The Prime Minister is right to say that the Leader of the Opposition was naive. He did not know what he was talking about, and he still does not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House about the outcome of the APEC ministerial meeting in Bangkok last week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The APEC Ministerial Council last week committed itself to continue an agenda of trade liberalisation in the region. The communique had some quite interesting text on it. It said:

ANSWER.PARA: Ministers endorsed the view of the informal group that APEC economies should encourage investment linkages . . . and support the process of broader trade liberalisation.

Ministers discussed the practical measures identified by the informal group to carry forward the mandate from the Seoul meeting to identify options and make recommendations for approaches to trade liberalisation in the region.

It talks in these terms. This was another step on the way to further integrating Australia in the region, which has already brought us remarkable trade success as we now have exports running at about 25 per cent of GDP; where we have seen our manufacturing and service exports triple; and where we have seen elaborately transformed manufactures triple.

PARA.TAB: As I said last week, even the shadow Minister for trade, the honourable member for Kooyong, complimented the Government by repeating the successes in the statistics which we have had. Of course, up until recently the shadow Minister for trade and the Leader of the Opposition were united in their support for focusing our trade efforts on the Asia-Pacific region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145. A request was made from an honourable member to tell us about the outcome of a very important conference. The Prime Minister nearly got himself out of breath trying to read that little bit, and now we will get an attack on the Opposition. That is not relevant.
—The Prime Minister is in order.

—In the printed text of Fightback!, at page 64, it talks about regional free trade arrangements, `aimed at reducing, and eventually eliminating, trade barriers . . . through the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to achieve this objective'. That is the focus.

PARA.TAB: I am quite puzzled to see that this morning the Leader of the Opposition said that if he were in government he would announce targets for Australian exports to each market in the region. He is twisting and turning and squirming on trade. This morning we had a new policy, not the one published in Fightback!, that he is now going to announce targets, because he reveals this sort of strange split in the thinking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. How can the Opposition's announcement of targets about trade be in any way relevant to the question, which asked for the outcome of the APEC conference?
—There is no point of order.

—We will have targets for the likes of Malaysia, where we have virtually little control over the outcome, targets for Singapore and the Philippines, and we will have a target for France and a target for Germany. Precise numbers and percentage increases will be required by certain dates. He is quite happy for the Australian Government to announce these targets and for Government officials to be responsible for them—

—Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. We know this has been coming; we have read about it in the press. On relevance, the question was very narrow on government decisions at a conference. It had nothing to do with Opposition policy.
—The honourable member for Mitchell has made his point of order. The Prime Minister is in order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Beazley

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I take a point of order that the nature of that intervention was disorderly, starting as it did with a discussion of the press. I draw your attention to standing order 303. It says under the heading `Disorder':

INTERJECT.PARA: (a) persistently and wilfully obstructed the business of the House; or—
persistently and wilfully refused to conform to any standing order; or
(e) persistently and wilfully disregarded the authority of the Chair—

all of which are regularly offended in Opposition points of order—the member may be named by the Speaker. I ask that you, Mr Acting Speaker, give us an interpretation on whether the last particular intervention offended that.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

PARA.TAB: Mr Costello interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Higgins will restrain himself. I am sure that honourable members are aware that points of order need to be directed appropriately to the Standing Orders. It is difficult for members of the Opposition before the event to know whether their point of order is in order and, therefore, difficult always for them to know whether in fact it will be regarded as frivolous. To this stage members of the Opposition have not breached that. However, they ought not to be using points of order to disrupt the procedures.

—We are going to have targets for these countries where we have no control and require bureaucrats and the private industry of Australia to meet the targets. At the same time he has a precise target of withdrawing $70m from the trade budget and, while he slashes Austrade and splits the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the shadow trade Minister says, `We don't need an export development grant scheme or something like it'. In other words, those opposite would take away all of the mechanisms to increase trade, while at the same time adopting precise targets that were not mentioned in Fightback. But, of course, they are targets over which the Leader of the Opposition has no control. Yet, where he would have control, as a government, he has no targets for Australia or for Australians.

PARA.TAB: He has no target for the Australian motor vehicle industry—it can sink or swim under zero tariffs; no target for the Australian sugar industry—it can sink or swim under zero tariffs; no target for textiles, clothing or footwear under zero tariffs; no target for Australian manufacturing employees; and no target for Australian farmers. But, all of a sudden, under his trade policy, where he is slippin' and slidin' on trade, he now has precise targets for markets. None of this is in his official text. This has been developed on the run over the weekend. Bureaucrats will be required to meet them and, presumably, the trade Minister's head will be lopped if the targets are not met. But he has no targets in Australia.
Of course, on the targets he has set for himself, such as presenting the Cole report on the consumption tax—which he promised last month—there has been no meeting of the target.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Under standing order 145, the coalition's policy on Fightback that we proposed—
—Order! Previous points of order have been taken under standing order 145. I call the Prime Minister.

—The Leader of the Opposition promised a Bill on industrial relations earlier this year. He has not met that target. It is like the target he set for having a press conference in Canberra. He has not met that.
—This is impossible.
—The honourable member for Corinella!

—All of the targets set by the Opposition are unmet. But, no, we are now going to have targets for particular markets while he slashes Austrade, breaks up Foreign Affairs and Trade and berates Australian industry. This is right at the time when our success in exports has never been greater—so says the shadow Minister for trade. It is not just us saying this; it is corroborated by the shadow Minister for trade. All today's Australian Financial Review reveals in that interview about the specific trade targets is that somebody was making policy on the run. Just as NAFTA emerged from the Queensland sugar fields a week ago, trade targets emerged over the weekend, as he tried to extricate himself from the stupid position he has himself in.

—I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon members of a parliamentary delegation from the Parliament of the United Kingdom. On behalf of the House I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is it true that, as reportedly stated by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy during his recent visit to Washington, the issue of a close Australian involvement with NAFTA was specifically raised by the Australian Government with President Bush and his team when they visited Canberra in January? Is it also true that the matter was subsequently addressed by Cabinet?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject of a North American free trade agreement—the development of NAFTA—was precisely mentioned by me. I said that it was largely an insidious influence on world trade if it extended into South America. I made the points then to the President, and I made them in the public speech in the Great Hall, saying that we wanted the United States to have a foot in both oceans—in the Atlantic and the Pacific—and that actually slipping behind trade barriers in the Americas was basically not going to be a trade liberalising thing; that is, for Australia, which produces a lot of products similar to that which would be produced by Canada and Mexico, and particularly by countries of South America. I said that a free trade agreement must inevitably mean that exports from this country would be shut out. I told the President that, while there was a naturalness about Canadian and Mexican exports going to the United States—meaning that it was natural, therefore, that a free trade arrangement between the countries could be developed—there was nothing natural about Central America or South America.

PARA.TAB: I made that quite clear. Therefore, that issue would mean that, if the United States is basically jockeyed into a position where it wants to respond to trade protectionism in Europe, this is basically against its best interests. The great preponderance of its trade is in the Pacific, not the Atlantic, although most of its investment is in the Atlantic. The President should enhance the role of APEC as a trade liberalising force so that we all enjoy higher incomes and greater levels of growth by seeing trade in agriculture, services, intellectual property rights and all of the things which are in the current GATT round, as we saw a pick-up in trade in goods following the Kennedy Round in the 1960s. That is what I urged upon the President. It was because of those urgings that he made it quite clear in his parliamentary speech in this chamber that the United States was not withdrawing from the Pacific, that it was going to engage the Pacific and that he wanted to consider those issues.

It is this Government which proposed the establishment of APEC. Those opposite make these fraudulent claims that the Government has sat down on trade policy. But the very vehicle with which most of the countries of the Asia-Pacific area focus—that is, APEC—is the vehicle which was promoted by this Government. As we saw from this week's meeting and the transcript and the communique, APEC is continuing to develop. But the issue of Australia and NAFTA has been discussed over a very long period and has been rejected as a way forward by this Government. We made it quite clear that we were not going to fly over Asia to San Francisco. As I said the other day, the only place where you are comfortable is either Washington or London. If you are not being drawn to the old epicentres of influence—London or Washington—then you are basically lost.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Higgins.

—The fact is that, with APEC, you can have the best of both worlds: a free trade area in the Asia-Pacific area, including the Pacific Basin—Canada, the United States and Mexico, as Mexico has now applied to join APEC. While NAFTA has been an issue in discussion for a decade or more, we have always chosen to go for trade liberalisation in the Pacific area against the general background of a GATT change. The Leader of the Opposition made it clear when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: So maximum pressure on the GATT first. Anyone who flirts with the idea of bilateral trade deals is undermining what ought to be our main emphasis in terms of making headway in the GATT.
That is about the only sensible thing he has said on trade in the last couple of months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Is Australian manufacturing industry now more internationally competitive than a decade ago? By what process has that occurred? What will promote the continuation of the improvements and what will put it at risk?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Robertson for his question. It is the case that the international competitiveness of Australian manufacturing industry has improved dramatically in the last 10 years. One only needs to look at some of the statistics which show that there has been an increase in labour productivity of something like 3 per cent per annum in manufacturing industry as a whole. If we look specifically at the car industry, we see that during the 1980s labour productivity has increased by about 3 per cent per annum, something which even the honourable member for Goldstein has reflected on admiringly, when he says that productivity growth has been between 6 and 12 per cent.

PARA.TAB: If we look at export growth, we find that this has been nothing short of spectacular. Motor vehicle exports have grown 2 1/2 times to $1.3 billion. Interestingly, we have seen the quality of Australian cars improving as well from over four faults per car to something like two faults per car, well within the order of the quality of imported cars which we were not within cooee of a few years ago.

In the steel industry we have seen that labour productivity has increased by well over 6 per cent every year during the 1980s, and that as a result BHP Steel has made investments and it has slashed the cost of making steel in this country. In the next day or two the Australian Manufacturing Council will reveal that something like 400 companies in Australia have seen their elaborately transformed exports growing by an almost unbelievable—to use their expression—rate of 60 per cent per annum. This has come about because of the sustained hard work of the manufacturing industry, improving their productivity and improving their quality. It has been the sustained hard work of management within that industry, working with unions, improving work practices, developing new products and seeking out new export markets. It has also been the result of sustained hard work on the part of this Government, providing the supporting mechanisms, providing things such as export facilitation and an industrial relations environment in which these changes can occur.

Who are some of the stars of Australian manufacturing industry that have been able to achieve these results? Amongst the long list, of course, would be John Prescott's BHP, Bob Johnston's Toyota, Mike Quinn's Mitsubishi, Dick Warburton's Du Pont, just to mention a few. These are people who have worked hard at trying to lift the quality of Australian manufacturing industry. These are the good managers in Australia. But I note that amongst the many things on which there is a huge gulf between us and the Opposition is this question about who are good managers in Australia. I reflect back to 1987 when the Leader of the Opposition wrote on this topic of good management in Australia. After spending the usual 90 per cent of his article denigrating Australian managers, he said:
But he saw a silver lining.
Nevertheless, there are signs that things may be changing. They indicate that a managerial revolution is under way.
This revolution has manifested itself in the emergence of a new breed of industrial managers. Names such as Skase, Bond, Elliott, Spalvins . . .
The superior managerial skills of this new breed are readily apparent.

ANSWER.PARA: They may be readily apparent to him, but they are not so readily apparent to us. I do not know what Chris Skase has exported from Australia, except other people's money and backache; and, of course, John Elliott has managed to export 30 per cent of Fosters.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are your mates.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo!

—Here we have, on the one hand, the Leader of the Opposition praising these people, who have basically contributed little to Australia, whereas at the same time he denigrates those who have been working hard to achieve great results for Australian industry and for Australia itself. This was about the same time that amongst the Leader of the Opposition's candidates for Governor of the Reserve Bank were Tim Marcus Clark and Bill Moyle.

PARA.TAB: The point about the Leader of the Opposition is that he hangs so fiercely to these views. He grasps these views and hangs fiercely to them regardless of the criticism, regardless even of the facts. As one of his most prescient critics, Mr Gerard Henderson, has said:

The problem with Hewson is not that he is wont to change his mind. Many politicians are inconsistent. The worrying factor is that he embraces each conviction with an absolute intensity along with the belief that many of those who do not support him are motivated by ill-will.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the view which is so concerning about the Leader of the Opposition and the way in which he has launched this assault on so many great Australians who have been doing such a lot for manufacturing industry in this country.

PARA.TAB: The point is that, as a result of the work of these managers and their unions, manufacturing industry has transformed the success of Australian manufacturing. We have become more internationally competitive and many of those companies, such as BHP, Toyota, Mitsubishi and the others, have been turning in very impressive results.

But the Leader of the Opposition says, `We need a new consumption tax; we need a big bang in industrial relations and we need zero tariffs'. But what should be ringing in the ears of the Leader of the Opposition is those powerful words of Mr O'Brien the other night when he said, `What if you're wrong, John?'. That is the question which members of the Opposition should be asking themselves constantly. What if the Leader of the Opposition is wrong? What will be left of these great companies? What will be left of these great industries, if the Leader of the Opposition is wrong?

The honourable member for Bennelong says that he cannot understand what all this fuss is about because basically there is no difference between the Government and the Opposition. So after months of the Leader of the Opposition saying to Australia that he wants to give us a choice and that we have to make these dramatic changes, the honourable member for Bennelong says, `But we are no different from the Government'.

If there is no difference between the Government and the Opposition, why does the Leader of the Opposition not just utter those few words to indicate that the car plan will remain, in order that those investments can occur and those jobs in the car industry—which he says he is interested in—can materialise as a result of this crucial investment. Why do you not say it, John?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer should refer to members by their appropriate title.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.
—Come in sucker!
—Order! The honourable member for Makin should not interject in the proceedings.

—Given that the Prime Minister did not answer my previous question, I will direct it to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. During the Minister's recent visit to Washington, did he state at any stage that the Australian Government had raised with President Bush and his team during their Australian visit in January the issue of Australian access to NAFTA? What did he say in Washington in relation to Australia and NAFTA? Has Cabinet addressed this issue?

—I did not indicate to anyone whilst I was in Washington about Australia's possible accession to NAFTA, nor did I ask for that matter to be taken up by anyone with President Bush. It is true that when I was in the United States and I had discussions with my counterpart the Secretary of State for Agriculture, Secretary Madigan, I raised with him my concern about the possible implications of NAFTA to our sugar industry. I indicated in this House last week the response that I got in relation to that issue specifically having been raised; and that was that I was concerned—and this is one of the basic concerns that the Government has about joining NAFTA—that trade bloc agreements can become inward looking, not outward looking.

PARA.TAB: Let me explain the reason we were having concerns with the way that NAFTA was developing. It might have been all right if NAFTA had been building on the need for trade liberalisation. But, if NAFTA was resurrecting or constructing new barriers, it did not have much in it for us. The sugar industry was one particular area where this matter was taken up. As I say, I referred to this when I responded in the House the other day.As a result of those discussions with Secretary Madigan, he indicated to me that when the details were known Australia's concerns would be alleviated.

The problem that I have been having is that, between the document that came out on 12 August, I think—which had no detail at all about the level of sugar tariff or the impact of the sugar implications of NAFTA—and the leaked document that has been available over the last couple of days, we have still been trying to clarify what that detail involves and to ensure that that detail, when it translates, adheres to the commitment that Secretary Madigan gave me. That is the very reason that we have it as a priority on the discussions with the US trade officials and Agriculture Department officials when they come here tomorrow.

That, after all, is what sensible bilateralism is about. It is not about running around trying to join something that we do not know the details of. It is about trying to get clarification as to how policy which is going to be implemented over there will apply to specific industries. The very fact that we cannot guarantee in advance how these things are going to apply is the reason why we need specific domestic policies which take those factors into account.

The Opposition's approach is to join in some nonsensical commitment to NAFTA without knowing the details, and to try to join it after one side of the coalition—the National Party—has called America our number one trade enemy. How one expects to get any sense in negotiations from someone those opposite have insulted before one even sits around the negotiating table is a bit beyond me. But having put all their eggs in the basket of joining NAFTA on the back of an insult, Opposition members would then proceed to decimate the sugar industry in this country by wiping out its tariff support and, in the process, try to pretend that there is no difference between Opposition policy on sugar and our policy.

The fact of the matter is that there is a gulf of difference. That gulf of difference is the reason why the sugar industry is spending more time talking to us about its future than it is spending talking to you. It is the reason why the statement by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, who has asked me this question, that countervailing duties can protect the sugar industry was dismissed so rapidly by the Cane Growers Association. It is of course a stupid suggestion and the Association knows it, but it is all those opposite can offer. They offer them the chance to join NAFTA when they do not even know how the thing will apply to us; they insult them in the process and then believe that countervailing duties will protect the sugar industry. Well, they will not.

Opposition policy so far as the sugar industry is concerned is vacuous. It reflects the same approach to industry policy that has been demonstrated not only by the National Party but also particularly by honourable members who claim to speak for industry on that side of the Parliament. It is policy run by anecdote and backward-looking visions.

We had an amazing circumstance last week when the honourable member for Barker, confronted in his party room and asked how he developed the approach in terms of industry policy in relation to the car industry, said, `Well, when I got in the car and turned on the ignition, the gear wouldn't work'. That is the way that side of the House approaches policy. Similarly, when he was asked to tell people how regional development would react to changes in industries such as the sugar industry when tariff was cut away from them, the honourable member said, `Go and have a look at what happened when the corn laws were introduced in England in the nineteenth century'.

There you have it. It is industry policy run by anecdote, by the past and by this view that all one has to do is dispense the medicine without any regard to the consequences. It is little wonder that people are turning away from those opposite in droves.

We will protect the interests of the sugar industry. We will do it by having a sensible trade policy, one that is multilateral in dimension, but with a strong bilateral focus. But most important of all, we will develop a growth strategy for the sugar industry with the sugar industry and in which we will recognise a legitimate role for government—not one in which government vacates it and leaves the industry to the corrupted world market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the progress of the Government's plan for a national system of road user charges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be able to inform the House that a national system of road user charges for heavy vehicles proposed by the National Road Transport Commission has now been accepted by the Council of State and Federal Transport Ministers. I might add that this is a great win for cooperative government; it is a great win for doing things by consensus and rational discussion; and it is a great win for all of us because the Australian economy is very heavily dependent on an efficient road transport industry. This initiative has been welcomed by the trucking industry and by the States.

PARA.TAB: We will go on to introduce a national uniform system of regulation for the trucking industry, something which is long overdue and which has been long sought by all governments. The new system, which will come in in three years, will fix vehicle registration charges for heavy vehicles at $4,000 for a six-axle vehicle. It designates 18c a litre fuel excise as a road user charge. This progress, this cooperative arrangement, this principle of charging for use of the roads, is in marked contrast to the proposals of the Opposition—although the Leader of the Opposition has again committed himself to road user charges. He said on 4 September—

—He said the charge would not be linked to fuel. He has said what it will not be, but he will not say what they will do. He knows that if the road user charge on trucks is paid through registration changes, the charge will be $17,000 per year per truck.

PARA.TAB: As the leader of the National Party wanders around telling those people in rural Australia that they will have cheaper charges for transport, he should also tell them that every cocky with a truck will be charged $17,000 for registration fees.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the Opposition is now trying to make a big point. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The jeopardy to Australia's economic future caused by a Prime Minister continually changing policies regardless of the national interest.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most remarkable things about the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is that when he is under pressure in Question Time he cuts off Question Time as quickly as he can. Today we had four questions from the Opposition. When we exposed the hypocrisy of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on the trade issue, suddenly the Prime Minister wanted to cut it off—just as he would not debate the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) last Thursday, and just as he cut off Question Time last Tuesday, at the beginning of the fortnight.

PARA.TAB: This is a man, by the way, whose great political hero is none other than Winston Churchill. He says to the unsuspecting Australian public that the reason he admires Winston Churchill is that Winston Churchill showed a great sense of leadership and destiny at a time of his nation's greatest national crisis. The irony of the Prime Minister's view is that we as a country face today one of our greatest national crises—certainly our second greatest national economic crisis since 1788. But we do not have a Prime Minister who is prepared to address and analyse the problems of the country, to commit this country to practical solutions and to have the courage to tell Australians what solutions will really work in their interests.

That is in stark contrast to the Leader of the Opposition who, for whatever else the Labor Party may say about him, is a man who does not lack political courage and who, as the Treasurer himself said the other day, believes what he says and says what he believes. That is something that we on this side of the House are proud of. The fact that the Labor Party thinks it is a point of criticism says more about it than it does about the substance of the argument.

The Labor Party, led by the Prime Minister, has done precisely the reverse. Government members have looked at the problems we have as a country and they have analysed those problems. They know about the exploding foreign debt that we have; about the one million people who are out of work in Australia; and about the recurrent month by month massive balance of payments deficits. They know that those problems can be resolved only by making this country more competitive.

But have a look at the Government's record in decision-making. Does it reflect the knowledge of the problems and an objective analysis of the solution to those problems? The fact is that after 10 years in office—not 10 days or 3 years—all Government members are doing is playing politics. They are inventing arguments to suit the convenience of the day, which bear no relationship at all to the fundamental problems that this country has.

I will run through some examples of how the Labor Party—and in particular the Prime Minister—has been doing this. I have noticed that the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, in particular, like to make the point that the Leader of the Opposition apparently abuses business. Let us reflect on that. Do the Treasurer and the Prime Minister ever abuse the business community? The answer is that they sure do. Many members of the Opposition will remember the remarks the now Prime Minister made about Nobby Clark and the National Australia Bank, and how the National Australia Bank was broke. The Prime Minister said that, if it had not been for him, that would have been the end of it. There has been constant criticism of business people. On 23 November 1989 the now Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: I mean if there is any slothfulness in Australian policy or Australian commerce, it is not on the part of the Government—
of course—
it's on the part of business.
He said that many Australian business people:
. . . wouldn't get going in a barrel of yeast. . . a great problem Australia has is basically its management structure and particularly its middle management.

So every single day we have abuse across the chamber about how we criticise certain business leaders, but the Government has attacked the whole of the business community. The person who did it was, of course, the notorious Prime Minister of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Let us turn to the great issue of the day—the tariff issue. Let us look at what the Prime Minister has said about tariffs. He is running around Australia giving the impression that the only way our economy can be saved is by high levels of protection. He is beating up every protectionist sentiment in this country for cheap political advantage. Yet we all know that he knows that one of the things we have to be prepared to face up to as a country is reducing tariff protection.

It really is a matter of credit to this Parliament—not much is—that over the last decade or so it has supported a process of lower levels of tariff protection. If it had not been for the support of this side of politics in that process, it would never have been achieved. It would have been simply unachievable. The Prime Minister is running around and trying to beat up protectionist sentiment, set himself up as the champion of protectionism. In order to do what—win an intellectual point? No, in order to rake in a few cheap votes. That really is cheap politics of the worst kind. On 9 April 1991 in this House, the then Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are the only party that has removed the tariff wall—in 1988 and more recently in the Prime Minister's speech—to see it go to 5 per cent, to see it abolished, and to see a free flow of goods as well as a free flow of funds in this country.
On 12 March this year, the present Prime Minister said:
The package of measures announced today ends for ever Australia's sorry association with the tariff as a device for Australia's industrial development. . . Within this decade Australia will—
let us think about it—
have renounced once and for all the fallacious doctrine that prosperity can be found behind the insular wall of protection.

We do not argue with that. But how come, suddenly, in the last two or three weeks he argues with it? How come the Prime Minister is now promoting an entirely different and contrary argument? We should never forget the interview he did on the John Laws program on 14 March 1991. He told his mate John Laws:
Frankly, we're better off without them—
that is, the textile, clothing and footwear industries; we are better off without them altogether—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—The Prime Minister. I continue:

SPEECH.PARA: and having national resources going into something which is competitive and which will employ people . . .

the Australian economy has finally broken the chains of protection which has given us stunted growth, a sort of sub-culture in manufacturing which has basically robbed us of a higher standard of living that we would otherwise have enjoyed.
And at the end of the phasing, which is 1997 and 2000, we will have removed tariffs altogether.
Honourable members should never forget that. He said:
. . . we will have removed tariffs altogether.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—It was the Prime Minister. Did he mean it? Was he kidding? Was it a joke? Was he telling John Laws a pack of lies? Or was he a sincere national leader, in the great traditions of Churchill, who was telling the people what should be done? Now what is he? A few months have passed and what is the Prime Minister? He is the champion of protectionism; the champion of the protectionist lobby.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the issue of trade. In the last week or so we have had howls of confected derision directed at the Opposition—it was very confected, too—about how dreadful this idea of joining NAFTA is and trying to change the direction of Australian trade policy and trying to get a little access to markets in Japan and the United States. I would have thought that it was the patriotic duty of this Parliament to try to get better access to other markets. Oh no, this is shock, horror, terribly naive and terribly dangerous. But as we were reminded in Question Time, the Treasurer, not five or 10 years ago, but on 4 September 1991 at the Northbridge Taxation Office doorstep—I think a plaque should be erected there; a plaque should be put on the doorstep—said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, these are things which are obviously worth thinking about . . .
What things are obviously worth thinking about? Joining NAFTA is a thing that is obviously worth thinking about. He continued:
I myself have proposed the same sort of thing before . . .
We know this. As the Leader of the Opposition says, those opposite have been talking to President Bush about this for quite some time. He continued:
A couple of years ago I actually proposed precisely that—
there is the admission—
that we should look at a closer association with the Americans.
So if Dr Hewson is now picking up my ideas, at least he's beginning to learn something about international trade.

This was said on 4 September. Today is 14 September and we have a different tale—that Dr Hewson is not picking things up from the Government, that he is naive, that he is a fool. Who are the public going to believe in the face of this sort of nonsense coming from the Labor Party? The hypocrisy of it all has to be seen to be believed.

PARA.TAB: Frankly, if one goes through a whole range of public issues that are being debated in Australia, one finds the same thing over and over again. Do honourable members remember the issue of enterprise bargaining? The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) is interested in these industrial relations issues. Those opposite believed that enterprise bargaining was New Right, neo-fascist, crazy nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Treason.
—Treason, indeed. In this House on 26 October 1989 the now Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Does anybody believe that in an economy with any growth, particularly such as we have had—
he was not kidding—
the enterprise bargaining model would do anything other than lift wage rates and inflation way beyond the levels at which they are now?

Are those opposite opposed to enterprise bargaining today? We hear it from the Labor Party every single day: `Admittedly, we do not support the type of system those opposite propose, but we hear their support for enterprise bargaining'. What are people supposed to believe?

PARA.TAB: Remember privatisation? That was New Right, neo-fascist, crazy Liberal Party policy. The Prime Minister described privatisation as `economic vandalism'. Do honourable members remember that? Now privatisation is fine. The Government has privatised part of the Commonwealth Bank; it is privatising Australian Airlines; it is privatising Qantas.

TALK.START.PARA: —If only to help Joan Kirner.

—Admittedly, the bank was privatised only to bail out Joan Kirner and her Government who had basically bankrupted the whole of the State, and bye-bye Joan. At least the simple point is clear to all Australians. It was economic vandalism one year and it is worth doing this year. Ho-hum! Who is going to believe the Labor Party any more if that is the quality of the argument that it is trying to put to the Australian people? Everything those opposite say today was argued against yesterday and they will probably argue against it tomorrow.

PARA.TAB: I have two minutes left to finish on the mother of all policy U-turns, and that is the tax issue. I do not think we should ever let the Australian people forget the comments of the now Prime Minister on tax reform. I wish to make only two quotes and raise two basic issues.

The first is the issue of payroll tax. Now the Prime Minister says that it is impossible to abolish payroll tax and all these sorts of things; he is not in favour of payroll tax. In fact, the present Prime Minister is the champion of the payroll tax system, as I love to tell my constituents. But back in 1977 he said to the Fraser Government that we should abolish payroll tax and that that would create 200,000 jobs. Was that what he believed then? Does he believe that today? We would not know. He will believe today what suits him politically.

Finally, I finish on the issue of the GST. I want to read to honourable members two quotes that I hope they and the Australian public will reflect on. One of them was in a speech to the Melbourne Age taxation symposium on 7 June 1985 when the now Prime Minister was arguing in support of a broadly based consumption tax. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We must all recognise that it would be all too easy in this debate to inflame fears and prejudice. And we should realise that some people will be trying to do just this—
oh, we know who they are today!—
It would be all too easy to let the discussion collapse to the lowest common denominator. The emotive claim of the screaming headline will always be a strong temptation—
oh, won't it be, Ministers!—
But the question is whether we have, as a nation, the maturity to pursue a dispassionate debate in order to achieve such overdue change.

What humbug! What a frightful lot of humbug we get from him today! What a fraud! Yes, if ever there was a fraud in this Parliament it is the present Prime Minister. There were all those arguments he used to repeat in support of a broadly based consumption tax: `Allow a more rational indirect tax system; generate tax revenues to allow for a reduction in marginal rates of income tax; get rid of the black economy'—that was one of his big arguments—`there should be virtually zero exemptions; a single rate tax structure. That is a crucial design feature, to assist both administration and compliance: for business this is a simple tax'. Ho hum—the man who admires Churchill! Well, no wonder he does, because Churchill is up in the sky and he is down in the gutter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech that we have just heard from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) had as its premise an absolutely false proposition, as those opposite all know: that this Government has not been about fundamental change to the Australian economy to make it much more internationally competitive—the fundamental objective that a government should have if it is going to tackle the needs of the economy at the present time. His premise is that this Government has not been doing it. That premise is absolutely untrue.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that no government in the history of this nation has tackled the need for this country to become internationally competitive in the way that this Government has done. No government has come anywhere near that, let alone its predecessors, the Fraser Government or the other conservative governments that ran this country from 1949 to 1982, except for three years. Those governments made the Australian economy what it was at the beginning of the 1980s: entirely unable to develop a sophisticated array of manufactured exports or service exports; entirely unable to be internationally competitive; dependent on its rural and mineral products for exports; and therefore not able to continue to maintain the growth in living standards which the people of Australia had become used to through the postwar period.

That is the reality of what the previous conservative governments delivered to the Australian people at the beginning of the 1980s. This Government has spent 10 years addressing the shortcomings of that period and has brought about enormous change in the process. Certainly, in making those changes, there has been an evolution in the Government's thinking in various respects. We are doing some things now that we would not have said we would do at the beginning of our period in office.

Not only has the Government's thinking changed, but there has been an evolution in the thinking of the parties involved and a greater understanding of various policy propositions, which has led us to the point where we are now, I believe, pursuing policies which are absolutely dedicated to continuing the thrust of greater international competitiveness. No government has done more to bring this about than this Government. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been in the driving seat of all of those changes, as Treasurer and now as Prime Minister, and he certainly deserves enormous credit from the Australian nation for the changes that he has been prepared to face up to and introduce in this country, rather than be castigated by the juvenile, schoolboy debating tactics of the honourable member for Mayo, who cannot even stand the heat and has now left the kitchen.

The fact is that this Government has brought about that enormous change. Let me just give an example of that and look at enterprise bargaining and wages. The wages system in this country has evolved during our period in office and we are now pursuing enterprise bargaining very successfully. Is the Opposition against that? Is the Opposition crook on us for adopting enterprise bargaining? Those opposite say this Government has not gone far enough. One of the great ironies is that it was the conservatives who brought about the non-competitive Australian economy, and now they attack us for not moving faster to undo the non-competitive economy which they produced over 30 years. They say we should be moving faster to undo their previous policies. When we have introduced programs such as enterprise bargaining we are attacked for not doing it fast enough. As in many other cases, the fact is that this Government is pursuing enterprise bargaining, tariff reduction, the liberalisation of aviation and so on in a very substantial and measured way, which is as fast as it can without creating substantial problems.

A fundamental tenet of the Opposition's approach to economic policy in this country is absolute extremism; right wing extremism and right over-the-top—completely over-the-top—policies. It has been the hallmark of the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), as Leader of the Opposition, that that has been the way in which the Opposition's policies have evolved.

Let us look at enterprise bargaining. It is not just a matter of accepting enterprising bargaining which we introduced, and which is now developing at a rapid rate, and in a very satisfactory way, with increased productivity and with major change in our workplaces. It is happening well because of all the preconditioning that occurred with the change in attitudes of the parties over the previous decade.

The Opposition wants to go much further than that. It wants to break away the safety nets of award conditions which would open workers to exploitation where they did not have strong bargaining power. It is a typical example of the Opposition's right over-the-top, extremist approach. This is an ultra right wing approach to economic policy, and one which would do great harm to Australians and to the Australian nation.

Let us look at tariffs. The Opposition would adopt a policy of taking tariffs to zero, or near to it, by the year 2000 in the car, and textiles, clothing and footwear industries, knowing that the result would not be the strengthening of the industry by making it more efficient, but the demolition of the industry. The Opposition does not care about that.

It knows that investors are saying, `We will not invest, if that is the policy'. It knows that investors have investments on hold now because they think that the Opposition might win an election. It is doing great damage to the Australian economy and to the recovery process. Nevertheless, it is pursuing an ultra, over-the-top, extremist policy. The policy is damaging even now from opposition. If it were to get into government, the policy would be devastating in its impact on the Australian economy.

In relation to aviation, the Opposition has a policy of open skies. We have had tremendous change in aviation. There have been increased numbers of international operators coming into this country, and the number of passengers coming into this country has doubled in our period in office. That has been brought about by great liberalisation through the bilateral agreements, which give much greater access to foreign operators to come into Australia. This has resulted in many more operators and many more services by those operators. But what does the Opposition want to do? It is not satisfied with going down that kind of path. It wants to go right over the top and have an open skies policy. What is an open skies policy? It is a policy where there are no bilateral agreement restrictions. One simply says: anyone who wants to come to Australia can, and can fly his plane here and wipe out our aviation industry—certainly in its international aspects. That is the open skies policy in Fightback which the Opposition pursues. It is another typical example of being right over the top, massively over the top, in the way in which it seeks to approach the solutions to the Australian economy. It is deplorable that the Opposition has such extreme policies and they certainly are there.

In relation to taxation, and Fightback, and all of the associated arrangements with that, there are a whole panoply of over-the-top policies, including a very large goods and services tax at 15 per cent. This would put inflation into the economy of at least 5 per cent, when the other taxes are taken off. In the process, this would undo one of the great achievements of recent times, which has been to get inflation down to very low levels—below the levels of our major trading partners. That is an enormous structural change.

The unions are committed to saying, `We will pursue wages policies which will keep us in that position, where we will have inflation at no more than that of our major trading partners'. Australia has never been, for a concerted period in its history, able to have inflation continuously at competitive levels. If we are able to achieve that now, and go ahead with growth on that basis, that is a fantastic structural change, and one which will be of enormous benefit to our manufacturers and exporters.

But what would the Opposition do? It would drop a 5 per cent inflation effect, at least, on that through the goods and services tax. This would totally blow apart the arrangements in relation to wages, lead us to countervailing wages claims for compensation, and take us back into the high inflation mould. That is what its policies are about.

The Opposition says that it will all just pass through in a year, but it knows that is not going to be the case unless it really grinds the economy into the ground by exceedingly stringent fiscal and monetary policies. That is what it would do. It would have to if it were going to stop inflation becoming endemic.

We have typical examples of the Opposition's absurdly over-the-top policies. The honourable member for Mayo attacks us for engaging in privatisation. Privatisation is something which this Government has pursued to a certain degree. It believes it has done so in a measured and sensible way and one which will bring about substantial benefits in terms of increased efficiency in some of those industries and certainly a return to the Budget. But the Opposition wants to go right over the top and privatise just about everything in sight. In the process of doing that, it would be likely to cause substantial damage to the Australian economy.

The fundamental tenet of the proposition of the honourable member for Mayo is therefore utterly untrue. It is simply untrue to say that this Government has not been able to address the fundamental issues. It has addressed those fundamental issues in an extraordinarily diligent way since the time it came to office. If one looks at what is happening now in the Australian economy one can see the fruits of that approach beginning to arrive. One can see it in things such as the growth in manufacturing exports. There has been enormous growth in manufacturing exports. Why? It is because people are able to be competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because there is a recession.

—It is not just because there is a recession. I would certainly agree that some products would be exported because there is a shortage of demand in the domestic market. But overwhelmingly—and we can see it in industry after industry—it is because investments are being made to commit to the export industry. We can see that in the vehicle industry, which would be destroyed by the Opposition. Virtually the whole of the production of Holden's engine works in Melbourne is exported—virtually all the engines it produces are exported. We can see it in the decision to export the Ford Capri. It was not built for the Australian market; it was built because it could be exported.

PARA.TAB: In industry after industry these examples of enormous growth are beginning to appear. Everyone can see that they are there, except those who will not see. Those who will not see are those people who sit opposite. Everyone else in the community who is an objective observer can see that these things are happening. They can see that the Australian economy is becoming much more competitive and that it is able to develop a much broader and more sophisticated array of exports—both goods and services. They can see that it does not need the absurdly extreme policies of the Opposition to bring about the kind of change that the Australian economy needs because this change is already happening under current policies. In fact, it would be jeopardised by the policies pursued by the Opposition.

Those opposite say that they would produce great benefits for business by taking $20 billion in taxes off business. This is one of the great, absurd arguments of all time. They are saying, `We'll take off payroll tax, the wholesale sales tax and the fuel tax—that's $20 billion in taxes off business—and therefore business will be free to grow and there will be a tremendous burst of economic activity'. I have never heard such nonsense in my life. They are totally ignoring the $27 billion in taxes that they would impose through the goods and services tax. Those opposite take $20 billion off business inputs and put $27 billion in tax on business outputs. The consumer pays either way. The fact that there would be a 5 per cent inflation impact demonstrates that the consumer would pay more. Where is the great economic benefit in that? Where is this great burst of economic activity going to come from?

The honourable member for Mayo said that in 1977 the Labor Party proposed a payroll tax abolition and said that it would create 200,000 jobs. That is true; we said that then. Obviously, on its own payroll tax abolition would probably have some employment-inducing effects. But those opposite are not proposing that; they are proposing a much bigger tax on wages. Through the goods and services tax, they are proposing a $27 billion tax on value added. What is value added? Value added is wages and profits—overwhelmingly it is wages. Those opposite are proposing an estimated $27 billion tax on wages. They will take off a $6 billion tax, put on a $20 billion tax and then say, `Haven't we had a tremendous reduction in taxes on wages and won't a million flowers bloom in the form of increased jobs?'. It is absolute and arrant nonsense. There is no reason to believe that in any sense.
Mr Filing interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You, too. There is the absurdity of the proposition of those opposite that they have some solution to employment. They stand up here telling us how they are concerned about employment and asking us questions about Darren and so on, as though they are concerned about it, when in fact their policies are employment destructive. Another example of that is that they would take away the job placement function from the CES. That body, which has the capacity to and does put the overwhelming number of people in jobs, would be abolished; it would be privatised. Those opposite would make the unemployed pay or business pay. Either way, there would be increased costs. If those costs are borne by the unemployed, they would be greatly increased costs. Certainly placement would be done much less efficiently than it would be done under this Government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to the abysmal performance in Question Time today of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—
—Which he cut short.

—Which he cut short—and also particularly the pathetic performance of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) at the end, which is the reason that the Prime Minister cut Question Time short, and then listening to the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) frothing at the mouth now, I am pleased to be here debating this matter of public importance today because I think the wording of the MPI encapsulates the feelings that my constituents express to me as I travel around my electorate. Everywhere I go people come up to me and say, `Can't you, for heaven's sake, do something about this Prime Minister? It seems he spends all his time in the House badmouthing you, using foul language, abusing people, calling black white, and doing things like that, rather than doing something about the country's ills that he himself has created'. Quite frankly, I find it very hard to argue against that.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister is the most disliked man in Australia today, and if honourable members do not believe that they only have to go to a party or function and mention the words `Paul Keating'. People immediately start to froth at the mouth. Not only is he the person regarded as having the foulest mouth in Australia today, not only is he the person who abuses others the most, but, in addition, he has the worst track record of any Treasurer in Australia's history. On top of that, he is now developing a reputation as a politician who is the most inconsistent in his utterances when it comes to adhering to previously espoused policy.

The Prime Minister has taken inconsistency, expediency, and political flip-flopping to Himalayan heights. I remember that when I first came into this place I used to sit over here and listen to the Prime Minister, who was then Treasurer, in Question Time. He was always going on about people diving into the bunkers at the first whiff of grapeshot going over the bow. Leaving aside the fact that I always thought that bunkers were where the diesel for the ships was stored and one would probably be better off being on the deck, what did I observe when this fellow finally managed to stab Bob Hawke in the back and become Prime Minister himself? He had been Prime Minister for only a month or so when along came the Wills by-election. Do honourable members remember that? I was sitting here one day and up came the question of tariffs. When the first whiff of political grapeshot went over the bow, where was the Prime Minister? He was espousing the virtue of high tariffs. I could not believe it. I had sat here for seven years hearing and agreeing that tariffs should be coming down. The Prime Minister was in the job where he actually had responsibility for tariffs, yet, with a by-election coming up in one of the safest Labor seats in Australia, with the first whiff of political grapeshot over the bow, there he was taking a bath in the diesel tank below the deck. I could not believe it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who won the seat?

—Exactly. This is the same fellow who only weeks before was calling tariffs an insidious cancer on Australia. This is the fellow who only the year before had said the tariffs were a poison on Australian manufacturing. The Prime Minister is not up there saying that we have to keep them up and maintain the levels of high tariffs to maintain employment.

PARA.TAB: What is happening now? We have another election coming up. If one puts one's nose northwards one can almost smell the political grapeshot coming up again. What is the Prime Minister doing? He is espousing high tariffs again. This is the fellow who was saying only last week in Question Time that the effective rate of tariff protection back in 1988 was 243 per cent and how his Party will bring them down to 36 per cent at the effective rate. But when the Opposition wants to take them from 36 per cent down to 5 per cent nominal, which is probably 10 or 15 per cent when grossed up to the effective rate, and we want to knock another 20 percentage points off that, all of a sudden that is somehow disastrous. It is okay to lower them 207 per cent, but if one wants to lower them 10 per cent of that it is somehow disastrous. I can only recommend that the Prime Minister enrol in some remedial maths classes.

The previous speaker on this side of the House read out those comments of the Prime Minister on the John Laws show and they are worth referring to again. The Prime Minister early in March this year said:

SPEECH.PARA: The package of measures announced today ends forever Australia's sorry association with the tariff as a device for Australia's industrial development.
He then went on the John Laws show and said:
. . . at the end of the phasing, which is 1997 and 2000, we will have removed tariffs altogether.

Either he said it or he did not say it. If the Prime Minister says that he did not mean what he said on that occasion, one cannot believe him ever again. Only two days earlier the Prime Minister was advocating and passionately talking about a reduction in tariffs, but he then flip-flopped on the issue as soon as the Wills by-election came around. The year before he had been rebuking Senator Button for being too slow in reforming tariffs.

PARA.TAB: What the Prime Minister says one day with apparent conviction he professes as if his words were etched in concrete, yet he comes out the next day and calls black white. There is no better example of this than an article in the Canberra Times last Friday by Richard Farmer, who is hardly a person enamoured to our side of politics. In this article he referred to the depressing tariff debate we have had in this country this century where we keep going over and over the same arguments. He said that a supine press, as he called it, is not responsible in holding Ministers to what they say. Richard Farmer stated in the article:
What a pity that journalists have not felt obliged to write what they know is the truth. What a delight it would have been to see a story like this:

"Australian vehicle manufacturers tried again yesterday to use the natural fear of politicians on the eve of an election to get a special advantage for themselves at the price of making Australians pay thousands of dollars more for their cars.
"The car makers claimed, as they have every year since the establishment of the first car assembly plant in the 1940s, that they could not survive without tariff protection.
"Prime Minister Paul Keating, desperately trying to hang on to office, succumbed to the industry pressure and pretended that he knew how vital the tariff was.

"Mr Keating thought it politically expedient to suggest that he agreed that a tariff level of 15 per cent was somehow vital. Mr Keating chose to mislead the electorate by ignoring the fact that the devaluation of the Australian dollar had recently increased effective protection against imports by some 20 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing encapsulates better than this article by Richard Farmer, a former Labor supporter, the total hypocrisy and expediency of this Government, and in particular the expediency of the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —A fraud and a hypocrite.

—Indeed, he is. We have only to turn back to those statements in 1985 when there was no more passionate advocate of a GST in Australia than the Prime Minister. I tell everybody in my electorate at every opportunity that the Prime Minister has not changed his mind. Leopards do not change their spots. He has not changed his mind. He believed then that a GST was the best policy for Australia and he stills believes it today. He just will not say so because he is frightened of losing votes. The whiff of grapeshot has gone over the bow and he is in the bunker below. But let us turn back to some of his quotes:

SPEECH.PARA: All of us, especially those in positions of influence, have I believe, an important duty to ensure that the debate . . . remains on this higher plane.
One has only to see his performance in Question Time. Another quote was:
I have no doubt that, unless this climate is acted upon, tax reform will be thrown back into the too hard basket for another 20 to 30 years at immense cost to the vast majority of Australians.

The present tax system is riddled with ad hoc concessions which destroy investment decisions. Instead of being made on the basis of genuine economic return, investment decisions are often made on the basis of short-run cash flow as determined by the tax law.
He believed it was the best thing to do for Australia then and he stills believes it now but he has not got the guts to say so. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance really reflects the way the debate has gone in this Parliament over the last week and the absolute disarray of the Opposition on a series of issues relating to tariffs, its general policy perspective as far as the economy is concerned and fundamentally the total inflexibility of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to address the issues that areas of business and the broader areas of the community are concerned about in order to ensure that we get economic recovery.

PARA.TAB: All we got from the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) and the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) was a diatribe of abuse directed at the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). There was no substance and no structure to what they propose as far as their policies are concerned. There was no attempt to answer the fact that industries around the country, particularly industries such as the motor vehicle industry and the sugar industry, are telling those opposite that their policies will not work, that their policies will decimate those industries and that there will not be investment at the Mitsubishi plant in Australia if the Leader of the Opposition proceeds with his mad experiment of the zero tariff approach and the other things that are part of his agenda. All of those things that come forward from various segments of the community to suggest to the Opposition, `At least think again; have dialogue and discussions before proceeding with that sort of structure' have met with derision and abuse—the sort of abuse and the sorts of comments that we got from the honourable member for Parkes and his colleagues when he was speaking.

TAB.TAB: Nothing can dispute the fact that, for instance, the executives of many of the motor vehicle companies have said that the Opposition's policies just will not produce investment. If the Opposition wants to have its way and say that the motor vehicle industry is an optional extra for Australia, that the workers in that industry do not matter, that the industry does not matter and that the exports that have been generated through the motor vehicle component industry do not matter, that is fine. Let those opposite have that policy; but let the people of Australia understand what the net effect of that policy would be and contrast that with the Government, which is dealing with a very deep recession and creating the economic recovery that is necessary, but at the same time is recognising that we have a part to play in the world and that the best way for us to achieve that is to get a combination of national and international perspectives.

PARA.TAB: It is clear, as the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) said in his contribution that, when we get this sort of spurious MPI that we have had from the Opposition, we are entitled to ask: what about wages policy? Does wages policy matter? Of course it matters; yet the Opposition suggests that having a meaningful wages policy, a dialogue with the trade union movement, also is an optional extra. It wants to decimate the trade union movement of Australia and it is prepared to go along with that as part of this phoney experiment that it wants to place upon the people of Australia.

Having looked at the questions relating to employment and industrial relations, we then turn to the questions relating to overall economic conditions. We have been through a period of very difficult economic times in Australia. But we are not unique; that has been the case around the world. We have a chance in Australia because we now have a low inflation setting; we now have inflation at the lowest level in 20 years. We have the lowest interest rate setting in 20 years and manufactured exports at the highest level for many years—in record terms in fact. The fact that we have those ingredients should be the basis for new investment to occur, for real sustainable recovery to occur and for jobs to grow.

We have not just relied on having those conditions right. The Prime Minister and the Government recognised that, as well as those preconditions for recovery, there was an important need for government to reflect the continuing stimulus in the economy and create circumstances for growth by a fiscal stimulus, as occurred through the Budget, the One Nation statement and the youth jobs statement in July. All of those things are important.

The Opposition's alternative to having that sort of fiscal stimulus is to say, `We'd like to take $7 billion out of Commonwealth outlays'—to hit the very people who need assistance in these difficult times. The Opposition is quite happy to have the unemployed tossed out on the street after nine months. It is quite happy to have a situation in which people who need to provide for themselves—for example, accommodation for the aged—elect to have an extra 15 per cent lumped onto those sorts of services. That is okay; in the view of the Opposition it does not matter about those people.

Clearly, there does need to be a balance of policy. There does need to be a recognition that we cannot have this extreme right wing ideology lumped on the people of Australia come what may: `It does not matter what happens, we can have this experiment thrust on the people of Australia'. Adopting the Hewson experiment would be a disaster for Australia. It would put an end to those lights of economic recovery that are starting to shine. Putting the Leader of the Opposition in charge of economic policy in Australia would be the equivalent of putting Guy Fawkes in charge of an explosives factory. That is an experiment I do not believe the people of Australia would want. I am sure that, as time goes on, the people of Australia, particularly those in the motor vehicle and sugar industries, will start to speak up and make it known that they are not prepared to be wiped out; that they are not prepared to let the Leader of the Opposition and his colleagues loose on this sort of setting for Australia.

It is important to note that in the last week we have seen some people starting to get out of the Opposition Leader's cart. The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred) and the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) are starting to raise serious questions because they have manufacturing industry in their States and areas. They are saying, `We're not too sure that this manic desire of the Leader of the Opposition to wipe out the motor vehicle industry is such a good idea. We're prepared to speak up and say this might not be the best way to go'.

They are entitled to speak up. Indeed, they have a responsibility to speak up so that the people of Australia understand that it is no good just branding the leaders of our motor vehicle industries as liars, as the Leader of the Opposition has been prone to do. It is one thing to denigrate the people in the Parliament—the Prime Minister and the Ministers—but we get the spectacle of continual denigration of those outside the Parliament who disagree with the Leader of the Opposition.

The Reserve Bank is constantly under attack. Renters are under attack; they have committed some sort of heinous crime. The Greens are constantly under attack. All of the people who happen to question some policies of the Leader of the Opposition are subject to the sort of abuse that we have witnessed today from the honourable member for Mayo. The truth is that those people have a legitimate point to make as well. They are entitled to have their views heard. We are entitled to ensure that, in the development of national policy by the Government or the Opposition, some regard is paid to the interests of Australians in the broader context.

We now have the unique spectacle of the Leader of the Opposition, as part of this process, having reached the stage of engaging in international insults. Over the weekend, both the United States and Japan—Japan, our largest trading partner, with which we have a tremendous trade surplus—have been forced to come to the unique position of attack in response to the Leader of the Opposition's comments. Japan is saying, `Some of the comments of the shadow Minister for trade are a bit far-fetched'. As Greg Sheridan said in Saturday's Australian:

SPEECH.PARA: You've got to hand it to the Opposition. They've pulled off an amazing quinella. They have managed to get themselves criticised, on the very same day, by the embassies of the two countries most important to Australia: our two top trading partners, the United States and Japan.
It is important to understand the psychology and politics of this. It is an extraordinary event.

Much of what has been going on in recent times with the Leader of the Opposition is an extraordinary event. The more the pressure is put on the Opposition to explain how it is going to deal with the effects of its policies and the more it is asked to explain the impact of what its policies will be, the more amazing it becomes, the more abuse we get, the more strange the circumstances and behaviour, and the more dramatic are the Opposition's announcements.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the extraordinary turn in circumstances of the Leader of the Opposition in relation to the trade issue. How did we get some sort of ordered policy in the Opposition Leader's trade policies? There was not any order; there was not any coherence. It really was policy on the run. What did we get when he went to North Queensland? He said, `I've got to do something to get this sugar industry off my back. I've got to find some way of getting the sugar industry not to focus on what we are planning to do with our zero tariffs on sugar. We've got to try to do something about it'. What did he do? He dreamt up this notion: `We'll get in and attack our trading partners. That'll be the best way of getting us off the hook'. As we have seen, it has not got him off the hook. In relation to trade and the broader economic issues, the Government has, rightly, focused the attack on the Opposition and where its policies will affect Australia very severely and adversely, as they will in the sugar and motor vehicle industries.

It is no good saying now that our policies are really just the same. We know the policies are not the same. We know that fundamentally there is a gulf between the policies of the two sides. Zero does not equal 15; it does not equal 25. What really matters is that we do have a car plan; we do have a commitment to Australian industry; and we do have a commitment to economic recovery and economic growth. The Government's strategy all through this process, led by the Prime Minister, has been to achieve that objective. (Time expired)
