DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, I present the report of the Committee entitled Australia's Refugee and Humanitarian System: Achieving a Balance Between Refuge and Control, including dissenting reports, together with the minutes of the proceedings and several volumes of evidence received by the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to present the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations regarding its inquiry into refugee and humanitarian visas and permits. The report is entitled Australia's Refugee and Humanitarian System: Achieving a Balance Between Refuge and Control. It focuses on all issues concerning onshore asylum seekers—that is, those persons who seek asylum at Australia's borders—and persons who are temporary residents or illegal entrants in Australia and who seek asylum from within Australia.

PARA.TAB: This report is the most comprehensive assessment of the onshore refugee situation yet undertaken in Australia by any public body. During the inquiry the Committee received a large number of submissions and took a considerable amount of public evidence at hearings over a two-year period. The Committee's inquiry and this report have come at a critical time. Today the world is faced with a refugee crisis of proportions not seen since the Second World War. Australia, like many other countries around the world, is faced with an increasing number of asylum seekers applying for refugee status, either at the border or once they have entered the country. It is estimated that currently there are approximately 17.5 million refugees worldwide. With the continuing crisis in the former Yugoslavia, this number is expected to increase in the near future.

In a recent visit which I undertook to several European nations, I was able to witness first-hand the extreme difficulties which many countries are facing as a result of the refugee crisis. I held discussions with officials from countries such as Germany, which are bearing the major refugee burden. I also witnessed the trauma and suffering of the refugees themselves, and was told continually of the need for a solution to this crisis.

To deal with this growing problem, Australia and other major countries of resettlement, such as the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom, have been reviewing and amending their refugee laws and processing arrangements. My Committee's inquiry has been an important part of that review process. With countries around the world looking to each other for solutions to their own refugee difficulties, my Committee's report takes on a significant international dimension. The recommendations in this report will be compared with and assessed against the proposals which other countries are bringing to the refugee debate.

In the report the Committee has sought to achieve a balance between the best humanitarian outcome for asylum seekers, while ensuring that Australia maintains control over its refugee programs and systems. During the inquiry the Committee had to come to terms with a number of changes to Australia's onshore refugee and humanitarian system implemented by the Government. A number of these changes reflect the evidence received by the Committee. Through these changes, the Government has sought to address the deficiencies in the existing processing arrangements which were identified in the course of the inquiry.

Most of the evidence to the inquiry supported the establishment of a simpler and speedier processing system for onshore asylum seekers. There was a strong view that lengthy delays in processing not only disadvantage genuine refugees by prolonging uncertainty in their lives, but also provide an incentive for those who do not have legitimate refugee claims to lodge an asylum application as a mechanism for prolonging their stay in Australia.

In this report, the Committee has noted the recent changes which have been implemented and announced in relation to both the primary refugee decision-making process and the review procedures. At the primary stage, the changes include priority processing of border claimants and detained illegal entrants, time limits on lodgment of applications, and greater emphasis on case officers obtaining information at interview. These measures accord with the Committee's view that the Government should seize the initiative and control refugee determinations.

At the review stage, the changes include the recently announced replacement of the Refugee Status Review Committee with a new and independent Refugee Review Tribunal in 1993. The Committee anticipates that the RRT should be demonstrably fairer, should allow for a more accurate assessment of the merits of a claim, and should be faster and less costly.

The Committee, though, was concerned to ensure that there would be consistency in decision making between the various members appointed to the Tribunal. For this reason, it has recommended the appointment of a senior member to the RRT, who would be responsible for allocating work to Tribunal members to ensure development and enhancement of country expertise, and who would be empowered to establish three-member Tribunal panels to consider model case types for persuasive authority.

During the inquiry one notable criticism of the existing decision-making process was that the information available to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs regarding events and circumstances in particular countries was incomplete and out of date. The Department itself admitted in evidence to the Committee that the data available to it is limited, as its documentation centre is still in its formative stages. To rectify this problem, the Committee has made a series of recommendations aimed at improving the information which is available to both the Department and the review body, and which is used as the basis for their decisions.

In particular, the Committee has recommended that the Department establish and maintain a current and comprehensive database relating to every country in the existing refugee case load for use by departmental officers and the Refugee Review Tribunal. In addition, refugee applicants should be able to request and obtain all publicly available information which is used by the Department or the Tribunal in making their decisions.

The Committee also gave consideration to the existing procedures for granting entry on humanitarian grounds. In the report the Committee has endorsed the principle of providing short term extensions of stay to particular ethnic or nationality groups in humanitarian need. Recent examples of this policy include the concessionary arrangements applied to the nationals of Kuwait and Iraq during the Gulf conflict, and to nationals of the former Yugoslavia.

In the Committee's view, such a policy allows the Government to respond appropriately by providing protection to classes in need, while ensuring that such protection is given for the term of the conflict or disaster which is the basis of the need and not beyond it. To this effect, the Committee has recommended that short term extensions of temporary stay should not only be given to individuals in a class or group affected by civil disorder, but also should be considered for individuals in groups whose homes or livelihoods have been affected by a major natural disaster. The area affected by the civil disorder or natural disaster could be either a nation state or part of a nation state.

To ensure that the temporary extension of stay is given to those who actually need it, the Committee has recommended that, where repeated extensions of stay in excess of one year have been given, before any further permit is granted, the applicants should be expected to show not only that they are citizens of the country affected by the civil strife or natural disaster, but additionally that their homes, livelihood and families are in areas affected or that they would be required to return to the area affected if returned home.

In terms of the general on-shore humanitarian program, the Committee considered the existing procedures for humanitarian entry under which the refugee and humanitarian streams are combined into one process. The Committee was firmly of the view that the refugee and humanitarian streams should not be separated because of previous problems relating to duplicitous applications. However, it has recommended that to assist future decision making in this regard, monitoring of the existing refugee case load is required to determine which cases are more appropriately humanitarian claims rather than refugee claims. The Committee also has recommended that the new Refugee Review Tribunal be empowered to recommend to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) that, in deserving cases which do not meet the requirements for grant of refugee status, the Minister grant stay on humanitarian grounds.

One of the more contentious issues during the inquiry related to Australia's procedures for processing persons who claim asylum at Australia's borders. This includes boat arrivals who under existing requirements are held in detention until their applications for asylum are processed. In particular, the Committee heard considerable criticism about the lengthy detention to which recent boat arrivals have been subjected. In a number of cases, persons have been held in detention for over two years.

Various explanations were given to the Committee for this lengthy detention, particularly of the Cambodian boat arrivals. While some have criticised the processing procedures of the Department, others have been critical of the time taken by lawyers to lodge refugee applications for these people. The Committee is firmly of the view that, regardless of where the blame should be apportioned, the detention of these boat arrivals has lasted far too long. It is imperative that the procedures which are in place do not allow a repetition of such lengthy detention.

In this regard the Committee has noted the recent initiatives of the Government aimed at achieving a more efficient and expeditious determination system for border claimants, including the adoption of processing target dates. As recommended in an interim letter of advice which the Committee provided to the Minister in July 1991, the Committee also has noted the amendments to the Migration Act in May this year, which set out the intentions of the Parliament that undocumented boat arrivals should be held in detention until their status is determined but that such detention should not extend beyond a designated timeframe.

In relation to this latest legislation, the Committee is of the view that even though it was introduced as an interim measure it has added to the complexity of the border arrangements. There is now a confusing array of provisions focused not so much on the status of the person as on his mode of arrival in Australia. There is a variety of terms now used to describe border claimants. In response, the Committee has recommended that the provisions in the Migration Act relating to border claimants be rewritten in a simplified and comprehensible manner, using as far as possible a single descriptive term for border claimants.

As for existing detention arrangements, the Committee has recommended that, given the new expeditious processing procedures for border claimants, the Government retain the policy of holding border claimants in detention until such time as their applications can be processed. Priority, though, must be directed to the expeditious processing of border claimants, with adequate resources to be directed to the Department to ensure that the processing targets are met.

The Committee also has recommended that the detention facility at Port Hedland be maintained. While the Committee heard various criticisms about the Port Hedland facility—particularly about its remote location—the Committee found that the facility has proved useful in ensuring improved access to detainees and improved opportunities for obtaining information relevant to their claims. In particular, the Committee took note of evidence from one group of lawyers working at Port Hedland that the isolation of the facility enables those lawyers who are assisting border claimants to focus on the task of preparing applicants' claims without the usual daily distractions.

With regard to the role of lawyers in the refugee processing system, the Committee has recommended that public funding be available for the provision of legal assistance to border claimants in relation to the preparation of primary applications for refugee status. However, the Committee felt that public funding should not be available for pursuing unmeritorious claims through every avenue of appeal. Accordingly, it has recommended that publicly funded legal assistance to refugee claimants seeking review of a refusal decision be provided via the Legal Aid Commission, based on the merits of that particular case.

The Committee also considered the issue of permanent residence for refugee applicants. In the past, Australia granted refugees immediate resident status. However, this policy was modified in June 1990, when new regulations were introduced which gave refugees four years temporary stay, with the option of obtaining permanent residence at the end of the four years, subject to the availability of places in the migration program.

While endorsing the general principle of granting four-year temporary stay to refugees, the Committee was concerned about the inflexibility of this arrangement. In the Committee's view, there are some refugees, notably torture and trauma victims, who ought not to be required to wait out their full four-year temporary permit if places in the refugee program are immediately available or become available at some earlier time within the four years. Recommendations to this effect are contained in the report.

I now turn to the final chapter of the report, dealing with citizens of the People's Republic of China. This issue was the subject of much debate during the inquiry and within the Committee itself. In particular, considerable attention was focused on the position of PRC nationals who had arrived in Australia prior to the incident in Tiananmen Square in June 1989, and the Government's decision to grant such persons four year temporary entry permits. Debate within the Committee was directed especially to the undertaking given by then Prime Minister Hawke that no PRC national in Australia before 20 June 1989 would be forced to return to China against his will. This undertaking was reaffirmed in April 1992 by the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

The Committee concluded that while recent policy in relation to PRC citizens has been aimed at providing a humanitarian response to persons, particularly students, affected by the unrest in China, it has contributed significantly to the immense burden which has been placed on Australia's refugee determination system over the past three years. It has also led to a great deal of uncertainty among PRC nationals in Australia.

The Committee considered that there are difficulties in granting permanent residence to pre-Tiananmen Chinese as a class. It also considered that there are problems if all such PRC citizens are rejected for permanent residence when their temporary entry permits expire in June 1994. Such a move would raise the alarming possibility of the refugee determination system being clogged with some 10,000 PRC citizens when their temporary entry permits expire in June 1994.

In searching for a solution to this problem, the Committee came to a consensus agreement that Australia, as a nation, must stand by the word of its Prime Minister, and should honour the spirit of the commitment which was made to those PRC nationals. However, there was disagreement in the Committee as to what constitutes a solution to the PRC dilemma within the spirit of the Prime Minister's commitment.

On this question, I, as Chairman, differ from the majority view of the Committee. The majority has recommended that the Government should end the uncertainty concerning the long term future of PRC permit holders in Australia by announcing the arrangements which will be used to differentiate between those who from June 1994 will be granted permanent residence, those who may be granted a further four-year temporary entry permit, and those who will be returned to the PRC. The majority has recommended that from June 1994 PRC permit holders should be able to apply either for permanent residence, on the basis of already existing criteria for change of status, or for continuing protection, on a case by case basis against internationally accepted refugee criteria. The majority, though, has gone on to recommend that those who do not meet these selection criteria should be granted, on expiry of their permits, a short extension of stay, say three months, to put their affairs in order and make appropriate arrangements for departing Australia.

In my view, the recommendations of the majority clearly contradict the spirit of the Prime Minister's commitment that no PRC permit holder will be returned to China against his will. The recommendations, if adopted, probably would result in the vast majority of PRC permit holders being required to return to China after June 1994. I cannot support such a drastic solution.

Instead, I have recommended that all PRC permit holders be eligible to apply for permanent residence provided that they satisfy certain criteria, and that all applications be considered on a case by case basis as to whether they satisfy the criteria for a specially designed PRC permanent entry permit. I have recommended that all applicants must show, in order to qualify, that they have strong humanitarian grounds, such as the possibility of facing severe discrimination or detention on return, and/or that they have appropriate connections with Australia, that they have been making a worthwhile contribution to Australia, and that they satisfy public interest criteria. Those applicants who do satisfy these criteria should be given permanent residence, while the remainder should continue to be given temporary entry permits until such time as they thought it safe to return to China. My strongest recommendation is that at no stage should they be forced to return against their will.

My recommendations are similar to those in the other minority report on this issue by Senator Barney Cooney, who suggests that two categories should be available for this group of PRC nationals at the end of June 1994. Under Senator Cooney's proposals the first category is to give them permanent residence, while the second is to continue the temporary entry status they now enjoy.

Leaving aside the differences in the Committee on the PRC issue, it is important to note that all other recommendations in this report have been endorsed unanimously by the Committee. To achieve this result, a great deal of hard work has been undertaken by Committee members. I wish to express my appreciation to my fellow Committee members for their assistance during this long and difficult inquiry. Special thanks also go to the Committee's legal adviser, Dr Kathryn Cronin, the current Committee Secretary, Mr Andres Lomp, the previous Secretary, Ms Robina Mills, and Secretariat staff, Ms Dianne Fraser and Ms Cassandra Paulus. I would also like to thank the many foreign government representatives and officials who provided the Committee and me with much useful information.

At the conclusion of this inquiry, it is evident to me that the refugee crisis is an international problem which will continue through this decade and into the twenty-first century. As a result, it is important that nations such as Australia continue to pursue the twin goals of achieving the best humanitarian outcome for asylum seekers, while maintaining control over their refugee programs and systems. It is towards these goals that the Committee has directed its recommendations in this report. I urge the Government to give immediate attention to the implementation of these recommendations. I commend the report to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly to the report entitled Australia's Refugee and Humanitarian System: Achieving a Balance between Refuge and Control. I urge the Government to adopt the recommendations in the report in their entirety. Before I move to the report itself, I join with the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), in thanking the Committee's advisers and assistants, particularly Dr Kathryn Cronin, who assists very much as our legal adviser, our Secretary, Mr Andres Lomp, and his predecessor, Robina Mills, as well as the other staff. It is particularly important that this be noted because they have put an enormous amount of work and effort into the report. I am sorry that the Chairman of the Committee is not here to hear the comments that I offer in relation to the report because it is one of the more notable reports that the Parliament has seen in a long time.

PARA.TAB: First, the report is one with a bipartisan view—not one formed in the way which is often assumed; but one which is formed between all members of the Opposition and a majority of members of the Government. It is in relation to the most perplexing issue that needs to be resolved in the refugee area, and the issue which gave rise to the problems that Australia faces today in dealing with the refugee issue: the outstanding question of the PRC nationals who were here in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre.

All members of the Committee are conscious of the emotional environment in which a lot of the decisions in this area were taken. But this report catalogues in the most comprehensive way how the decisions taken in this area—starting with the decisions taken by the Government to market to PRC nationals in Australia the education of the English language—undermined the integrity of our immigration program and our ability to assist those people who have a need for refugee status.

The Committee's report gives all of the sorry history in terms of the absence of control and the inability to undertake bona fides testing. It deals with the number of students who were allowed to arrive in Australia before the Tiananmen Square event and the number of them who were already here illegally before that event took place; in other words, those who had already breached visa conditions.

The report also catalogues the number of people who came after the Tiananmen Square event and who have not left Australia; that is, the 44,644 people who came up to 31 May 1991 and the 16,382 who left. We had something of the order of 28,000 at that point of time still here in Australia. The report clearly deals with this matter in the most honest and frank way that any committee could, with a view to providing to the Government helpful advice as to the way this long term problem might be dealt with and assistance in ensuring that we have non-discriminatory principles in place.

As the honourable member for Calwell commented, this report is one that a majority of members of the Committee—seven out of nine members—have agreed to entirely. The only people out of step were the Chairman and one other member. The majority recommendations on this issue present a challenge to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Government. They call for the abandonment of the proposals put in place by former Prime Minister Hawke, which constituted a discriminatory approach and gave the PRC nationals preferential treatment.

The Opposition and Government members who formed the majority view of this Committee have taken a truly bipartisan approach. It is our view that the Government should demonstrate some flexibility and appreciation of the longstanding bipartisan principles of migration and make it clear that from 1994, under either a coalition or Labor government, the position will be as follows: the uncertainty concerning the long term future of the PRC permit holders will be resolved; from June 1994 permanent residence will be granted to those who hold four-year temporary entry permits on the same basis as any other applicant for permanent residence; non-discriminatory criteria will be an important principle in the refugee determination system; and that, in addition to the granting of permanent residence using universal selection criteria, there will be continued protection, established on a case by case basis against internationally accepted criteria, for any others who have a need for ongoing protection.

We took the view that, to assist in determining whether there is a need for ongoing protection for PRC permanent entry holders on an impermanent country assessment of human rights, the Government should be prepared to put together information to enable those people to be properly assessed against the situation in China and assurances should be sought from the Government of the People's Republic of China to ensure that permanent PRC permit holders who return to the People's Republic of China will not suffer discrimination or detention upon their return. We further determined that those PRC permit holders who do not meet selection criteria should be granted, on the expiry of their permits, a short extension of stay for, say, three months to enable them to put their affairs in order and to make appropriate arrangements for departing from Australia.

I want to make a point about this. The Chairman in his statement suggested that the Committee was in some way walking away from the statement of the former Prime Minister and not wanting to give effect to his undertaking. Let me make it clear that we did not want to make a political point of that sort, and we did not seek to do so. We sought to put in place provisions that would enable this matter to be resolved without rancour or difficulty and in a bipartisan way. As I said, it is an honest and frank assessment.

The majority of members of the Committee came to this view for a number of reasons. I want to emphasise two of them to ensure that it is well understood. Firstly, the majority of the members of the Committee wanted in place consistent and principled decision making; they wanted the same rules to apply to anybody from any part of the world. We wanted to get those provisions back in place. Secondly, we did not want a situation where we had, in effect, quasi-guest worker status for those people who are in Australia under these arrangements at this time.

If we adopt the view that is put by the Chairman or Senator Cooney, we are saying, `Look, we are going to have permanent residency for some people but we are going to have another class which will be for temporary entry, but quasi-permanent in character'. It would not give right to any other entitlements that people might have for benefits in Australia, even if they remain here for the whole of their lifetime. It would not give rise to rights to family reunion to the full extent that would apply to anybody else who is in Australia. In other words, it would open up Australia to a form of guest worker status that, as we have seen, has bedevilled countries in other parts of the world. All of us look in anguish at what is happening in Germany at this time. One of the reasons is that it has this guest worker status where people are brought in and allowed to remain permanently. They may be there for generations, but they are not citizens of the country. The majority of members do not want to see that occur in this country.

As I said, this is a most comprehensive report; it is one that is very worthy of this Government's consideration. I am glad the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) is here because what we endeavoured to do in the most constructive way possible was to canvass the international situation—the problem that is affecting the world generally—

TALK.START.PARA: —You'll note I have done a lot of things in there, too, won't you?

—The Committee has acknowledged many of the matters that the Government has addressed and has sought to assist by suggesting, with helpful advice, further steps that the Government might take. I will go through some of those points that ought to be made. We have looked at the problem that has been occasioned by the fact that refugee claimants, if they are given refugee status, have to apply for four-year temporary entry permits. We are conscious that there are some people, particularly those who have suffered torture and trauma, who are disadvantaged through not being able to consider permanent residency. We have sought to address that. I think it is a very appropriate series of recommendations that has been made.

PARA.TAB: In relation to humanitarian policy, we have endorsed the approach that the Government has taken, except for the PRC student issue, and given some helpful advice as to the way that can work in the future. In relation to the Minister's new proposals for a refugee tribunal, we have given advice as to the way in which that organisation ought to operate to overcome the problems that have occurred in the development of the Immigration Review Tribunal. We have suggested that there ought to be a senior member who is able to bring together members of the panel to constitute an appeal body to ensure that they can deal with model cases, and establish a framework of decision making which will bind all the members of the tribunal together. We think that is a very positive and helpful suggestion.

We have suggested a positive approach to the question of offering legal advice. We wanted to bring to an end this business of providing legal advice right through the courts and the appeal arrangements. One should give them advice in the beginning and ensure that it is done properly, but take away the further extended nature of advice that now appears to be offered to many of those people who are seeking to make non bona fide claims. We have suggested the aid should only be available where there is a prima facie case.

We are very critical of the fact that people have been held in detention for 2 1/2 years, but we do not want to undermine that system. We have suggested further steps that might be taken in relation to dealing with those who are held in detention. We believe that the putting in place of further arrangements will in part assist in relation to that, but clearly there is a view in the Committee's mind that the refugee tribunal needs to be the last resort and further appeals ought to be constrained. If it is helpful to the Minister to have that advice in putting in place a new regime, he will find it in this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about the Federal Court?
—We want it constrained.
—I have announced that I am going to.

—Yes, I have seen the Minister's announcement. As I have said, this bipartisan report is designed to give the Minister every assistance in relation to that. I do not wish to detain the House further. It is a very comprehensive review; it is a balanced report; it is one where the Government ought to pick up all the Committee's recommendations. The Minister should note that on this matter the Chairman of the Committee is very much on his own.

—I want to add a few words to the debate in relation to the report by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Relations, entitled Australia's Refugee and Humanitarian System: Achieving a balance between refuge and control. I know the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) is about to return to Cabinet. I wish there was somebody there with some sense; I do not know that the Minister will add much, but one hopes that he might.

PARA.TAB: As far as this report is concerned, I want to do as both the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Committee have done and commend Dr Kathryn Cronin and the staff of the Committee. The preparation and the work that has gone into the report has been excellent and they certainly deserve commendation. Ms Robina Mills, who was Mr Andres Lomp's predecessor, also deserves to be thanked for the contribution she made. But there is no doubt that the work of Dr Kathryn Cronin has been outstanding. We are extraordinarily fortunate to have had the benefit of her advice and guidance.

I want to set down a bit of the background to the report and comment on it, because those points have not been brought out. Australia is in a rather different position from that which obtained since the end of World War II. It is not new for Australia to receive refugees, but it is true that only in recent years has the number of applicants from our region arriving by sea become a significant feature in the determination of refugee status.

I commend those who are interested in the subject to table 3.1 on page 34 of the report. That table sets out the number of refugees arriving in Australia from January 1945 to June 1984 from the top 14 source nationalities. Importantly, that table indicates that the dimension of the refugee problem around the world today, as the report itself identifies, is significantly in Europe. Indeed, in an earlier table in the report, on page 14, table 2.1, the applications for asylum in European community countries are identified.

In the immediate postwar years, Australia played a very important part in receiving refugees from the displaced peoples of Europe. It was that mass migration in the postwar years that largely changed the character of our country. All of us recognise and commend the influence that those who came from Europe have had on our culture and our society at large. In more recent years the movement of refugees has come significantly from the region around us and many of those people have arrived by sea rather than by plane. This report identifies the difference.

Those who come by plane are in a different position, and to a large degree they have been dealt with fairly satisfactorily; although I think all of us have been a little concerned about some stories we have heard of people who have applied for refugee status and who perhaps have not been given the consideration they should have been. I believe that problem has largely been overcome, although from time to time there are reports which suggest that on occasions the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has not given adequate consideration to those who apply for refugee status on arrival at airports. It is very important to ensure that there is equity of treatment between those who arrive by sea and those who arrive by air.

The major problem, as it exists now, appears from table 5.1 on page 98. That table lists the applications for residence awaiting processing, compassionate and humanitarian cases. The number of people indicated in that table—10,928—identifies the crisis in our refugee determinations. It needs to be remembered that as soon as we accept somebody as a refugee we are prejudicing an application by a person who is applying for entry into Australia as a migrant, who might well have been in a queue for a long time. We have laid down the criteria for entry into Australia. While many of us have reservations about some aspects of those criteria, we realise that essentially they mean that some people wait for a long time before they can gain entry. A person who is coming in as a refugee of course gains precedence. I have a worry that there should be equity between those who come in as refugees and those who apply in the normal course to be migrants. That is something that we need to bear in mind.

I do not intend to go over the details of each of the recommendations. I think in general the report is very good. I am one of those who had some doubts about this special status that was given to the Chinese applicants for refugee status post Tiananmen Square, and that is the four-year temporary entry permit. I have that reservation because it seems that we have already created a special entry condition. It is because of the problems of continuing that special entry condition that all the members of the Committee, except the Chairman and Senator Cooney, have come to the conclusion that there has to be some terminal way of putting to an end that temporary entry status.

Of course, there has to be genuine recognition of the rights and responsibilities of Australia to accept those who meet the international criteria of reasonable fear of persecution. I tend to be one of those who think that where there has been a delay in processing, as there has with the Chinese boat people up in Port Hedland, it becomes far more difficult to expel the refugees after they have been here for a time, particularly when they have been in detention—as the report itself identifies, some for more than two years. If people enter, we have to adopt expeditious procedures to process them or an enormous problem is created. I do not think to date we have addressed that problem adequately.

I criticise the Minister and his Department for the way in which they have not required the processing of documentation, and even the lodging of applications. The recommendations in respect of legal aid are designed to ensure that does not occur again. We have suggested that any applicant should have immediate and adequate access to legal advice to ensure that they can apply for refugee status so that the Department in turn can process that as soon as possible. Having talked to some of these applicants, I am worried whether we have treated them in the way in which they should be treated in a humane society.

I think people being confined for long periods of time creates difficulties. My answer is not to support Senator Cooney's minority recommendation, that is, that we release them, it is that we should make sure that their applications are, initially, lodged quickly and then processed quickly. Then we provide not for aid in all cases but only where there is a prime facie case which ensures a reasonable chance of their being successful.

I also commend very much to the Government the system that we recommend with respect to the Refugee Review Tribunal. I think it is essential that there should be a capacity to provide uniformity of judgments. That is why we have recommended the appointment of a senior member to the RRT, who would be responsible for allocating work to Tribunal members to ensure the development and enhancement of country expertise, and who would also be empowered to establish three member tribunals to consider model cases for persuasive authority and precedence.

In the course of looking at that, I am most concerned at what seems to be the inner capacity of the Department with respect to country expertise. It just is not good enough. There needs to be a far better fund of knowledge available within the Department on the state of affairs in each country. If the consequence of the freedom of information applications is that the sources of that information might be disclosed—which means that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade does not provide the information to the Department—that needs to be exempted from FOI applications. As far as I am concerned, the Department has to have better information than appeared to me to be available during the course of our inquiry.

It is quite important that there be an adequate source of information. It has to be current. If the information is provided on a confidential basis, the privacy of source must be protected. I do not see that it needs necessarily to be passed on to applicant. I think that, in circumstances where the applicant claims a right of appeal, it should be only that information which is public that could reasonably be passed on. There are circumstances which obviously need to be taken into account by the Department and the Refugee Review Tribunal in making their determination. It is in that area that I think the Government again needs to take note of the Committee's recommendations.

Finally, I wanted to add two words with respect to the question of the Chinese students. It is a very difficult question. I think all of us recognise that the Government, in its attempt to promote English language instruction, did not put in place adequate supervision of those institutions that were offering English language instruction. I have been concerned that people have paid large sums of money in order to get English language instruction and some of them—certainly, for quite a long while—were disadvantaged because of the processes that they undertook. Some of the bodies in Australia certainly deserve to be criticised for the way they went out to try to attract clientele.

The important thing is that at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre the numbers of people who so flooded the system were such that there now needs to be a resolution to ensure that we get them out of the system. I agree entirely with the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) in his concern that we do not set up permanently a group of people who, one might say, are guest workers. They would have fewer rights as Australians than any other Australian if they were here under some different permanent condition of residence. It creates all sorts of problems if they are not able to participate in family reunions or have employment, and if those who because of their relationship with them, come in under some sort of conditional entry visa and are also denied employment. That is no good for the long term.

Let us face it, as I suggested in the beginning, the number of boat people is likely to increase, not reduce. Whatever the negotiations we have in our region—which I hope are continued to try to ensure equitable treatment—from the flood of movement that is occurring in Europe, we need to understand that we are unlikely to be isolated simply because we are at the other end of the world. Those people from Europe will not come by sea, but we are likely to have to accept numbers of them through our participation within the United Nations and by negotiation with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. I do not want to see us accepting refugees from only one part of the world.

Therefore, I think we have to be very careful in dealing with those from Asia who come by sea so that we do not set up a unique condition of treatment which precludes us from playing a part on a worldwide basis. That is another aspect of the problem that I think needs to be kept in mind. I commend the report to the Parliament. I believe it is worth while. I suggest that the Government and those interested in the refugee question can gain a great deal by looking at the report and the statistics within it. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Mr Johns:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Dr Bob Woods had moved by way of amendment:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

PROCTEXT.PARA: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House expresses its concern that the Government:

PARA.TAB: (1)has failed to implement a satisfactory eligibility checking system so as to prevent non-Australian residents and other ineligible individuals from wrongly receiving expensive pharmaceuticals at prices subsidised by the Government under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and ultimately paid for by the Australian taxpayers;

(2)is attempting to make pharmacists financially responsible for the fraudulent claims of ineligible individuals who obtain subsidised pharmaceuticals under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme at concessional rates;
(3)presented to the House grossly inaccurate costings of the estimated savings of the on-line computer eligibility checking system; and

(4)was publicly forced to reverse its proposal to proceed with the on line computer eligibility checking system following the Senate Committee report which found the estimated savings were inaccurate".

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me pleasure to rise in this debate to speak on the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 because if there is anything that distinguishes the policies of this Labor Government from the policies of the coalition it is health and welfare issues—issues that are the hallmark of a civilised society, and issues that Opposition members would gladly forsake in their pursuit for a society driven by cold, computer-model logic, devoid of compassion for those less fortunate than themselves. This Bill is but a small part of the on-going process of reform that the Government has had in operation since it first came to power in 1983.

PARA.TAB: We are a reforming government and we firmly believe in supplying the Australian public with the best health and welfare system that is humanly possible. This Bill, as has been previously noted, contains a number of minor amendments to health and community services legislation that help to finetune a health and welfare system that is already the envy of the Western world. These amendments include changing the definition of a `patient', changing the name of the head of the Health Insurance Commission to the Managing Director and allowing the cancellation of approval for pharmacists and medical practitioners when they cease to practise.

Before I look at these small yet important changes, I will pause to look at the big picture that was presented in last month's Budget—a Budget, I might add, that would be in stark contrast to any Budget that a coalition Government might have brought down under the same circumstances. To use a medical analogy, we have taken the long term strategy of nursing our patient back to health, whereas if the coalition had been at the controls last month, we would have seen amputations and the flash of keen knives reminiscent of scenes from field hospitals during the American Civil War.

When Kevin Costner in that riveting film Dances With Wolves saw what the good doctor had in store for him and his bloodied leg, he put his boot back on and ran for his life. I suggest that that is exactly what Australian voters will do come the next Federal election when they finally see the knives behind the glib talk of the good doctor who sits opposite—knives that itch with the anticipation of Freddy Kruger's fingernails; knives that are driven by the cold logic of the economic rationalist; knives that believe in the law of the jungle; and knives that would slash $10 billion from government expenditure rather than give billions to aid average Australian families in their time of need.
Last month we witnessed a giant step forward in the ongoing reform of the health system in this country.
Dr Bob Woods interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Lowe should listen to this. The provision of health care services to all Australians under Medicare is the single most important feature of our health system. Medicare was established so that all people, regardless of their location, age or health status, could enter the health care system as equals. It is by repute the most stable and popular health care financing system in the history of this country. Medicare is based on five principles: universality, access, equity, efficiency and simplicity. Its record on delivering on these principles is impressive.

PARA.TAB: But even things that work must move with the times. If we rest on our laurels, as those opposite did with their industry protection polices and others during their long reign in office, we end up with something that suddenly becomes antiquated and harmful to the very society that it was designed to protect. We on this side will never let that happen with Medicare. We move with the times. We look to the future. We care about flesh and blood, not just microchips and steel.

Following nearly three years of review through the national health strategy, the 1992-93 Budget contains a comprehensive package which builds on the foundations of Medicare to make the system more flexible and responsive, to put the needs of people squarely as the focus and to drive the Australian health care system firmly and compassionately into the next century.
Dr Bob Woods interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow Minister ought to listen to this. This Bill is a simple, yet effective, example of the ongoing reform; an example of this Party's dedication to move with the times and get better value for the taxpayers' dollar. Day surgery is being used increasingly where an operation or other surgical procedure can be performed and the patients are sufficiently recovered to return to their own homes within one day. This not only saves the need and cost of having a patient remain in hospital when it is not necessary, but also it allows people to recuperate in more familiar surroundings. The latter point is seen as particularly important for children, where the trauma associated with a stay in hospital may far outweigh that associated with the surgical procedure undergone.

PARA.TAB: Day surgery is seen as particularly relevant for procedures such as ear, eye, nose, throat, bowel, knee and some plastic surgery. Compared with international practices, Australia has a relatively low rate of day surgery. In the US and Canada it is estimated that between 40 per cent and 50 per cent of all surgical procedures are performed in day surgery. In Australia the estimated rate is around 25 per cent.

Under the Medicare incentive package, the Government has financed 130 programs which are aimed at establishing day surgery facilities in public hospitals, with the aim of increasing the percentage of operations performed as day surgery. However, while encouraging the growth of day surgery to replace overnight stays due to cost savings, the Government has been wary of the possibility of procedures currently being performed in doctors' surgeries being transformed into day surgery procedures and therefore attracting higher benefits.

As with most Acts of law, terminology needs to be updated constantly to make it easier to understand and to reflect the true intention of the legislation. Thus in this instance amendments to the Health Insurance Act 1973 will simply remove references to `in-patient' and substitute references to `patient' because under the current definition an in-patient is required to occupy a bed, which does not cover the increasing number of people who are opting to use day surgery. They are only small changes, but it means that we are keeping our fingers on the pulse and we are moving with the times.

Last month we heard about 1992-93 reforms which were based on the national health strategy's research and an understanding of the community's future needs. I suggest that those opposite embark on a little research of their own with regard to the needs of the Australian community. If their research tells them that the people of Australia want to have a health care system where those who cannot pay are sacrificed; if their research tells them that the people of Australia want to pay more for their meat, milk, bread and vegetables; that 16-year-old kids want to beg their bosses to be given a few extra cents beyond the $3 slave wage; that some home buyers want to return to higher interest rates and higher inflation; that sacked Commonwealth public servants want to be kicked off the dole after nine months; and that Australians want to return to the bad old days of industrial chaos and confrontation, I would love to sit down and play a game of poker with them. Talk about come in spinner!

In a recent edition of the Courier-Mail in my home State of Queensland there was a front page photo of an army sharpshooter with the limp carcass of a giant feral cat slung over his shoulder. Several pages on there was a cartoon of a sharpshooter Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) with an equally enormous feral cat dangling dead over his gung-ho masculine shoulders. The only problem was that this cat had a name: it was called the tourist industry. In recent days he has added the car industry to his hit list—it is probably another dead cat.

There is no doubt that the Leader of the Opposition is a dangerous man—a sharpshooter on a mission. His policies are his bullets and from the glint in his eye one can tell that he is not interested in taking any prisoners. This is the big difference between the coalition and the Government: we are healers and those opposite are exterminators. We open doors to the sick, the poor and the homeless. In a computer-model society if you cannot cut the mustard the question asked is, `What purpose do you serve?' rather than, `How can I help you to function better?'.

In my own portfolio of social security I have come under attack at times for launching Department of Social Security youth pilot projects around the country. In these we target homeless youth who are genuinely in need. The question is asked, `But what is your success rate? Can you guarantee that by giving them some income support you are going to get them off the street?' The thing is that there are no guarantees when dealing with human nature. If one used the same logic as those who decry my enthusiasm, one would go around and turn off every life support system in every hospital—firstly, because it is very costly and, secondly, because one cannot guarantee that Mary, John and Kathy are ever going to come out of that coma. We in the Labor Party put names to people; we do not treat them as raw data to be consumed and spat out by cold computers.
Mrs Bailey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the shadow Minister for consumer affairs, who is at the table, is a little concerned because she has the hardest job of anyone in the coalition. She has to go out and sell the consumption tax. I can understand why she is interjecting. In this Bill an amendment to section 4 of the National Health Act 1953 will substitute a new definition of `patient' to include people who attend day hospital facilities. It is a small thing, but we do not want people to miss out on their entitlements.

PARA.TAB: We do not complain about what we spend on health and welfare as do those opposite, who try to paint it as a national disgrace and a total waste of money. On the contrary, we are proud of it. We like to help people; we enjoy it. It is the reason our Party came into being and it is the reason we have been sitting on this side of the House for the greater part of the past decade and coalition members have been sitting on the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —The one million people out of a job want jobs.

—The honourable member interjects to say that one million people are out of work. Does she really think that by imposing a 15 per cent consumption tax and increasing interest rates that will create one million jobs? She is really in fairyland if she thinks that.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order! I suggest that one honourable member debate the question, we do not debate the interjections, and the honourable member for McEwen remain silent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. But we also possess the vision to look at the big picture. That is why last month we announced bonus payments totalling $1.23 billion to improve access to the hospital system, sending a clear message to the States, Territories and public hospitals that access to hospital services is to be on the basis of clinical need and not health insurance status.

PARA.TAB: We are no Big Brother government. Freedom of information, privacy provisions and rights of appeal are all integral facets of any legislation drafted by this Government. In the area of hospital care, in order to further safeguard patients' rights the Government will pursue the enactment of legislation by States, Territories and the Commonwealth, enshrining the principles of Medicare and endorsing a Medicare hospital patients charter and effective mechanisms by which patients may make complaints.

Would those opposite devote so much time to people's rights? In the hard-nosed world of the haves and the have-nots maybe some people simply do not have rights. That is not the kind of world that I want to live in. When I see an American movie there is always the inevitable scene of the dishevelled homeless warming their rag-covered hands around 44 gallon drums of burning refuse as the hero or heroine drives past, either oblivious of the poverty around him or her or frightened by the violence that lurks behind it. With the health and welfare system that Labor has created in this country, these types of scenes will never become the hallmark of Australian films. But under the policies of those opposite it is possible that that will happen because of the cuts that they will impose which will amount to billions of dollars—that is after they have taxed the people.

We are injecting $70.9m into the hospital system which is specifically targeted to reduce waiting lists. So that we can monitor the situation, data on waiting times and lists will be published each year by the independent Australian Institute of Health and Welfare so that the people of Australia can judge for themselves our success in this area.

Last month we announced a $8m package for 1992-93 to encourage general practitioners to relocate to rural areas. We announced a program of immunisation against haemophilus influenza B which is the most common cause of life-threatening bacterial infection in children under five years of age. We are going to build a research database on the supply of dental care which will be used to analyse access and affordability issues, particularly with respect to older people and low income earners.

This is a vibrant government. It is a government committed to continual reform and to meeting the challenges of a changing world. We are not thinking about going backward as are those opposite; we are thinking of going forward. We do not want higher inflation and the higher interest rates with which the Opposition's GST would envelop us. We have been there and we have done that. Unlike those opposite, we are doing something positive about the problems which face Australia. We are not into Madam Lash. We do not get off on gloom and doom as those opposite do every day during Question Time. If some bad figures come in they are into it straightaway; if some good figures come in they start crying about it. We on this side of the House are a positive bunch of people. In fact, I would say that some Opposition members probably secretly enjoy sitting over here during divisions. We see the ones who are momentarily touched by the positive aura that lingers around over here.

We are attentive. The Government knows that things have been tough. That is why we are fixing them—just like we did in 1983 and 1984 when honourable members on the other side of the House last went down with the sinking ship. They must be feeling a sense of deja vu as their captain steers full steam ahead towards the rocks—crash or crash through.

In the Health and Community Services Amendment Bill we also come across some simple housekeeping matters. Amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 will change the name of the general manager to managing director. The main function of the position will remain the same, namely, to manage the affairs of the Health Insurance Commission.

Amendments to the National Health Act 1953 will give the secretary power to cancel approval of pharmacists or medical practitioners if they are not carrying on the business of a pharmacist or they have ceased to practise as a medical practitioner. Part 6 of the Bill amends the Hearing Services Act 1991 so that the definition of eligible persons is changed to ensure that hearing services provided by the Commonwealth through Australian Hearing Services are available only to eligible persons who are Australian citizens or Australian permanent residents.

We are forever making the health system better in this country. Last month we heard of measures which will improve the coherence and cohesion of health, aged care and other related services. A total of $6.1m over the next three years will be provided to fund demonstration projects to show how population based planning and funding may lead to improved continuity of care and a fairer sharing of health spending. This initiative will encourage the development of better linkages between area health management, divisions of general practice, and the planning of aged care services in meeting the needs of the local community.

A total of $118.6m has been allocated for hospital capital planning over the next six years. Better planning and management of hospital capital stock will ensure access to hospital services is in step with changes in demographic trends. A total of $17m is being spent in 1992-93 to establish and support a network of divisions of general practice as a framework for the better integration of general practice with the rest of the health system. Integration between health and aged care services will be enhanced by the provision of $7m over the next four years to enable some aged care assessment teams to purchase crucial care services for frail older people coming out of hospital. This will ease their transition into the community and reduce the likelihood of admission to a nursing home or hostel, or an unplanned return to hospital.

The document that was tabled last month by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) is entitled Medicare: So Much Stronger. And it is. This Budget is a giant step forward for the provision of health services in this country, and this Bill is one of the many constant ongoing pieces of fine tuning being carried out by Minister Howe and the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. Medicare has become sacrosanct to the Australian user public. I pity those Opposite. We provide one of the best health systems in the world. Those opposite will provide a new tax which is going to take food out of the mouths of those who can least afford it. Where is the social justice in that?

I was heartened by a recent meeting I attended on the Gold Coast, the annual zone conference of the Gold Coast Pensioners League. Honourable members who know the area know that they could hardly call the Queensland Gold Coast the Labor heartland. It is a part of Queensland that is full of people of retirement age, the majority of whom would have more than likely voted for those opposite in the past. I was asked to address the conference on how the GST would affect the general pensioner and retiree population. One would have thought that, in that part of town, I would have been on a hiding to nothing—but I was wrong.

When I arrived I discovered that I was the only Federal member there. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), who handles that area, was absent. I was later informed that because he had copped such a hiding over the GST at the conference last year he had decided not to come back. This was much to the annoyance of the two local State National Party members present, who made a fist of trying to justify the GST by palming it off onto their absent Federal colleague. But it did not quite wash. In the end, it got too much for one of them. He looked around to make sure there were no Federal spies within earshot and told the audience he could not see how anyone could win government by introducing a new tax. In the end, of course, it is going to be that simple. All the complex arguments will be forgotten. The public will simply remember three things; first, that it is a new tax; secondly, generally people do not believe that they can trust politicians, particularly those opposite; and, perhaps thirdly, better the devil you know. To finish that interesting little story, a Democrat speaker got up and told the audience—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think the honourable gentleman has finished that little story.
—It was a good story, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Order! A debate that is based on something that has nothing to do with the Bill is not.

—Very well, Mr Deputy Speaker. In the Budget Speech we heard about support for carers, which amounts to $89m over the next four years. Generally, I think it can be said without any doubt whatsoever that, when it comes to health, the Government's policies far outweigh and are far better than those of the Opposition. We are not into slashing spending; we are into putting money where it is needed.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I make one final reference to part 7 of the Bill, where a number of minor amendments are made to the National Health Act 1953. The most important of these is the refund provision which is being amended so that as from 1 July 1992 patients who are unable to produce evidence of their entitlement at the time of supply may obtain a refund if they subsequently demonstrate their entitlement to the Health Insurance Commission, without a test of inadvertence. Stricter checking for eligibility for free or concessional benefits will be introduced from that date. I commend the Bill to the House. As I said, this is one of our minor but yet important ongoing reforms to the health system—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is full of rhetoric.
—It is not full of rhetoric. It is the truth. I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum concerning the Government's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last month the Keating Government, via the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), delivered its first and what will almost certainly be its last Budget. Without doubt it was the last throw of the dice for this failed Government for, when the people of Australia saw that the document offered nothing for them except more of the same, they gave it the thumbs down as a non event. The Australian people are now waiting for the next election to be called so they can vote this Government, and especially this Prime Minister (Mr Keating), out of office once and for all.

PARA.TAB: Rarely, if ever, has this country seen such a tragic waste of what is now almost ten years of office. This country was once a vibrant leader amongst the great nations of the world, but after Gough Whitlam introduced the handout mentality, after Bob Hawke went through a period of policies of populist nothingness, and after the present Prime Minister gave us the recession we had to have, Australia has been reduced to an economic wasteland. This Government, via various Prime Ministers, has delivered a million jobless, despite its constant cries of compassion for the poor and its so-called trumpeting of social justice. It has given us record bankruptcies of business, particularly small business. It has blown out the overseas debt from about $23 billion net to $148 billion. One of the tragedies of that is that even after we take over after the next election, overseas debt will continue to increase—such is its momentum due to the structure of the economy at the moment.

This Government has also delivered us with interest rates which have been at record levels for a record length of time. The architect of this appalling situation was indeed the previous Treasurer, the present Prime Minister, the honourable member for Blaxland, one P.J. Keating. If we look at what this man has achieved as opposed to what he tells us, we find that he wins by the length of the straight the gold medal for the worst track record of any member of parliament in Australia's history.

It is almost no exaggeration to say that when it comes to the economy, nearly every prediction the Prime Minister has made has been so wide of the mark as to blow away his credibility forever. This is shown in the comment of an ex-Minister in one of the previous Labor governments, Labor elder statesman, ex-Senator `Diamond' Jim McClelland, who said in a period back close to the Gulf war that Paul Keating:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . is like Saddam Hussein in that every disaster is called a victory. To coin a phrase, he saddamised the community.
That is indeed so. Let us consider the Keating Budget record. After 18 months of Labor being in power, when the then Treasurer delivered his second Budget in 1984, he said:
The Government's policies are on track.
In 1985 he said the Budget:
. . . builds upon our very significant successes and puts further behind us the despair and economic failure of the former Government.
In 1986 he said the Budget:
. . . rings the changes on a more robust, aggressive Australian economy.
In 1987 when delivering the Budget Speech he said:
Our economic strategy is now bearing fruit.
In 1988 he said:
The nation is successfully emerging from the most severe economic crisis in a generation . . . this is the one that brings home the bacon.
In 1989 he said:
Australia will emerge . . . without a recession and with its economic and social structure improving.
In 1990 he said that the economy will improve:
. . . without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.
We all know the truth of those statements. We have had time to judge them and all of them have been wrong.

PARA.TAB: I put it to the House that his record is a disaster. Like all Labor Treasurers, past and present, State or Federal, none of them can handle money when it comes to dealing with the economy. One only needs to look at the record of the last New South Wales Government, the present Western Australian Government, the present Victorian Government, the present South Australian Government, the previous Tasmanian Government and the present Australian Government. All have failed miserably when it comes to handling the economy. The present Prime Minister in so many ways must now be an acute embarrassment to his Party. For almost 10 years he has had his go, and he has failed and failed miserably.

What do we have that is offering for the future? I suggest it will be more of the same, if one studies the last Budget. One only has to look at the Budget Speech of the Treasurer this year. I quote from page 13:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the absence of new measures, revenues are also likely to decline. If the fiscal position nearer to the time is not stronger than is now projected, the Government will consider and implement a number of tax changes to maintain the revenue structure. These changes—referred to in the Budget Statements—would allow for the 1995-96 deficit to be between 1/2 per cent and 1 per cent of gross domestic product.
That is the famous statement made by the present Treasurer where he signals that this Government is going to have to bring in new taxes and possibly increase present taxes.

PARA.TAB: We have had a series of Budget deficits. When one includes last year's deficit with this year's, as well the deficits in subsequent years referred to in that quote, we will have a further blow-out in the Budget in the order of $50 billion. Last year the deficit was $9.3 billion. It is projected to be $13.4 billion this year. Next year it is projected to be $11 1/2 billion. If we are generous and say that the year after it will be $9 billion and the year after that again it will be $7 billion, we have an extra $50 billion to be tacked on.

However, it is not just in economic matters that this Government has gone astray. It is interesting to look back over the past decade at some of the other areas. Do honourable members remember the famous Bill of Rights that this Government tried to bring in and foist upon the Australian people? Fortunately it was rejected at the end because it was so unpopular. Goodness knows how much money was spent in trying to bring in that Bill.

Let us look back at the infamous Australia card which the Government tried to foist upon the Australian population. I dare say it would have brought the Government down if former Senator John Stone and his friend had not found a way to block it in the Senate. In one sense even though that has saved the Australian people from having the Australia card brought in, it probably also saved the Government of the day.

Let us recall the four referendum questions that the previous Attorney-General and Deputy Prime Minister, Lionel Bowen, put to the Australian people. The then Government spent over $40m just holding that referendum and each of those four was rejected by record amounts. I think the vote was something like 80 per cent of Australian people voting No in every case.

There is one other area of great waste that received a little bit of publicity the other day. I refer to the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1987 under which the Government wished to investigate Nazi criminals and prosecute them in Australia. When the Government introduced that Bill, this side of the House pointed out what a ridiculous piece of legislation it was. A short period down the track from the passing of that amendment to the War Crimes Act, according to reports the Government has investigated 834 allegations against people living in Australia who were supposed to have been tied up in war crimes overseas. I believe that three of those 834 cases have prosecutions against them. One relating to a 78-year-old pensioner in Adelaide has been dropped; and there are two other still active prosecutions out there, one against a 75-year-old and the other against a 68-year-old. It is my guess that those cases probably will be dropped. There is one active file on a Melbourne person, but apparently the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) advised the Cabinet the other day that there are only limited prospects for success. So the Government has also dropped that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Think of the cost.

—Exactly. I am told that the cost was in excess of $20m. The Government has investigated 834 people, but it still has only two active prosecutions. It is almost certain that no-one else will be charged. The Government has not yet had one conviction. The whole thing is an absolute farce. It has cost the Australian people $20m—money that could have been better spent on roads, on assisting the drought stricken farmers in my electorate or whatever. That is the sort of thing that the Government has wasted money on.

PARA.TAB: I wish to highlight an area where there is some waste that the coalition's Waste Watch Committee—of which I am a member—brought to the attention of the Australian people only the other day. This is an instance where $188,000 is to be spent on bisexual men to conduct a needs assessment of female partners and to implement the recommendations. Has anyone ever heard of a more farcical grant? The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) chuckles as I read this out. It would be funny if it were not so serious.

Also in the Budget an amount of $54,000 was allocated to transsexuals for a project commissioned by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services to conduct a needs analysis of this group in Australia. A sum of $129,000 is given to sexually active women to develop a strategy in conjunction with the Social Biology Resources Centre to improve their negotiating skills, for heaven's sake. A sum of $84,920 is given to the Prostitutes Collective of Victoria to enable it to develop sex information for sex workers with a non-English speaking background. That is the sort of thing that this Government is spending money on in this country. When the Australian people hear this, I think they will be appalled.

But the daddy of them all, the most remarkable story of all, relates to the local government grants, handouts, that were announced in the recent Budget. This Government decided to spend $345m of totally unfunded money—it is always very easy to spend somebody else's money, I might add—

TALK.START.PARA: —How much did the Prime Minister's electorate get?

—I will come to that in a minute. The Government is going to spend $345m—not one cent of it funded. It is going to splash it around Australia to create so-called jobs. Blunder No. 1 was that it gave it to some councils and not to others. So, rather than getting pats on the back, as it expected, from all the councils around Australia, all it has done is to get the backs up of the councils that did not receive any money. One has only to look at my electorate, my new electorate from the next election, which will take in 40 per cent of New South Wales. It is probably the most impoverished part of Australia at present, experiencing in many areas the worst drought in the country's history. Seven shires got some money—Wellington, Bogan, Coonamble, Bourke, Brewarrina, Central Darling and Broken Hill. Broken Hill got $700,000; those others got less than half a million dollars between them, which is less than one seven-hundredth of the money doled out. But right beside those shires are shires such as Forbes, Parkes, Dubbo, Narromine, Warren, Gilgandra, Cobar and Lachlan that did not get a cent.

PARA.TAB: I put it to honourable members: if one is an unemployed person—this is what this money is supposed to be spent on—in Forbes, one is just as unemployed as a person who lives in the shire next door of Cowra, which got $350,000 to spend in this area. If one is unemployed in Parkes, one is just as unemployed as a person next door in Wellington.

TALK.START.PARA: —Discrimination.

—It is discrimination. It is based most inequitably. It should have been done on a pro rata basis, on a sliding scale. All Labor has done is to walk away from those regions. It is absolutely farcical. The Cobar area is absolutely ravaged by the drought, with high unemployment and no prospects for the future while we have these clear skies. Stock are dying; the numbers are down to 10 per cent of what they were on some properties. Yet that area did not get a cent. To me that is absolutely incomprehensible.

PARA.TAB: In response to a previous interjection, at the same time the Minister for Local Government (Mr Simmons) announced that the electorate of Blaxland got $20m. He had to revise that later down to a figure of about $3m. But, while my electorate in total—40 per cent of New South Wales—got barely more than $1m, and $700,000 of that spent in Broken Hill, the electorate of Blaxland, a dot on the map in New South Wales if you like, got $3m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Blot or a dot.

—Well, a blot with the present member, no doubt. The Lismore region, which takes in two marginal Labor electorates which Labor will almost certainly lose at the next election, got $7m to spend. I highlight to the Government the injustice of this all or nothing approach.

PARA.TAB: Let us go further and look at what is actually proposed to come out of this spending of $345m. I turn to the employment paper which is the last of the Budget Papers. The very last paragraph of the last page reveals all. It states that the Government hopes to create 13,000 jobs right across Australia over a two-year period. So there we have it: only 13,000 jobs created—and, what is more, temporary jobs. If we cost that out, it works out at $26,538 per job. As most of those jobs will last no longer than three months, on an annualised basis we are looking at a cost to the taxpayer of $100,000 per job. So all we will do ultimately when we finally fund these jobs is to tax business and put marginal jobs, real jobs, out in order to create government jobs—painting rocks white, so to speak.
