All the Government is doing is putting taxes up in the long run to destroy more real jobs than it is creating in the short term. All it is doing is creating artificial government jobs to hide the unemployment problem out past the next election—a cynical exercise if ever I saw one. Nothing shows more how bereft is this Government in its capacity to solve the problem that it has created than does this RED scheme revisited.

In the brief time remaining, I would like to address my comments to the car industry because it has come in for debate in recent days. The Government is trumpeting that it is going to leave the tariff at 15 per cent later in this decade and that somehow this will save the industry whereas the coalition will reduce the tariff to 5 per cent. Somehow 15 per cent will save the industry and 5 per cent will be a disaster. What the Government, in running this illogical line, is overlooking is that the coalition will remove payroll tax, which works out at a reduction in cost of about $350 to $400 a car. We will remove wholesale sales tax, and we will remove fuel excise of at least 19c, if not 26c a litre in business cases. But we will not just remove those things; we will front end load them because we will put those benefits up front from 1 October 1994 for six years before we get down to that negligible level of 5 per cent.

On top of that, because we will lower tariffs to 5 per cent, all cars will be $1,000 cheaper to the customers of Australia than they would be under the Government's policy. So what this Government is in effect saying is that it is for more expensive cars; that is what it is saying. In what I have said so far, I have not even allowed for the industrial relations changes which are desperately needed in the car industry to drag it kicking and screaming into the twenty-first century.

I would like honourable members to contemplate for a moment the car industry itself. There are 335,000 people employed in the car industry. Of those, 66,000 are employed in the assembly and parts industries and 269,000 in the rest of the car industry, servicing all of those cars, selling petrol, selling cars or maintaining them on the road. That is a ratio of four in the service industries to every one in the assembly industry. If we can make those cars cheaper by $1,000 a car, as the Government acknowledges, and if we can make the customers who buy those cars wealthier by giving them such things as $95 per week in tax cuts—as the miners in my electorate of Broken Hill will be getting—we will sell more cars. What will happen if we sell more cars? That ratio of 4 : 1 will come into play and we will need more people employed in the service industries, and I believe more people employed in the assembly industry also. That has not even taken into account the fact that businesses will be able to buy their cars 15 per cent cheaper on top of that because they will get a refund of the GST.

So our policy is for more jobs in the car industry overall. It is a good bet that there will be more jobs in the assembly industry as well as more jobs all over Australia—we believe two million more jobs by the end of the century. The policy we have now makes cars $4,000 dearer, on today's figures, and that is a drain of $1,600m on the 400,000 cars we sell each year. That works out at $25,000 per job, which is exactly the amount of money that the average worker in the car assembly industry is earning today. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Budget builds upon One Nation and the youth package to give a moderate fiscal stimulus to the Australian economy to the extent of about $4.2 billion. The deficit is projected at $13.4m, about 3.3 per cent of GDP. Outlays are estimated at 27 per cent of GDP, which compares very favourably with the 30 per cent of GDP of the Budget of 1984-85. In those circumstances it is entirely responsible, given the domestic and overseas recession, to run a deficit of this nature. The key economic forecasts in the Budget are, of course, a demand estimated at 2.75 per cent, business investment at minus 2 per cent, plant and equipment at 3.75 per cent, employment at one per cent, unemployment to average 10.5 per cent, GDP at 3 per cent, inflation at 2 per cent and the current account deficit at 3.75 per cent of GDP.

PARA.TAB: I still think that if there is any risk in this Budget it is on the down side rather than the up side; that is, poor investment performance, low growth and intractable unemployment figures are a greater risk than a blow-out in imports or a surge in the current account deficit. However, one trusts that these Budget projections are more reliable than has been the case in recent years.

It must be said at this point how unfortunate the Government has been on two fronts. Firstly, there has been an apparent total inability of Treasury—and, I must say, of Government advisers and perhaps of some senior Ministers too—to produce reasonably accurate forecasts, particularly in 1991 and 1991-92, and in the One Nation document, on which fiscal and monetary policy could be based.

The forecast for gross domestic product in the 1991 Budget was 2 per cent. Of course, we actually had minus 0.8 per cent. In 1991-92 we saw a projection of 1.5 per cent and we had average growth of 0.4 per cent. These are all average growth figures. One Nation projected a 4 3/4 per cent growth for 1992-93, and this Budget projects 3 per cent.

When a breakdown in projections occurs, such as occurred in those two Budgets and in the One Nation statement, virtually every other major forecast goes out the window. For instance, the deficit can explode, investment can be lower than projected and unemployment will be higher. Above all, hope and confidence in the community, especially in business and industry, can fade.

Inaccurate forecasting can be politically dangerous and can lead to precious opportunities being lost. For example, as a result of inaccurate forecasting, real interest rates were kept too high for too long in 1989-90 and, I think, in the calendar year 1991. As a result of inaccurate forecasting, we saw delayed opportunities for fiscal expansion and improvements to investment incentives in 1990 and 1991. These matters were, to an extent, rectified in the One Nation statement and in this Budget.

The inaccurate 4 3/4 per cent projection of the One Nation statement led to the problem of how to achieve a surplus by 1995-96 and extend personal tax cuts amounting to $8.6 billion over two years to 1995-96 at the same time, since all this depended on 4 per cent plus growth over three years; and that was a problem.

Last February-March I wrote that the Labor Government was in danger of economic derailment from this puzzling failure to advance credible economic forecasts and that 4 3/4 per cent growth in 1992-93 would not be met. In truth, most street-smart economists and politicians should have known this at the time, given the flat domestic economy and the international situation in the United States, Japan and Europe. I conclude that there must be a major shake-up and revamp of economic forecasting branches and units in the Treasury. There is no question about it: that is what is required.

The second area of ill fortune suffered by this Labor Government has been the continuing overseas recession, excessively high German interest rates and the inability of the OECD and the IMF to get their projections right. For example, recently the IMF forecast average GDP for the United States of 2.1 per cent in 1992 and 3.4 per cent in 1993, and for Japan of 1.9 per cent and 3.5 per cent in 1992 and 1993 respectively, and the same for Germany. However, I do not believe there is much optimism anywhere in the world, so I doubt that these IMF forecasts will be achieved. Today I read this in Westpac Market Insights:

SPEECH.PARA: No country can point to strong consumer spending at this time.

Recently I travelled through the US and Germany. I had some talks with the US Federal Reserve, the Treasury of the United States and some commercial banks, and, of course, with the Bundesbank officials in Germany. All of them said that this is a time of consolidation and not a time of growth. Rather than project 1.9 per cent and 3.5 per cent growth for 1992-93, Bundesbank officials were projecting to me 1 1/2 per cent for 1992 and probably just in excess of 2 per cent for calendar year 1993.

PARA.TAB: The US banks, similarly, were predicting 2 per cent growth for 1992 and probably not in excess of 2 1/2 per cent growth for 1993. These are the latest trends. President Bush knows it too well, and that is why he is bribing US farmers and talking about tax cuts early next year if he wins, which I think is a highly doubtful proposition at this stage. He is offering tax cuts despite the horrendous US Budget deficits.

Thankfully, Japan is stimulating its economy with a $A125 billion fiscal package. As the Bank of Japan reports in the Australian Financial Review today, Japan is apparently looking at the worst recession since the 1970s. At any rate, even if those figures are achieved, I believe that Australian unemployment at 11 per cent, and 10 1/2 per cent average, for this financial year cannot be tolerated. In those circumstances, $4.3 billion is a moderate fiscal response.

I believe that job losses are quite serious. Industry restructuring, plus the recession, has caused the job losses in this country. The recession was caused by high interest rates through 1989 and compounded by the overseas situation that I have just been talking about. Necessary restructuring in the steel industry cost 14,000 jobs during the 1980s in Port Kembla alone. The private sector has lost 385,000 jobs in two years, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, and manufacturing was down 75,000 jobs in one year.

Last week, figures showed that full time jobs in August went down by 30,000. Many regions, such as Wollongong and south-western Sydney, are looking at 15 per cent-plus unemployment. My point is that, even if the Budget estimates on unemployment are correct, employment has reached totally unacceptable levels for the labour movement in this country. Something more will have to be done about it, in my view. Measures to encourage exports and to establish new value added industries to increase growth and create jobs will be required.

I do not want to give the impression that all is gloom on the economic horizon; not at all. Many policy pluses are in place. They are the building blocks of the future. Inflation is down to 2 per cent, and the Australian dollar, at last, is fluctuating between US71c and US72c and has gone down on the TWI. That is very helpful to export industries and import competing industries. We have a stimulatory fiscal policy in place, we are increasing spending on infrastructure, and on top of that we have in place an accelerated depreciation allowance and a 10 per cent investment allowance.

Housing starts are up, as they ought to be, as housing rates have come down by 8 per cent over the last couple of years. They were up 9 per cent in June. We have a credible wages policy in place, involving enterprise agreements, the maintenance of the Industrial Relations Commission and an equitable minimum award system to provide wages at a fair level to youth and low income earners. I note in passing that this coalition Opposition would terminate the IRC and terminate awards, and intends to pay the youth of this country the slave wage of $3 per hour.

We have a major education expansion in place, including big increases in spending, in labour market programs and in vocational training. As I have said, these are the building blocks of the future. Above all, the other great plus for this Government, while I am listing the pluses, is that it does not intend to introduce a goods and services tax of 15 per cent on jobs—that is, on value added industries.

Regarding the fall in the Australian dollar, I think that is good for industry. I do not think it will be inflationary, at least not very much, and I do not think it will fall further. There must be no increase in official interest rates. I think that people, particularly in the media, should drop talk of the possibility of having to increase interest rates again, because I believe that will not happen, nor should it happen.

Also probably on balance there ought not to be any early further additional cuts in official interest rates. The reason why the Australian dollar has fallen is not because of the Budget deficit, but because of international differentials in short term real interest rates. For instance, in the United States that differential is less than one per cent; in Germany it is 6.4 per cent; and in Australia it is somewhere in between those figures at 4 per cent. Germany, of course, has resorted to high interest rates in order to curb inflation resulting from reunification costs. Also, Bundesbank officials told me that they had resorted to high interest rates in order to curb future expectation in wages growth.

I believe that pressure will come off German interest rates over the next two or three months. I confidently predict that, because that is the sort of message that came through to me in Germany recently. I think it will happen before Christmas at any rate. I think that the reason for the coming reduction in German rates is that it finally has its inflation under control. The Bundesbank is now satisfied with wages growth expectations for 1993.

Germany has a worsening economy by the month, in tandem with a large budget deficit, so there is no scope for loosening fiscal policy in Germany. If it wants to get its economy moving, it really has to be on the monetary policy interest rate front. It is also suffering increasing pressure from other EC nations which feel that they are being held hostage through German monetary policy and high interest rates, and also a very strong deutschmark in comparison to the UK pound and the US dollar.

I repeat that there is no reason for the Reserve Bank to be even thinking of increasing official interest rates in the near future. That would be a disaster for a sluggish economy and declining investment. I note, again in passing, that the Opposition would lift inflation and interest rates in this country by the introduction of a goods and services tax. But we have not done too well on investment either. I have to say that and it is evident in the Budget Papers. In fact, I would go so far as to say that in an otherwise moderately satisfactory Budget, investment is the black hole.

The Bureau of Industry Economics states in its latest report that manufacturing investment in the calendar year 1991 went down by 11.7 per cent. There is an upside in manufacturing. Exports, particularly elaborately transformed manufactured exports, are 34 per cent and 14 per cent respectively of our exports, and $1.3 billion of that is in motor vehicles. That is a terrific performance.

The downside is that in manufacturing we have lost over 130,000 jobs since September 1989, and TCF is set to lose 50,000 jobs by 1995. Restructuring is necessary, but it is also necessary to establish alternative jobs and new industries. It is true, in my belief, that although we have general investment incentives of an improved nature now in place as a result of One Nation, further specific measures are now required to assist specific new industries. I think the first one is to extend export facilitation to all elaborately transformed manufactured exports; and the second is to extend specific assistance to specified new industries via the tax system.

In Australia, as in the United States, the lowest interest rate since the 1960s has not generated increased investment in new industries. This is a legacy of the wasteful 1980s when corporate debt surged to the highest levels this century. The people I spoke to in the US Treasury and in the Federal Reserve agree with me on that point.

Now, in 1992, business and industry are repairing their balance sheets. They are refinancing at lower interest rates and restructuring their existing operations. They are not yet in an expansionary or investment mode. Banks are very cautious; their margins are outrageously high and jobs are still being lost. This process has still some time to run, but capital reformation is under way. It is not so much a matter of a shortage of world capital, in my view, but as to when borrowing and investment will commence again—and, when it does, which nations will attract this investment.

Therefore, Australia needs additional specific incentives on top of the One Nation initiatives. I think they should be of a non-tariff, non-bounty assistance nature—for example, tax holidays for new industries, as has been offered in the past by the tiger economies of South East Asia, and lower corporate tax rates for a fixed period after cash flow commences for agreed new industries.

If we are to gain and expand industries such as wool and cotton processing—I certainly am very pleased at the initiative that was taken by Senator Button to help in the establishment of the new wool processing plant in Geelong by the German firm based at Bremen, whose factory I visited recently—food processing, aerospace industries, information and communications, technology and products and maybe even electronic goods, further incentives will be necessary as nations fight for advantage in investment over the next several years as reinvestment occurs throughout the world.

In closing, I am sorry that I cannot really be more optimistic, but I believe that when we are in public office and are in the Parliament of Australia, we really should speak our minds and call the shots as they are and as we see them. I do not think that any economy, with the exception of Japan, can balance the ever more complex technologies of production with employment growth sufficient to provide full, or even near full, employment in future.

But one thing is absolutely certain. This Labor Government with its policies on social justice, on education and vocational training, on its consensus on industrial relations—which has the support of business, industry and unions—its more moderate and sensible position on tariffs, and its refusal to countenance consumption taxes, is infinitely preferable to a coalition government. Such a government would ignite an industrial relations bonfire that would wreck the motor vehicle industry with zero to 5 per cent tariff levels, and destroy some 114,000 jobs and $1.4 billion of new investment. This Government is preferable to a coalition government which would reignite inflation with a $27 billion to $30 billion goods and services tax. Such zealots and inflexible ideologues can never and will never govern this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a fascinating valedictory speech from the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West).
—He will be here a while yet.

—Judging by the number of his colleagues attending, I am not sure whether that is the case. I say to him, as he leaves the chamber, that after 10 years in office, and part of that period as a Minister, it must be a really sad occasion for him to look back on 10 years of failure. It must be sad for him to reflect on the fact that with all the drive and enthusiasm and ideas of an incoming Hawke Government, the Labor Party has failed Australia.

PARA.TAB: The country is in the worst recession that it has had for 60 years. There are a million people unemployed. Jobs are being lost and there are record bankruptcies. People are hurting in every electorate in every part of Australia—whether it be in manufacturing industries; whether those people be on the land or in service industries; whether they be mothers at home trying to manage the family budget; or whether they be school leavers in their final year of school, thinking about what career path they should choose and whether they will get a job.

The whole nation has been set back by the policies of this current Government. As the honourable member said, Australia wants and needs a manufacturing industry. What is being offered by the coalition is an opportunity to seize a new chance to have a dynamic and flexible manufacturing industry.

I guess that for many years I too felt that Australia needed protection from the predatory practices of our competitors. The only reason we needed that protection was, basically, that our workplace relations were not part of the process of assessing how much it cost to produce in Australia. Too often for the sake of greed or self-interest union leaders have put the proposition to workers that they needed more protection and more assistance. What this did over time was build in internal costs in Australia to such a high level that it has been impossible for us to compete, except in a few basic industries where we have huge quantities of raw materials requiring further processing.

What has been the result of these policies, for a time held in abeyance by the Fraser Government, but then given a head of steam by the Hawke Government? Australia is now in a difficult situation; almost a shambles, one would say. What is the way through? The way through is to believe in the inventiveness, drive, spirit and education of the Australian people. We can win. We can come through this, but not by fiddling on the margins.

The honourable member for Cunningham expressed his disappointment with so many of the Government's policies: its failure to deliver what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) said they would deliver. These failures in policies are brought about because there is not a will to look at the important issues and to deal with them. I do not consider that Australia should become Asian, but it is easy to learn some of the lessons from our neighbours. I draw the attention of the House to a summary article by Heather Smith in Commercial Issues entitled `Picking winners in East Asia—not all it's cracked up to be'. It is a very interesting summary and detailed analysis of the policies of our Asian neighbours and why they have succeeded, and why some have succeeded better than others. She compares the manufacturing industries of all of Asia, but particularly Korea and Taiwan as the ones which have succeeded the best. She comes to this conclusion in a summary piece at the end of her article, entitled `Lessons from the East Asian experience':

This episode supports the view that East Asian growth relies more on macroeconomic factors than a sectoral approach to industrial development. While some targeted industries have grown to become internationally competitive, others have not. Moreover many industries not targeted by Government have flourished and become highly competitive.
Economic success has tended to be greater when the role of Government has been an indirect one. To this end a number of policy lessons become relevant.

SPEECH.PARA: The summary of the practices adopted in Asia, as analysed by Heather Smith, drawing together the work of a number of economists, is that macroeconomic policies are the ones that can best allow a nation to flourish, rather than a policy of trying to pick winners. I think that all Australians know that our pastoral and agricultural industries are internationally competitive and have been great winners for us in terms of paying our way overseas. I think most Australians know that our mining industries are internationally competitive and that they have helped to pay the bills also.

PARA.TAB: However, we are less sure when it comes to things such as our transport industries and some of our manufacturing industries. I guess that if one consults the participants in those industries one becomes aware that they too are concerned about how well they can manage and how well they have done in the past. In an analysis presented to the Industry Commission inquiry into the automotive industry, the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries outlined what it felt the Government was doing to restrict it. On page 29, right at the beginning of this report, the organisation states that government needs to get out of the way to allow it to do things in a certain number of areas. It says that we do not need to have the wages or the living standards of Asia but we need the Government to remove some things, thus allowing us to become competitive and able to hold up our heads in the international region.

Frankly, these are not issues that are world shattering in their own right, but they are issues that need to be dealt with by a government determined to lead the nation. This Government has lost the wish to lead the nation. The FCAI listed the following cost burdens:

SPEECH.PARA: a continuing high inflation rate;
excessive interest rates;
disproportionate taxes on motor vehicles;
the overall tax structure, which discriminates against manufacturing and investment;
centralised wage determination;
an adversarial and institutionalised disputes settling mechanism;
high labour related on-costs, such as workers' compensation, accident insurance, payroll tax, compulsory superannuation, leave loadings and so on;
uncertainty from frequent changes in motor industry `plans';
the regulatory environment;
inefficient rail and sea transport systems; and
delays at wharves caused by labour disputes.

Those are the main points that Australian manufacturers want to see a government address, and they are the main points which this Government has not addressed. Therefore, rather than having a scorched earth policy, which the Government proclaims is being enunciated by the coalition, it has chosen to fiddle at the margin and say, `Ultimately, in the year 3000—somewhere down the track—we will achieve this goal'. However, there is no mechanism for achieving those goals. That is why we have employment creating programs, education programs, superannuation increases and statements in the Budget and One Nation, some of which have been partially followed but most not.

PARA.TAB: The Government has lost its determination and direction to deliver for Australia what Australians themselves say they want. So we have a manufacturing industry beset by many problems. We have the worst recession for 60 years. People are not buying stuff; Aussies cannot afford to buy stuff. Their standard of living is too low to allow them to buy the sorts of products they want to buy. On top of that, the Government has instigated a regime of massive interest rates so that people wanting to expand or buy things as the ingredients of a manufacturing process have had to pay exorbitant interest rates. People were not prepared to make new investment or buy new equipment and machinery. There is no new activity; it is all low activity. The automobile industry is trying to develop new models to stay competitive in the process. The Ford company itself has lost market share. The quality of its vehicles and industrial disputes have marked it as having great difficulties in management.

Where can Australian manufacturers go if governments ignore what they want? These are the problem areas: inflation, interest rates, taxes on motor vehicles, centralised wage determination, poor dispute settling practices, high labour oncosts—which just kick up the cost of labour for the employer but from which the employer and the employee gain little advantage—and inefficient rail and sea transport. The Australian automotive industry has selected four major areas that it thinks the Government should deal with. First, it has asked for the level of taxation to be reduced so that there are incentives for effort in the community. Secondly, it has asked that the tax mix which disadvantages manufactured goods—which are subject to a wholesale sales tax and represent some 70 per cent of the GDP—relative to services be more equitable and the same as the tax that the rest of the country pays. Thirdly, it wants the sales tax that motor vehicles attract to be reduced. Fourthly, it wants taxes on fuel to be dealt with. It says, rightly so, that taxes on fuel are effectively taxes on motor vehicles.

The automobile industry and our manufacturers have been asking for a new package and attention from the Government for two years. The Government has not delivered. The Prime Minister has resolved this situation by retreating more into the past instead of seizing the present and looking to the future. In a comparison of international attractiveness of Australia's position relative to selected automotive producers, 10 factors were considered. We score really badly in a number of areas compared with most nations. We score badly for our innovative forward orientation. We are not prepared to drive into the future to take advantage of our comparative advantages. Our outward orientation, our besetting of the mixes of policies, is also poor and we score below Germany, Japan, Taiwan, the United Kingdom, Canada, the USA and Korea. We are just in front of Malaysia, Brazil and Mexico. That is where Australia stands internationally.

Based on the dynamic attitudes expressed by government, we score below Taiwan, Japan, Germany, Korea, the USA, the UK and Canada. Malaysia is above us, and we are just ahead of Brazil and Mexico. In relation to industrial efficiency, Japan, Taiwan, Korea, the USA, Canada, Malaysia and Germany are ahead of us and the UK, Brazil and Mexico are level with us.

We have a long way to go, internationally. While it is recognised that we have a long way to go, the Government fiddles with Budgets at the margin and then criticises the Opposition for producing a plan that meets the needs of Australian manufacturers and the Australian people by reducing taxation, dealing with wholesale sales tax and looking at fuel excise and a whole raft of other measures that are designed to give Australia a boost of $20 billion from cuts in taxes; another $10 billion from reform of our infrastructure, our wharves, shipping and the rest of our transportation system; and a further $20 billion from the industrial reforms that we need to make. A total of $50 billion is going into the Australian economy to give Australia a boost—to give Australians a fair go, give average Aussies a chance and make them feel proud again that we are worth while. The Government is not going to do that and it has clearly drawn the lines for the next election: it is not interested in the future; it is interested only in retaining office.

The issue has come down to whether or not there should be protection for Australian industry. There should be protection for Australian industry and that basically comes from having anti-dumping and other procedures to stop the international cheats. We ought to be able to get in there, clout them and stop them playing games with us. It is not a matter of building walls that they need to jump over for the cost of their goods; it is a matter of stopping them abusing Australia. There is the classic instance of apricots being purchased in Turkey. Somehow or other those apricots were allowed into Australia and were not able to be sold here because the quality was so low. But when the importer wanted to export them again, he had a problem on his hands. He wanted to get them out of country, but he was not allowed to export them because the quality was so low. They were of good enough quality for Aussies to eat, but too poor for us to export. So those are the crazy things that we are doing in this country.

The Government has fooled around with its anti-dumping and countervailing measures, but it has done nothing. It is still a protracted legal process. We need to get smart. If we are going to move up with the pace that the rest of the world is setting, we need to be as smart as it is. We need to be smart by instigating anti-dumping and countervailing duty processes which will advantage Australia—not to protect us, but to stop the international cheats.

As far as the tariff debate is concerned, it is wonderful how the Prime Minister says that a tariff level of 15 per cent is such a massive difference from 5 per cent, when there was a drop in protection in the auto industry in 1988, just four years ago, from 243 per cent to an effective 113 per cent—which is half the protection. That is the sophistry of the Prime Minister. He dissembles here day after day, using language that this House should not have to listen to.

Last year on the John Laws show the Prime Minister said that at the end of the tariff phase-in, which is in 1997 and 2000, he will have removed tariffs altogether. Those are his real views, and now he is trying to argue that the 10 per cent difference between the Opposition and the Government is a significant difference at the end of the day. Of course, it is not. The real things that will make a difference to Australia are those things that the automobile industry has identified: providing incentive, relieving Australians of taxation, giving people an opportunity to take a second job or work overtime without penalty, and allowing Australians to buy cheaper goods because those goods that we make ourselves will be made more efficiently.

One only has to look at the situation just across the water, in New Zealand. Its economy was really bad news. It was in an extremely bad way, but it is starting to recover. It has settled its wages problems in a wonderful way—92 per cent of people are getting the same or more. Yet I know that there are people on the other side of the House who will continue to be hypocritical about this process and say that wages will be cut. That is not true. The facts do not prove that in any way whatsoever. We can do better if we have the shackles taken off.

The Government has to stop its hypocrisy, stop talking about whether 15 per cent is as bad as 5 per cent and deal with the macro-economic things. If it is prepared to look at the big picture, Australians will be able to buy motor cars a lot cheaper than they can today—$4,000 a vehicle cheaper. They will have incentives to invest in their own country, and young couples will be able to build homes because the disincentive that exists now will be removed.

So the Government's bad news Budget does not rate a mention. People out there do not know about it and do not want to know about it. They just want to move ahead, but they want the certainty to move ahead. I call on the Government to join the Opposition in promoting some of these policies. Let us go ahead together and really work for the Australian people, because they have said what they want—all we have to do is deliver it. We are prepared to deliver it; the Government is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the past two Budget debates I have devoted my contributions to criticisms of the policies of economic rationalism that have broken the hearts of Labor's rank and file, obsessed the minds of the Liberal Party and totally enthralled Australia's bureaucracy over the past decade. Nothing I have seen in the past 12 months has moderated my contempt for the neo-classical economics and those who peddle its immoral, unprincipled philosophies.

PARA.TAB: However, there can be no doubt that Australians are beginning to reject these marketeers and turn their faces towards policies more conducive to social harmony and economic stability. This Budget may well be seen by historians as the turning point, when Australian politicians buried the fallacious argument that all we had to do was free up the market and permit business to pursue its own self-interests whereupon our economy would boom and prosperity would be showered upon all who were prepared to work for it.

It is appropriate that, as we approach the twentieth anniversary of the sacking of the Whitlam Government, we should contrast the policy directions of that era with those of the past decade. I emphasise that I am not talking about the economic settings of the Whitlam Budgets, which most commentators would agree involved imprudent spending. However, just because it can be said in retrospect that Gough and his Ministers tried to do too much too soon, it does not follow, as the rationalists would have us believe, that Whitlam's social policies were wrong.

In the early 1970s, government economic policy was dominated by a value system based on a humane and compassionate society giving encouragement and support to all Australians to play a full role in our community. It was characterised by respect of human rights and dignity, promotion of social justice for the disadvantaged and the development of a society accepting all classes, cultures and creeds. Those values were enshrined per medium of traditional Labor economic policies which were rooted in the Keynesian economic position that the market, left to itself, would not produce a full employment level of output and that meant that governments had to intervene to manage demand and stabilise fluctuations in the level of economic activity. Such policies incorporated the belief that Australia's unique history and geography made it imperative that the public sector play a special role in our economy.

True it was that these early Keynesian policies tended to be somewhat naive, but they were capable of adaptation and much greater sophistication. They did not deserve to be dumped for a neo-classical philosophy which presented as new scientific economic thinking, but which really represented a throw back to the discredited and failed policies of the past.

However, the sad truth is that politics, like economics, is a cyclical business and in the wave of political reaction that saw Labor leaders like Whitlam, Dunstan and Wran depart the political stage we were thrown into an era of government by chartered accountant, where greed was god and the public sector activity had to be sacrificed at its altar. The new credo was the maximisation of the scope of corporate and individual activity and the sacred icon of the new economic religion was the market mechanism. The neo-classical theory was dubbed `rationalism' because its gurus constantly asserted that it was based on scientific empiricism. The implied corollary to the title was that its opponents were irrational—and they were often sneered at as the `looney Left' or `voodoo economists'.

However, what the rationalists were about was no different from their discredited laissez faire primogenitors. They saw society purely as a marketplace and sought to separate economic science from the culture in which it operated. They told us that the only choice for Australians was between a command or centrally planned economy or an absolutely free market system. They entertained no debate about middle ground models which would allow governments to create equitable, just societies by intervening to ensure competitive markets operated in a socially acceptable way. When faced with the inevitable cyclical boom-bust nature of free market economics they simply shrugged and told us that life was not meant to be easy and that recurring market failure is the cost that we have to pay to maintain individual freedom.

I have always had a healthy disregard for zealots and believe Australian society should reject those who preach that greed is good and that the law of the jungle is the proper order of things. I have no less disregard for the nonsense the rationalists spout about even playing fields and the infallibility of the market mechanism.

In the real world speculation constantly dominates enterprise, economic power is never evenly spread and complex cumulative processes control prices. Despite the rationalists' rejection of concepts such as morality, social values such as integrity, initiative, freedom and thrift play a major role in market outcomes. For example, the criminality of the likes of Bond, Skase, Connell and the business irresponsibility of the Australian banks greatly impacted on the confidence of the Australian markets and attitudes of our trading partners. Australians are still paying a very heavy price for the antics of those corporate cowboys.

Real economies are nothing like the computer models of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). They are not simply the sum of their parts or susceptible to simplistic arithmetical modelling—often sectors have discrete lives of their own. The complexity of their interaction and the immense potential for major error makes a joke of those who claim to be able to make economic policy on a scientific basis. Such people are about as reliable as long-range weather forecasters. Allowing the market free rein will produce times of great prosperity, but it will also guarantee regular recessions and occasional depressions. The lives of the rich will be enhanced by such a system but great suffering and impoverishment will be periodically visited upon the majority of Australians.

The rationalists also gloss over or choose to ignore other fatal flaws in their models. For example, the environmental movement is constantly pointing out that the most profitable industrial processes invariably produce the most pollution. The builders of the atomic reactors at Chernobyl and Three Mile Island thought that they were producing cheap energy, but the ultimate cost to their communities was immense. One of the first rationalist economies was Brazil. It grew rapidly, but the cost was international environmental disaster, as natural resources, including the Amazon forests, were raped, affecting us all. Unsustainable development fits nicely within economic rationalist thinking, which puts individuals before the community, even if it leads to social disaster. Little is said by the rationalists about the increasing international mobility of capital. Capital today tends to move around the world to where the cheap labour is. To a much lesser extent labour will move around a nation to where the capital is.

This dual mobility results in powerful pressures to reduce wages. Australian workers are now being told by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and his Leader that they will have to lower their wages or the jobs will move offshore. They are also being told that if we are to compete with cheap Asian labour we will also have to cut or abandon long held conditions, such as social security, unemployment benefits, workers compensation, superannuation and health and environmental protection. We should be very wary of the uncontrolled logic of these arguments.

In the past 30 years the Third World has continued to get poorer. Becoming increasingly desperate to survive, Third World countries will accept lower and lower incomes and conditions. Eventually a free flow of capital to Third World countries would equalise wages, but at very low levels and with catastrophic results for the standards of living in countries such as Australia. Already the emergence of a vast underclass can be seen in developed nations. The recent Los Angeles riots bring the implications of this pattern home to Australians. The last decade has seen Australia follow the American and British trend to increasing inequality of incomes.

What is the point of having highly efficient markets if their effect on society is to produce great wealth for a shrinking minority and increasing misery for everyone else? We would all like to pay less taxes, but with the exception of the Leader of the Opposition and his fellow members of the Gordon Gekko society, most Australians also want to maintain high standards in education, transport, communications, health services, defence, policing and environment protection. Those standards cannot be achieved in the feudal jungle the rationalists would make Australia.

Like it or not, society is an interdependent phenomenon—we have to work together if there is to be a common good. To ensure social harmony and economic stability we have to provide safety nets for the poor, the disadvantaged and the underprivileged. Having an equitable, socially just society does not mean we lack freedom, any more than laws against murder restrict individuals rights of self-expression, nor does it mean that our economy should not be productive or efficient.

How dare the rationalists describe the primitive lifestyle they wish to create as free. The American trends are proof enough of the great lie behind those arguments. There they are developing a form of new feudalism where the privileged are retreating behind high walls guarded by ever increasing numbers of private police and sophisticated security systems. Larger and larger proportions of their wealth are being used to protect themselves from the poverty stricken hordes who, being without jobs, social security or an adequate health scheme, burn, rape and pillage like the barbarians of old. Sooner rather than later such underclasses are going to become so numerous that they represent a real threat to the stability of democratic societies. Unstable nations' economies will never be productive or efficient.

I acknowledge that the economic problems facing Australia and the world are horrendous. However, they will not be successfully resolved by adopting the amoral pseudo-scientific stance of the rationalists. We must face up to the real questions of ethics, of social morality, which affect us all, no matter what our religious or philosophical commitments are.

Until recently, I believed that, despite our obvious party political differences, we shared a vision for the betterment of Australian society. I had a lot of political differences with Malcolm Fraser and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), but I would never deny that they had a personal commitment to a society which was humane.

Regrettably, I cannot say that about the current leadership of the conservative forces in this Parliament. They are the true radicals—radicals of the Right—who would happily visit social chaos upon us all in their fanatical commitment to the view that market forces will solve everything. There is no starker example of the yawning ideological gap between the major parties at the moment than the issue of industrial relations and employment.

The Fightback plan presents a policy based on the Liberals' perceived need to substantially lower unit labour costs. A 30 per cent reduction in the unit cost of labour is the Opposition's objective, and it has talked about a wide range of plans to reduce wages and conditions. However, the Liberals have reneged on their promise to produce a draft Bill outlining their industrial relations policy. All we have to rely on is a series of sometimes contradictory statements made by their Leader and the honourable member for Bennelong.

Initially, they proposed to scrap our conciliation and arbitration system of awards and replace it with a deregulated, market driven system based on direct negotiation between employers and employees. However, they are committed to imposing a minimum wage, of a yet undetermined amount, which will be more than the dole and less than existing awards.

Unions will be excluded from the negotiations, and strikers will be made to personally pay for any economic loss the employer sustains. That did not go down too well with many employers and traditional supporters of the Liberal Party, particularly after they saw the chaos created by such policies in the APPM dispute at Burnie.

The Leader of the Opposition has recently turned turtle and has said that employers will now have the option to stay within the awards system if they want to. The legal and industrial nightmare of marrying an arbitrated system with a totally deregulated labour market is no doubt the reason that the honourable member for Bennelong has refused to honour his promise to table the Bill.

A minimum youth wage of $3 will be introduced, forcing young people to work for less than the dole. The training voucher of $19 per week will also be available, but employers will not be giving much training for just $19 per week.

Unemployed people would be cut off the dole after nine months, and vicious tests would be imposed to limit the entitlement of unemployed people to benefits. After six months, beneficiaries will be forced to take any job offers at a figure 20 per cent below current award rates. No doubt employers of unskilled workers would replace all of their work force and save the 20 per cent.

There will be no wage rises if the cost of living goes up as, undoubtedly, it will under the GST, which is highly inflationary. Despite rapidly increasing prices, the only wage increases will be for those who can show an increase in productivity. The providers of services will be condemned to ever-decreasing salaries. How could a teacher, a health worker, or a policeman establish higher productivity?

Those employers who choose to opt out of awards will be able to open up a range of hard fought and long held conditions. Overtime, penalty rates, annual leave, holiday pay, superannuation, workers compensation, and health and safety provisions will all be up for grabs.

There can be no doubt that such a strategy will bring our labour costs in line with those of our trading partners—particularly, those in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Korea and China. It will also require a huge reduction in the standard of living of working Australians.

The end result of the Leader of the Opposition's brave new world will be a massive class division. There will also be industrial chaos, as Australian workers bitterly resist being turned into coolies. Australia's economy will be paralysed by strikes and class division.

I might move on from labour relations to industry policy. The rationalists claim that, to get maximum efficiency from the Australian industry, we have to create more competitive markets. They identify two obstacles in that exercise; that is, excessive labour costs and tariffs.

The Opposition's radical solution is to scrap the accord and our arbitration system, crush the unions, reduce wages to the level of our Asian trading partners, and reduce all tariffs to zero. The Government's response has been to use the accord as an incentive for unions to negotiate micro-economic reforms and to gradually produce across-the-board tariff cuts, while at the same time putting forward a number of plans to reinvigorate key protected areas of manufacturing, such as the steel and motor vehicle industries.

The Government relied on macro-economic policy strategy to maintain job growth, and on the accord to maintain wage restraint. I have always seen a flaw in the accord; that is, it did not lock employers into the system. That was why in times of record profits, caused by deregulating the financial system, employers failed to invest in Australia and, instead, played money games and caused the troubles we have today. If the employers had been locked into the accord, we would have had a better result. That is what is happening at the moment. I see a lot of signs that the leaders of employers in this country are prepared to reject their traditional Liberal allies and look for ways to cooperate with the trade union movement and the Government to get Australia back on its feet again. That is good news for Australians.

I think the Budget is good news for Australians. It is a Budget that is responsible. It is certainly responsible in international terms, when one looks at what is happening in Japan and Germany at the moment. It is a caring Budget. It is a Budget about jobs and about people. To that end, it will be very well received when Australia goes to the election.

As I walk around my electorate, I am constantly assailed by supporters of the Liberal Party who want me to put forward in this Parliament propositions to ensure we have a referendum about a GST. It is quite clear that there is a major revolt within the supporters of the Liberal Party. The truth in that assertion can be seen in the small business community, which is almost universally horrified by the issue of the GST.

The Liberals have been trying to sell the GST for a long time, and they have totally failed. There will be a great revolt within their traditional supporters when the next election comes. I only hope that we can find the jobs that will return to the Labor fold the many hundreds of thousands of people who have lost their jobs and left it in recent times. I think that is going to occur with this Budget, because this Budget has a series of realistic plans to get people back to work in Australia.

The Australian people can see which particular party is really caring about their concerns. The Labor Party is prepared to find jobs for them and to spend money to get them back into jobs, and stop tariff reductions. The Liberal Party wants to impose a $27 billion, highly inflationary tax upon them. When that choice is put before the Australian people, we will see one of the biggest landslides in Australian political history to the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No.1) appropriates money for a range of programs for schools, training and higher education. There are few portfolio areas where the Government has such a sorry record as education and training. When its record in education and training is set alongside its record in employment, there is only one conclusion that can be reached: a generation of young Australians has been betrayed. Those in education and training have been betrayed by the damaging effects of the Government's policies on the quality of education and training they are receiving. Those who have been unable to obtain the education and training they want and who are seeking work have been denied employment in record numbers by the shocking mismanagement of the economy.

PARA.TAB: At a time when Australia's main competitor nations are placing increasing emphasis on education and training, and the peers of today's students in other countries are receiving enhanced educational opportunities, the opportunities for young Australians to achieve education of world class standard have declined.

The Government would deny this picture of the effect of its policies. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has on a number of occasions in this House claimed that the Government has had a great success in increasing the numbers of young people who are staying on to the end of secondary school, and then proceeding to tertiary studies. This seems to be almost the whole weight of the Government's defence of its policies, and it is, therefore, worth subjecting to close examination.

The first thing to be said about this defence is that it says nothing about quality: the Government's defence is quantity, not quality. In the end, of course, it will be quality that counts because, if Australians do not receive education and training equal to the best in the world in the open trading environment of this coming decade and beyond, they will certainly not be able to hold down jobs which will withstand international competition. Quality is the key.

Certainly, there must be opportunities for all young Australians to build their knowledge and skills. It is one of our main criticisms of this Government that it has unduly restricted and limited the capacity of young Australians to pursue their education. As the United

SPEECH.PARA: States, which has traditionally had one of the world's highest participation rates, has found, sheer numbers of completions mean little if quality is not there.

PARA.TAB: The Government's attempts to claim higher retention and participation rates as its main educational achievement do not withstand examination. The truth is that school retention rates have been rising for decades. In 1967, 22.7 per cent of students went through to year 12. By 1983, this figure was 40.6 per cent—up from 34.9 per cent in 1976 when the Fraser Government took office. By 1986, the figure had reached 48.7 per cent and in 1990 it was 64 per cent. The Prime Minister always contrives to understate the participation rate in the year that Labor came to power—but we know from his attack on the flag that history was never his strong point. If the Government has made a distinctive contribution to higher retention it is through the impact of the failure of its economic policies in destroying job opportunities for young people.

The previous coalition Government had a proud record of expanding educational opportunity. It was the coalition led by Sir Robert Menzies which began the great expansion in the university sector, and it was the coalition which initiated the policy under which the colleges of advanced education were founded. In 1960, there were 53,391 higher education students in Australia. By 1983, this number had increased to 348,577.

The Government is not entitled to claim any special credit at all for rising educational participation. Given the rising level of qualifications and skills throughout the world, it would have been shocking if it had not increased. It is shocking that the Government, for ideological reasons, continues to restrict the right of parents to choose an appropriate school for their child and to restrict access to tertiary places so that tens of thousands of qualified students are locked out. The Government's policies give every impression of having been deliberately designed to stop Australians investing in education—in their own education and in that of others.

The failures of this Government's policies in education and training are visible at every level of education. After nine years of Labor, one in five Australians does not have even basic functional skills in reading, writing and mathematics, science standards are falling demonstrably relative to other countries, language education has declined, and the knowledge at senior grade levels of Australia's history and institutions is abysmal. The status of teaching as a profession has been eroded and parents who want to choose a school for their child have been discriminated against year after year.

In relation to training, by the Prime Minister's own admission Australia is facing a training emergency. The number of places for young people in vocational education and training has actually declined in recent years as a result of the Government's policy failures. In an address last week, Mr Richard Sweet of the Dusseldorp Skills Forum surveyed the fate of the Government's traineeship system based on subsidised wages. Mr Sweet pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: Since its inception, the Australian Traineeship system has never been able to meet its annual target of 75,000 places adopted as a goal in 1985.

Intakes peaked at 13,796 in 1989-90, but have fallen by around 5,000 to 8,698 in the last two years. This 37 per cent decline in traineeship intakes over the two years is about the same as the observed rate of decline in apprenticeship commencements over the period.
Drop-out rates have also been very high. In each year between 1987-88 and 1990-91 roughly 38 per cent or more of those who commenced a traineeship failed to complete it . . .

Adding up the fall in apprenticeships, in traineeships, and in the non-apprenticeship areas of TAFE, the number of vocational and training places available for Australia's youth has fallen by around 36,000 or 23 per cent since the recession began.

Labor's deliberately chosen training policy has been a complete failure and it is now setting out on a new venture under the guidance of Mr Laurie Carmichael: an Australian certificate of vocational education grounded in competency based training. In theory, of course there is much to be said for competency based training if it is genuinely applied and if it is applied only in those areas for which it is suitable—mainly the trade related areas. Misapplied, it has the potential to do great harm, and the obvious agenda of the Carmichael report is to produce a centralised system of competency definitions linked to the centralised industrial relations system where promotion and pay will be according to certification and where certification is linked directly into the award arrangements.

PARA.TAB: In the industry focus of the system there is a very great danger that the needs of individual enterprises will be overlooked and that employers will end up being forced to pay for training which is of no relevance to them. The Government's approach carries with it the danger that a whole new nationwide and centralised bureaucratic system is about to be imposed on industry, with the trade union movement exercising a veto through tripartite tribunals at every point.

Years have been wasted as the Government has neglected quality vocational education and training for young people as a result of its preoccupation with participation rates in schooling and with its union inspired forced amalgamations between universities and colleges of advanced education. This latter policy, which was never explained or justified on educational grounds and which not even the Government now claims has resulted in significant financial savings in the provision of higher education, was part of the Government's attack on the so-called elitism of the universities in pursuit of its egalitarian ideologies. It has resulted in exploding costs in a number of institutions and has produced a demoralising upheaval which has made academic life increasingly unattractive to those who would otherwise have contemplated an academic career.

Standards across higher education are being squeezed down as a result of this policy of forced amalgamations and there is a looming shortage of up to 20,000 qualified academic staff—a shortage to which this policy has been a significant contributor. The forced amalgamations have not been the only contribution the Government has made to the decline of academic staff conditions. The centralised industrial relations arrangements imposed on universities after 1985 forced on these institutions an inappropriate model which was drawn from the corporate world, with an ideology of confrontation and national uniformity. It has been one of the most significant factors in depriving Australia's universities of control over their own affairs.

But beyond all of that, its great failure has been that it has presided over a sharp decline in the conditions of academic employment relative to those in other countries. For that reason it should be condemned. The failure of this system, so beloved of the Government, is another major contributing factor to the declining attractiveness of academic careers.

The threat that the staff shortage poses to standards is a significant one, but students and staff in universities are well aware of the effect on standards of the overcrowding and declining resources per student which also result from this Government's policies. Here we come to the effects of the absurd system of central regulation which the Government has imposed on the university system.

The problems of overcrowding are a direct result of the regulations the Government has imposed on the universities. The student quotas mean that universities are not funded for the additional students they take in. The incentive was always to enrol up to the quota, never under it. Overcrowding is a direct result not of numbers of students, but of unfunded students. The Government's recession has induced many students to stay on in university. The result has been thousands of unfunded students, with all that this has meant for the quality of teaching and learning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was addressing the problem of overcrowding in universities. The Government has, of course, given its ideology, rejected the obvious answer to the problem of overcrowding. That answer is to allow the universities to create additional places and give students and industry the right to invest in those places—the traditional right that universities have always had. But the Government's answer is to force the universities, at a time of unprecedented demand, to cut back on their intakes. The number of commencing students has actually fallen as the number of students seeking entry has risen. It is 7,000 lower this year than last year. This year there are some 50,000 qualified students locked out of universities, many of whom would have gained entry in previous years. This problem shows every sign of continuing over the next few years unless effective action is taken.

PARA.TAB: This Government mouths its platitudes about equity, but what equity is there in a policy under which universities can admit 15,000 overseas students into unfunded places, with the permission of the Government, but cannot admit Australian students to similar places? This is what the Government calls central planning. It claims to have planned the increase in school retention, which it did not. Does it also claim to be planning the intakes to the universities? Did it plan the disastrous training initiatives to which I have referred?

There is no central plan for education in this country, nor could there be a detailed and coherent central plan given the complexity and size of the education sector. The great mistake the Government has made is believing that there could be such a plan for higher education and forcing its preferences on the system to the point where it is choking the universities in this country of resources which would otherwise be available to them, and demoralising those who are supposed to be bringing the clever country into existence.

The solution is to provide the institutions with the freedom and the flexibility to address the problems. There is nothing very radical about this; it simply means restoring to the universities their traditional freedoms to decide what courses they will teach, to whom they will teach them, the terms on which they will admit students, and the terms on which they will employ staff. These proposals are, of course, frightening to the powerful bureaucratic and union interests for whom the present policies are designed because they mean that power will return to the academics and to the universities and empty away from the central supervisory and regulatory agencies these interests have so painstakingly put in place. So for the next few months until the election we will hear the most irresponsible scare talk about how it is impossible to give the universities back their freedom because this would be incompatible with the interests of working class Australians who would be shut out.

The fraudulence of such claims needs to be exposed. The 50,000 students shut out of universities will be overwhelmingly students from less advantaged backgrounds. The correlation between tertiary entrance scores and educational background makes this certain. Under a freer system there will be more places, because a Hewson government will fund at least as many places as the Government proposes to fund directly, and will also restore the rights of Australian students to provide their own funding for additional places. Many will get industry sponsorships, others will work to put themselves through, and the money available for scholarships to provide free places to talented poor students will expand.

Labor has abandoned its traditional supporters. They are the ones paying the price of the Fawlty Towers system of university regulation the Government has put in place. They will be the major beneficiaries of a better funded system with more places and more scholarships. Out of the chaos caused by this Government, of course, quality has been the victim. But the Government has an answer to that. It will set up committees to give an assurance of quality: when in doubt, set up a committee.

For schools it has set up the so-called national project on the quality of teaching and learning. This is a committee of employer and union representatives. It is the kind of committee beloved of this Government. It excludes the parents and the community, but they have never been favoured participants in the Government's corporate state. The main work of this committee—the national project—seems to be to provide the Australian Teachers Federation and other unions with a cover under which they can hijack the move towards teacher professionalism through supporting an Australian teaching council dominated by the unions and interest groups.

Such a body can never promote teacher professionalism in any real sense because a professional body must be, above all, concerned with standards and must be prepared to act when standards are not maintained. A professional body should be representative and be led by outstanding teachers, and not dominated by the industrial relations agenda. But a real professional body might challenge the grip of the unions, and that cannot be allowed to happen in Labor's world, even at the cost of setting back the professional advancement of teachers for a decade. So little is the Australian Teaching Council being seen as a genuine professional body for teachers that it is even being debated whether teachers will have a majority on it. I am sure that the significance of this fact will not be lost on teachers around Australia.

Then there is the issue of quality in the universities. Ah, the Government has a solution to that one too: set up another committee, this time called the quality assurance mechanism. This committee will give out money to the universities which use their resources best. By what criteria? Ah, this causes more than a slight problem. It is coming up to a year since the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) announced this initiative. We are still waiting to see the criteria. There are no satisfactory criteria which can be administered by such a committee. The criteria of quality relate to the quality of the degrees which the university issues and the quality of its research. One can be quite sure that these will not be the dominant criteria when they are eventually published. The whole concept is a nonsense concept, and instead of pretending that it is viable the Government should abandon it and put the money to some more useful end.

I have referred to the Prime Minister's admission that Australia faces a training emergency. According to the latest report of the Auditor-General, this emergency extends right into the Department of Employment, Education and Training itself. The Auditor-General year after year has made reports drawing attention to serious deficiencies in basic control procedures and accounting routines. The Australian National Audit Office identified the problem: it is a lack of training. As the report concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: There is an urgent need for further training in basic Commonwealth accounting practices at operational levels.

Labor's disastrous failure in education and training reflects a government which has lost its way. The Prime Minister constantly tells us that he is going to do something. The cheque is in the mail, he is from the Government and he is here to help us. But the record speaks for itself. He has no answers. His interest is not in solving problems but in servicing them to meet the political needs of the day. Labor has abandoned its traditional supporters, and a generation of young working class Australians are the victims of the worst policy failure in 60 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed at the comments of the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), even though I recognise that, as the shadow Minister in the employment, education and training area, he may have the odd little axe to grind. He has totally misrepresented the Government's achievements in the area of employment, education and training, and its motives. It is certainly incorrect to say that the Government has forgotten its traditional supporters. Anybody who has been a student of employment, education and training policies in this country would know and note that the Government has improved the opportunities available to every person in Australia in the education system and has also made sure that more places are available for people to take up, as well as improving Austudy, which obviously helps people from lower socio-economic backgrounds.

PARA.TAB: In terms of job skills, we have made sure that people are not going to be disadvantaged because they do not have the skills required in a modern economy. That is a very important aspect of the Government's approach, and one which I am very proud that we have taken. Certainly it cannot be said that a person—for instance, a supporting parent—is now being encouraged to stay on a pension. Such people are being encouraged, on the other hand, to take up a position in the work force or to pursue education to improve their position so that, when their children are older—say, age 16—if they want to go into the work force they will have the skills to do so. That offer, that opportunity, is being accompanied by assistance from the Government in terms of child-care, for instance.

It is an absolute nonsense for the honourable member for Goldstein to make those comments about the Government's employment, education and training programs. I wanted to point that out to the House, although it was not meant to be the primary part of my speech. I would also point out that under Jobstart we have an improved situation where more money is being paid to employers to employ people who have been out of work for a considerable time. They will be subsidised in their employment for up to 26 weeks.

In Western Australia, both in my own and other electorates, we have a particularly good scheme which has been assisted by DEET where BP, a national company, has undertaken to train people to work as forecourt attendants in service stations. This is a new area of employment for people. It is a return to some of the old value systems where people expect to get service for money. The petrol station proprietors acknowledge that they have been losing custom because of self-service. People have been coming into the service stations, getting the petrol themselves and driving on through without anybody checking their water, their oil, the air in their tyres or their batteries. That is an opportunity lost for the small business person concerned, the operator of the service station, in trying to assist that customer to buy something from the service station.

I believe BP has taken a laudable step in this direction, with the assistance of the Federal Government through Jobtrain and Jobstart. I might stress that this scheme has been aimed not just at young people but people up to the age of 45 and over, and they have been getting these jobs. After five weeks of training these people have a guaranteed job for 12 months in the forecourt of a service station in Western Australia. The service station proprietor chooses the person that he or she wants for the job. If they are able to prove themselves, then in a year's time, with the economy picking up, there is a very strong chance that that job will remain on the service station's books.

I am also pleased to say that BP is going on to start a console operators course so that people who previously may have had little experience with computers are now able to train on them. They can then try to get a job in the computing area of a service station in order to be able to assist with stocks and so on. Both Jobstart and Jobtrain are good schemes. I think that the honourable member for Goldstein was underestimating the Government's commitment towards trying to get people into work and also keep people in work. He was also underestimating the Government's commitment to education and to the working people of this country.

This Budget continues the Government's commitment to achieving economic recovery in a responsible way. It contains measures specifically designed to further stimulate employment and improve business and consumer confidence in the economy. It also heralds policy developments which will strengthen the social fabric of Australian society to a very important degree. It is a Budget appropriate to the times and one which has been widely accepted by the community at large. It underlines the caring commitment and capacity of this Government, which stands in stark contrast to the destructive and divisive posturing of the Opposition in its Fightback proposal.

I would point out, in passing, that the Opposition's policies mean that people would be cut off unemployment benefits after a period of nine months. It is no good those opposite saying that is not what it means.

TALK.START.PARA: —They still get special benefits.

—If the unemployed are going onto special benefits, then the Opposition's figuring is all wrong because it is based on a reduction in cost. There would be no reduction in cost if the unemployed were all going onto special benefit. Those opposite cannot have it both ways. It is definitely a fact that the Opposition, for all its moaning on this matter, intends to cut off people's unemployment benefit. I think that is a crying shame.

PARA.TAB: It is also a fact that under the Opposition's policies people would be paying up-front fees to go into tertiary education. This Government is not proposing anything of that kind. On the contrary, this Government is proposing a policy of continued support for and expansion of Austudy for students. It also means that people in receipt of Austudy will have the opportunity to take out a loan of up to $2,000. This is traded in as part of their Austudy in order to expand the student's resources during the period of study. That loan will be paid back in the same way as under the HECS arrangements. In other words, when their income reaches the average weekly earnings point, they start to pay it back through the tax system. This is an important and progressive reform that this Government has made. It will also enable Austudy to be expanded in future.

This Budget has some very important, compassionate and caring aspects. I would like to concentrate my remarks on the areas of health, housing and community services, albeit I have already made some comments on employment, education and training. To begin, the 1992-93 Budget provides a $93m package of assistance to carers. I would point out to honourable members that at the moment I am wearing an `I Support Carers' badge. This has been provided to many members of the Government, but I assume that members of the Opposition would also be able to obtain them. These are badges that people can wear to show that they support carers during this carers week. This is a very important week because carers are a under-recognised resource in our community. Without these people, we would be up for a lot of money. We would be a less compassionate society if we did not have people in the community who are prepared to put themselves out to assist members of their family and their friends.

As I said, this is National Carers Awareness Week. Carers provide care and support for a parent, partner, child or friend who has a disability, who is frail or who suffers from dementia or a chronic illness. It is an unfortunate fact that many carers experience a deterioration in their own health as a consequence of the physical, mental and emotional strain occasioned by long term care of someone else. It is imperative that the Government act to diminish these stresses and strains in every way possible.

I am sure that all honourable members are no strangers to situations in their own electorates where an elderly person is helping their partner and they are suffering physical hardship as a consequence of lifting that person in and out of bed and so on. It is very important for government to recognise the role those people play.

I have a lot to do with people suffering from chronic fatigue syndrome.
