I know that their families go to a great deal of trouble and are subject to a great deal of stress in trying to assist the person through the depression, uncertainty, insecurity and lack of self-esteem associated with that particular illness which has troubled many in Australian society.

I would say that this illness has occurred mostly in the eastern States, especially in New South Wales, but we also have a large number of sufferers in Western Australia. These people could not exist without carers. It is a sad fact that many families or partners are unable to withstand the rigours which those sorts of problems cause. It often ends up with a breakup of the marriage, which is a very sad thing. What the Government is intending to do for carers will help many people in those situations.

Carers deserve our thanks and our support. They need recognition and assistance in their essential role. Accordingly, the Government has proclaimed its commitment to carers in a statement released recently. Its approach to carers contrasts with that of the Opposition—not individual members of the Opposition but the Opposition in general—which has characteristically chosen to ignore the role of these most important people in this critical area of social policy.

It must be understood that the Opposition's proposed cutbacks in government services and spending would cut the heart out of areas such as community services and inevitably would result in even more responsibility and work being thrown on carers and other compassionate volunteers in the community. In other words, the Opposition's `Hands off', `No go' and `Don't ask me' approach to the role of government would result or could result in chaos at the community services coalface.

Responsible government cannot and must not avoid its obligation to provide assistance to those in the community who cannot look after themselves. It must, as this Government does, acknowledge the work of carers, recognise the sacrifices that they make and value each of them as an essential contributor to and component of our society's social fabric. Government must also assist carers in every way possible, including the arrangement of respite care wherever reasonably required.

The Government genuinely cares for carers. The Budget includes the following welcome improvements in this regard: the domiciliary nursing care benefit will be increased by $5 per week to $26 per week from January 1993. It will also be indexed to ensure it keeps pace with increases in the cost of living. Care can be interrupted for up to 42 days a year without affecting eligibility. Carers will benefit from the injection of an extra $40m to expand existing respite services. Almost $5m will be available to improve information and support for carers. This will include a carers kit with information about available services and how to access them, together with material on financial, legal and health issues.The carers pension will be increased by $6 per fortnight in January 1993. Education and part time employment opportunities are to be enhanced and promoted by allowing carers up to 10 weeks for training, employment or education and access to the JET scheme. Importantly, there is an increase in the mobility allowance of $10 per fortnight, which has been indexed to preserve its real value. This allowance will also be extended to people with disabilities who are undertaking voluntary work for at least eight hours a week or looking for employment.

Nowhere is the role of the carer more harrowing than in the area of mental illness. Apart from senile dementia, thousands of families are involved in assisting and supporting sufferers of schizophrenia, often from their teenage years onwards. This is not an easy task. I am very pleased to note that the Budget Bills being debated tonight include an allocation of $135m over the next six years to meet the Government's commitment to implement a national mental health policy in conjunction with the States. This policy will see a major expansion in community based care and acute care facilities in mainstream hospitals, improving care for people affected while enabling the progressive closure of substandard institutions. The national mental health policy will result in a marked change in mental health care, focusing on consumer rights and improved service provision. The package of measures announced in the Budget will increase significantly the range and quality of community services available to assist people with mental health problems.

The Budget also boasts a housing policy which will take Australian housing into the twenty-first century. It will meet the challenge of continuing to provide secure, affordable and appropriate housing for the nation. It will deal with people's changing housing needs over time.As the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) has said, the Commonwealth will work with States, Territories and local governments to ensure that all Australians have access to secure and affordable housing best suited to their needs over a lifetime, to transport, jobs and services, and that our cities and towns remain environmentally sustainable and great places in which to live. As a person who comes from Perth, I can say to members of this House that that is something that I certainly wish to retain for Perth, and I know that other people in other States wish the same thing to be happening in their areas.

This Budget is a caring Budget, a compassionate Budget and a Budget appropriate to the times. The Government has gone to a great deal of trouble and consulted with many people to ensure that it is appropriate and deals with people's needs. It is also a generous Budget, but responsible and much needed to stimulate the economic recovery that we are all looking forward to.
I know in my own heart that the most important things for people are jobs and opportunities, and we as a government are committed to both of those things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just a quick message for the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), who is at the table. I noticed in the Budget that we still do not have funding for that arterial road that he and I have discussed on a number of occasions.
—The cheque is in the mail. I am from the Government and I am here to help you.

—Thank you. I would just like to pick up a couple of points made by the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen). I have to say that I was somewhat disappointed by some of her comments because they were less than accurate. The honourable member for Cowan referred to, for example, the jobs for the petrol station attendants that BP Australia Ltd is organising and so on—which, I have to say, is a good scheme. I remind her that it was her Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who not many weeks ago in this place was pouring great buckets over the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) for suggesting the creation of just such jobs. It seems to me that there is a fair degree of hypocrisy in those statements.

PARA.TAB: I also say to the honourable member for Cowan that the Government does not have a monopoly on care and compassion. I may not be wearing a badge, but if she cares to come down to my office on Friday afternoon she can have tea with the several hundred people, carers from my electorate, who will be coming in to mark the same occasion.

I also have to challenge her on the statement that the coalition would cut the heart out of the carers area. That is absolutely untrue. If she reads Fightback! she will find that there are extra funds directed specifically at those sorts of service deliveries. Where we are going to cut funding is very much in the bureaucracy; but we are going to put the money at the sharp end where we need to deliver the services. She should look at the detail of the policy and not just believe some of the rantings of her Prime Minister in this place on occasions.

Previous speakers from this side have dealt extensively with the broad measures in the Budget, so I do not propose to go over them in great detail. I want to make a few quick general comments. I want to talk specifically about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander elements of the Budget because I take a special interest in that area, being the Deputy Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and being a member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation—in fact, the only member of this chamber on that Council. I also want to develop in depth some thoughts in the area of industry, particularly in science and technology.

In general terms it would be fair to say, from talking extensively around my electorate, that the Budget is a non-event for the average man in the street. It caused a currency crisis when it first came out. It borrows heavily to provide some bandaid measures, and it ignores, for short term political benefits, the fundamental change necessary in this country. It is really all about not offending some people's mates. It increases our debt substantially and will have a marginal impact on the long term unemployment situation. In terms of doing good things for the people in my electorate, it very much leaves them out altogether.

In my electorate of Aston in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne there are no local government capital grants whatsoever. There is minuscule road or housing funding. There is no help for business. The threat when the Budget came down of an increase in interest rates has become an actuality—and this in an electorate which has more mortgage payers than any other electorate in this country. I have the mortgage belt of Australia in my electorate, and what we are seeing is interest rates starting to go up. It seems to me that there is great inequity in terms of the way my unemployed residents are treated compared with many others. A 45-year-old unemployed man with a wife and three children is just as deserving if he lives in my area as one who lives in some other area. Under the scheme that this Government has brought down, he is being ignored totally.

The bottom line is that we must recognise the impact of the world economy and the recession. But 10 years under this Prime Minister as either Treasurer or Prime Minister show that he does not have the answers in any shape or form. What the Government should have been doing is to bring down a reduction in business costs so that businesses can get up and working and start to employ people again. It should have been attacking the issues of the costs of things such as electricity. It should be doing away with payroll tax and attacking the problems with Workcare, petroleum excise and so on. We need a reduction in government interference in business, yet the trend is in the other direction, with more and more forms to fill in.

We should be looking at competition, to get prices down and better service—not monopolies—in the public and private sector, in so many areas whether transport, communications, power generation or whatever. We need some incentives for individuals to save, to invest and to work—not the present system where so much of what we earn goes in tax. We need to wean people away from the handout or welfare mentality. Of course, all of those things are in Fightback.

Let me talk about some of the specifics in this Budget. Firstly, I want to talk about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander area. As I have said, I take a special interest in that. I have no intention of making this area a political football because I think there is broad support for what is going on.

There are three points I would like to make briefly. Firstly, I say to the Government—and I am sure I will have the wholehearted support of the coalition in this—that it has done well to spend money as a result of the recommendations of the Aboriginal Deaths in Custody Royal Commission, but it is important that it continue to press the States, of whichever political persuasion, to make their contribution as well. It seems to me that a number of the States, of all political persuasions, are avoiding that issue. I think it is something that they should not be allowed to get away with. They are running for cover and they have to be made to stand up and face their share of the responsibility as well.

Secondly, there is a need to prune some of the bureaucracy which is eating up so much of the Budget allocation in this area. There are too many consultants and bureaucrats, and not enough of the money that has been allocated to the Aboriginal and Torres Islander area is actually getting out to the sharp end for the delivery of services. Thirdly, I am pleased that the Government has chosen to fund the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation in this Budget for the first time. The Council actually asked for somewhat more than it received. It had a 20 per cent reduction on its original request. That will mean that in this very important area we will be forced to cut back some of the planned activity. I think that is to be regretted. The Council's strategic plan will be presented in this place shortly. Obviously, that will be the time to comment on it in much more detail.

I want to devote some time to talking about industry and innovation. I want to talk about Australia's situation and some of the options facing us today. I will make some general points up-front. Firstly, we need to look at what I would call the technology pull, because of the failure of technology push in this country. For far too long, through R&D, the academic world and others have come up with some very clever ideas and have tried to sell them off to industry. It has not worked. Nobody has wanted to pick up those ideas. We really should be looking at getting our businessmen and our business leaders, as a matter of course, when they have a problem or a competitive need, to say to their R&D people, `Here is a problem. You solve it'. When that answer comes up, they are much more likely to pick it up and implement it. That is the pull from business that we need, rather than just pushing out a few ideas from academia.

We need application of innovation across the board. One or two bright ideas will not solve this country's problems. We need the consistent application of innovation, efficiency and technology right across the landscape of business and industry. I suggest that some of the Government's specific measures in this Budget are well-intentioned, but other things have not been addressed. I would like to remind the House of where this country stands at the moment and refer to the 1992 World Competitiveness Report. An article recently stated:
The 1992 World Competitiveness Report . . . suggests the pace of micro-economic reform and the internationalisation of the Australian economy is not moving fast enough.
While the Federal Government is trying to open up the economy, the rest of the industrialised world—including emerging nations such as Singapore and Taiwan—is making greater progress.

Australia is placed 16th out of 22 Organisations for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, meaning the nation's economic environment does not help to develop companies who can compete in global markets.

Although federal and State governments play a big role in improving the efficiency and productivity of the nation. . . and must share the bulk of the blame for Australia's slide, it seems that business and workers are not up to the challenge either.
Although in the past Australia has had a variety of strengths and weaknesses compared to other nations, the latest report suggests the nation has many weaknesses and only average strengths.

Australia rates poorly in internationalisation (21st), management (19th), domestic economic strength (17th) and science and technology (15th). It fares slightly better in finance (14th), people (13th) and government (13th). Only in terms of infrastructure (11th), Australia makes it into the top half of countries.
Australian managers rate at the very bottom in terms of long-term orientation, international experience and employee relations.

The performance of Australian companies and business efficiency is also near rock bottom in the OECD. Australian companies offer poor value for money products, are not innovative in new product development and have very low levels of productivity improvement, the report says.
Although Australian workers are well educated and healthy, the report finds that attitudes of the workforce are the worst in the OECD.
Workers lack competitive values and motivation, over-indulge in alcohol and drugs and are unwilling to retrain.

SPEECH.PARA: These are not my views; this is an international competitive report that looks at the whole world. The article goes on to say:

. . . a range of government policies are holding back Australia's competitiveness. Although Government fiscal and monetary policies are generally favourable, the legislative and regulatory environment are a drawback—especially in terms of environmental protection, improper practices and government efficiency and transparency.

PARA.TAB: Although financial deregulation is a competitive asset, the report says the finance sector needs to improve its corporate accounts, make capital more readily available for productive purposes and get a better return on funds.
In a comprehensive look at Australia's export portfolio, the report says the worn out industrial structure of the nation must change in a changing world economy or drift into economic oblivion.

Australia's exports are heavily concentrated in energy (coal and oil), agriculture (wool and wheat), mining and basic metals. But these are the areas of world trade which are either declining or growing at slow rates.

On the other hand, in areas such as metal products, chemicals, wood and paper, textiles, food and building products (where world trade is growing the fastest), Australia is only a small player and only a small part of its exports are found in these industries.

SPEECH.PARA: So what has the Government given us? The Government's science and technology White Paper, for example, tells us that the key to developing `a nation that is internationally competitive and environmentally responsible' is to generate business enthusiasm for applying research findings to increase wealth. To achieve this, the Government has revoked its original plan to cut the 150 per cent business research and development tax concession and will retain it, as it is, `indefinitely'. Would it not be better to relieve business costs across the board and cut payroll tax for everybody, as well as Workcare and those other things I mentioned earlier? Why do we have to just pick out some companies? Surely we would get more value from cutting across the board those business input costs, and it would be far less difficult to administer.

PARA.TAB: The Government is to waive the $10m limit on pilot plants purchased or built after 19 August and has reversed an earlier intention to slash support for rural research—a move in the right direction, but hardly a major initiative. The Government plans to create three new advanced engineering centres to bind public research and private industry more closely in an innovation chain. This probably is a good idea, but surely it is still tied to the concept of government involvement and science push when what is really needed is the commercial pull about which I spoke earlier.

The Government is to provide $4.9m to get the Australian magnesium metal R&D project off the ground and revamp the Prime Minister's Science Council to include engineering and, heaven forbid, to include the Federal Treasurer as a member of the Science Council. I would have thought that there were enough government Ministers on that Council as it was. The Government is to set up a special office to commercialise defence science and has funded its science commercialisation agency, the Australian Technology Group, which has not really distinguished itself in glory in the short time in which it has been in existence, through a one-off payment of $30m. Again, this is all more government involvement in business operations. Why not pass it to the private sector, whose very job it is to run business and make a profit?

The Minister has announced a new scheme to link Australian firms to overseas partners to acquire international know-how. It is another contrived scheme, but at least it is a move in the right direction. There is a crying need in this country to get technological transfer into the country and to learn from what goes on overseas. There is, equally, and in some senses more importantly, a need to have those international relationships so that we can take advantage of the international distribution channels for our products going overseas. It is very hard for a company in this country to go overseas and set up the mechanisms and all the infrastructure and the costs that take such a long time to get established. We need those international distribution channels, so those linkages are important.

The Minister has also said that he will launch a genetic manipulation authority to get the biotechnology industry up and running, and he has offered to provide seed funding for a food technology innovation association. As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology—which recently completed an 18-month report of 300-odd pages with 50-odd recommendations into genetic engineering in this country—I certainly welcome this move, but I would also be interested to know when the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) will respond to the recommendations we made in that report.

The major thrust of the Government's White Paper lay in the restoration of some of the nation's science infrastructure, which was run down over the 1980s. A total of $30.6m is provided over two years to upgrade assets in government research agencies. CSIRO receives $12m of this, although I have to say that it asked for $20m. It is perhaps noteworthy that this Government had allowed CSIRO capital spending to sink below the level of the last year of the Fraser Government until only this last 12 months.

There are other measures, of course. I could go on but time precludes that. We have had for far too long the fast buck mentality in industry, research and development, technology and innovation, the areas that I take a particular interest in. This Government has compounded the problem by adopting short term re-election stances. I suggest that the blueprint for advancing our industry, which means the take-up of innovation across the board, as I said earlier, requires a number of fundamental steps.

Starting at the bottom, we need to re-educate our work force and perhaps put much more emphasis on technology and innovation for our children at school. We should be using our purchasing clout, such as it is, to require multinationals to make long term investments here. We should be playing to our strengths in industry clusters—not individual winner picking, but using our natural advantages. We should be educating our business leaders in what is possible by way of technology to help solve their problems.

We need the sort of better business climate provided by Fightback: $20 billion taken off the back of businesses to help them be more competitive, to help them grow and to help them create those important jobs. We need better depreciation and investment incentives for business, and we need to wean business away from the short term property speculator mentality over to the longer term innovation investment mentality.

In summary, I have a jaundiced view of the Budget. Mainly it is short term measures. Debt has increased yet again. We have, of course, seen an incredible increase in debt during the lifetime of this Government. It took us 193 years to get to $23 billion; it has taken us another 10 to get that figure up to something like $180 billion.

No real jobs are created in this Budget at all; they are all short term measures. Locally, in my electorate of Aston, the unemployed are in as much need as they are anywhere else. I am one of only four Federal electorates in the State of Victoria that do not get a red cent. None of my three municipalities get a thing. Do not tell me that is because we do not have a big enough unemployment problem. We may have started off with a lower base, but we have had an over 600 per cent increase in unemployment in the last 10 years. People are bleeding in my area just as much as they are anywhere else, and they are entitled to support and help the same as everybody else. But they have been ignored by this Government.

As I said earlier, I certainly support the thrust of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander elements of the Budget. I dislike many of the science and technology elements. In a sentence, I have to say that this Budget fails to achieve most of what is required for this nation and for its people to prosper. I urge the House to condemn it.
Before I close, I would like to say one other thing very briefly. In Question Time last Thursday the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is espousing policies which would see major companies desist from major investment in the motor vehicle industry . . .

He named me, amongst a number of other coalition members, as being well aware that our policies would wipe out these industries. He implied quite clearly that we were not happy with that. I have to say to the Prime Minister and those opposite that that is untrue. I have certainly never made that sort of statement. Under the Labor Party's administration, companies in my electorate are already voting with their feet and going overseas. Tariffs are not the only issue. We have had a lot of argument recently about tariffs, but there are other things that we will do that the Government will not do which will help business tremendously. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bills give us the opportunity to talk about the matters in the Bills—government fundraising and matters of government spending. Contrary to the attitude of many members on both sides of the House, Australia has great reason for confidence. In 1983 we had double digit unemployment; we also had double digit inflation. In 1992, we have double digit unemployment, which is not good enough, but we also have almost no inflation. I will speak about that a little later. The real challenge is, as honourable members have stated, and as the previous speaker, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) stated, unemployment.
—Who created it?

—As I said, it is no higher now than it was in 1983. We need to face a number of challenges. We certainly need to face the challenge of more equipment, more robots and more computers taking the place of people. We need to face the challenge of how we will share the work. Here we have the problem of competing with countries that are paying low wages.

PARA.TAB: We have to face the challenge of hours of work. That is happening already; more and more people are working part time. We have to face the challenge of optional retirement. That is also being faced right throughout Australia. I congratulate the Government on moving towards optional retirement, particularly through superannuation, and giving people the opportunity to retire from the age of 55.

The honourable member for Aston spoke about local government community projects. I did not receive very much in my electorate either for these projects, because my electorate has lower unemployment than many areas of Australia. For instance, one area which received an allocation was Eurobodalla Shire, which recently had 15.6 per cent unemployment. Areas which did not receive it included Yarrowlumla Shire, which had 2.3 per cent unemployment. So it was based on submissions by local government and shires associations and by the Government itself. The Government wedded the ideas of both sides to come up with the program of local government community projects. Just because the Government did not pork-barrel, it does not mean that it will not be an effective project. It will be more effective because of that. This is why the electorate of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), for instance, received funding.

The challenge to unemployment is not only in the area of creating jobs; it is also in looking at education—education so that we can help people bridge that gap between the relatively high number of unemployed people and the relatively high number of jobs which are available to people with the right skills and the right education, if only they could get these attributes. This is why the moves that are made in the Budget to combat literacy and numeracy problems and to help through the $60m school capital works program some of those schools that have aged and not had an upgrading of facilities for many years are long overdue. All these things will benefit education and assist students to become employable more quickly.

I congratulate Mrs Margaret Whitlam on the work she did with the Australian Language and Literacy Council, touring Australia and inspiring people to seek more funds to help improve literacy and numeracy. This will make a tremendous difference. It will mean that people who have been moving out into the work force without knowing their numbers, without being literate, will no longer feel like drop-outs and feel the low self-esteem that people have at the moment. There will be a big difference, I believe, in the way in which students move out into the community and their readiness for jobs.

The job creation programs are important too. They are important for jobs; they are important because people see the work they are doing as important; and they are important because they are doing some very important works in the community. For instance, the water projects at Mogo, Bermagui, Nimmitabel and Captains Flat have assisted people to get good clean water when they did not have it before.

Dune care has helped many thousands of hectares of coastal Australia via job creation projects in the soil conservation area. Sand is no longer blowing away, no longer being washed out to sea, no longer being subject to widespread erosion. We have seen a lot of growth along our coastal areas simply because of the projects to care for some of the dune areas.

We have seen a wide range of projects, for instance, underground power lines in Cooma. Job creation projects do have long term benefits. The work being done by the Government in tourism will be of great benefit. The Snowy Mountains and coastal areas of south-eastern New South Wales and the historic towns in this area, as well as in other parts of Australia, will benefit from 80,000 new jobs in tourism—simply because of the successful promotion overseas of Australia as a tourist area. Now that tourism has passed all our commodities in terms of its value to Australia as an export industry, we ought to be taking it seriously. We should no longer be dismissing it as something that is temporary and that will not last forever. Paul Hogan did great work overseas in his advertising. Greg Norman did great work overseas. Now there is to be a new impetus with more sophisticated and direct advertising, particularly to some of the people of Asia.

There is good reason for confidence, as long as we are not tied to any of the `isms'—as long as we are not tied, for instance, to economic rationalism as a major reason for our successes. Economic rationalism has contributed to our success, but no `ism' is sacred. Humans are fallible, and so are their doctrines. Capitalism gave us growth, but it also gave us child labour and slavery. Communism gave us new insights into cooperation; it also gave us inefficiency and totalitarianism. Fascism gave us racism, persecution and dictatorships; but even fascism gave us constructive ideas about government intervention into industry. Economic rationalism gave us leaner government, more efficient industries and balanced Budgets. I draw that to the attention of those on this side of the House who deny those benefits. But it would also give us, if allowed to go unleashed, soup kitchens, homelessness and social chaos. Anyone who has visited the United States recently would have seen some of that social chaos in evidence.

Today's governments need to be concerned about the economy. They need to give attention, as well, to interhuman justice and to environmental sustainability. That is the difference between Labor and the coalition. Labor will give more attention to interhuman justice and environmental sustainability. It certainly will not be tied to the doctrine of economic rationalism. Neither would the National Party subscribe to this, except that it is the tail of the Liberal dog. That is its problem. Therefore, it is tied to economic rationalism. That is why honourable members opposite will be very embarrassed as we challenge them on Telecom and on Australia Post—when we challenge their intentions in regard to some of these great local country services.

Certainly, 10 years of a Labor government has seen a couple of mistakes. For instance, lack of control of bank lending may have been a mistake—when we saw people shuffling paper and making money but eventually coming a thud—forcing interest rates up at a time when commodity prices were dropping. There could have been more control of bank lending. Interest rates were perhaps not increased quickly enough. Those increases could have taken place in 1988; it could have been done earlier. There have been mistakes, but there have been some great successes. In spite of what the honourable member for Aston said, under Labor there have been a number of Budget surpluses which have made history in Australia. If we compare them with the achievement of any other government we will not see the level of Federal Budget surpluses that we have had here in Australia. They have stood us in good stead. We have not often been in the black. That means that the Government can go into deficit now with confidence in itself and the confidence of those who know the Government's record.

We have had some excellent Ministers. We have seen tariffs drop. I believe that we should not go back on those. We should not wipe the advantages that we have had from lower tariffs. Neither should we wipe the tariffs altogether because they have given us some great benefits. Certainly, whenever we talk to the Japanese about rice—the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) mentioned this today—they say, `What would we have done in World War II if we had not had our own food, if we had not had rice?'. For similar sorts of reasons we need to have a car industry, a clothing industry and a footwear industry. It would be wrong to allow those industries to go because, if we are to retain our independence and not be dependent on the industries of other countries, we need to have basic industries here in Australia. While I would urge the Government not to go back and increase tariffs, I also urge it not to wipe out tariffs entirely, as the Opposition would.

We have had a great record in health. In fact, our health system, in a very difficult world, is a very good one—one of the best. It may well be the best. I can recall an economics expert who works in business coming to one of the Government's policy committee meetings and mentioning that we ought to be selling our health system and our education system to other countries. Our health system is the best in a world that is finding it very difficult to cope with health costs. We can now spend a lot of money just to keep people alive. Should we be doing it? Archbishop George of Adelaide said only yesterday that it is now so expensive to keep people alive that we ought to look at the ethics of doing so. It is also expensive to treat people. Someone can go into a pharmacy or a hospital pharmacy or have ordered a prescription that is worth $2,700. The Government pays that, and the patient pays $15. That person does not always know how much it costs. So we need to continue this debate on where we are going with health expenditure. That is important.

It is also important that we maintain our lifestyle. For all the criticism of the Victorian Government, just recently Melbourne was awarded fourth position in the world for lifestyle values. It was in the top four in the world. It is true: if we go to Victoria we find that the roads are better, transport is better, and health and community services are better. People in Victoria will certainly yell if Kennett comes to government and wipes these services out. These are all values that the Victorians have learnt to appreciate and which they would certainly miss.

Australia ranked high amongst countries in terms of economic prosperity in the early 1900s. At that time agriculture was over 30 per cent of our economy. It is now down to just over five per cent. Mining has gradually increased in value to the Australian economy. But neither is occupying the proportion of the Australian economy that they once did. Australia cannot expect to rank as high when areas of income on which we depended for so many years are no longer quite as reliable in terms of economic return as they once were.

Of course, the English speaking world is not where it was in the success stakes either. If we were to ask which racial sector of the world is in the most confused state, we would probably look at the former communist states and find that they are in a confused state. But we could also look at the English speaking countries such as Britain, the United States, Canada, New Zealand and Australia. It is true that we have become arrogant over years of being on top. Now comes the inevitable demise when we choke on the lassitude, the arrogance, the careless mistakes, the assumption that the world owes us a living—which very often follow world dominance. There are great opportunities for Australia. We just need to realise where those opportunities are and move away from the attitude that we developed as part of the English speaking world.

There are 1.3 billion people in Europe—1.3 billion people whose trade we probably will not get. There are 1.3 billion people in the Americas—1.3 billion people whose trade we probably will not get because they will gradually be uniting. It has taken them some time, but they will gradually unite and form large single economies. But there are three billion people in Asia. What a great opportunity for farmers and businesses to work with the Asian people in their development. There are some great opportunities for Australia. There is great reason for confidence.

This Budget contains a number of measures for farmers and businesses in country areas. I can think of Landcare, the income equalisation deposits and the farm bonds that are associated with them. There are a couple of things that we need to remember. One is that farmers and businesses should not fall for Fightback. It is not only the paperwork that is involved, where they will have to tally everything that is sold and deduct from it everything that is bought, that will not help businesses and farmers. It will also have an effect on low wages. The performance is less when wages are lower because there is less spending in the community.

Then we have the fuel confusion. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) mentioned it today. Those opposite tell us that they will deduct 19c off petrol prices and, in the same breath, that the user will pay for roads. How? They have not explained it. We can only assume that they will find that $17,000 in the form of a registration charge or that they will tell the States to charge at the bowser. They should be telling us. The Prime Minister made it quite clear today that, after taking into account what those opposite have said, there will be $17,000 a year more in registration charges for vehicles. What will happen to car drivers, including pensioners and people such as that? Will they get a huge registration charge once a year? If the user pays, those opposite will be looking somewhere for most of that 19c. The Opposition will now be tackled by this Government day after day. Where is that user-pays money for roads coming from? We want to know.

One of the great advantages that this Government, farmers and businesses have at the moment is low inflation and a relatively low dollar. What has happened in the last few months with the dollar, interest rates and low inflation could mean $5,000 more for every farm household or $5,000 less on their debt—and I know that quite a few of them are in debt. It will be a $5,000 advantage to farmers. The drop in inflation reduces farm costs and business costs and helps management. It is a tremendous advantage to anyone in business, particularly for farmers who cannot price their goods, and they have always been in that difficult position.

Another reason for a positive attitude within Australia is the fact that there may well be a world recovery. Much depends on Japan and Germany. Just today Germany has made a decision on lower interest rates which could have very good ramifications. It has already had ramifications in the markets today. Much depends on world trade improving. More importantly, much depends on working towards economically, ecologically sustainable usage of our resources. It is particularly important that we get that balance right. In one sense, to use a hackneyed term, we are borrowing these times from our children and what we do today will be very important to our children and our grandchildren in the next century.

Another positive move has come from getting tariffs down. As I said, it has resulted in enormous efficiency in our industry. Farmers do well out of cheaper equipment and machinery charges and they have a vested interest in promoting low tariffs throughout the world. They also recognise that we do not want to walk away from important industries, such as the car industry, which must remain part of our economy if we are not to become dependent on other countries. As has been mentioned by my colleague the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen), there are a great many things for retired people and wages policy. I believe that when it comes to a vote no-one will vote to pay higher prices in shops and no-one will vote for lower wages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about the impact of the Budget on country people, farm viability, town employment and the quality of life of people who live in regional Australia. The starting point is the depressed situation in rural and regional Australia where, in the financial year just ended, most farmers had the lowest incomes ever on record. It reached its worst point with broad acre farmers—that is, the graziers—with a minus $44,000 net farm income. There will be an improvement this year, but not by a great amount. The western division of New South Wales, which is 42 per cent of the State, and parts of western Queensland have the worst drought they have had in many years. Cash income has fallen 55 per cent and the average debt in those areas is over $400,000 per farm. If we look beyond the farm, we see that there are above average levels of unemployment throughout regional Australia.

PARA.TAB: The depressing news in the Budget—this was quickly picked up by people in rural Australia—is that there is no long term hope for improving farm viability, employment or quality of life. There is no strategy; there is nothing that they can look to in the future to improve their situation. When we look at the Budget deficit—and this is very significant with regard to the interest payments that are necessary with those levels of debt—we see that it is already projected officially at $13.4 billion. Independent commentators put it at $21 billion. That compares with the Budget last year when the starting point was officially $4.7 billion and it blew out to $9.9 billion by the end of the year. So who knows what the final Budget deficit figure will be. Already there is pressure on interest rates to move up again with that deficit level and that, in turn, will have pressure on inflation. That is a very significant cost to country people when we consider those average debt levels.

The Government is also projecting income tax cuts to try to match those of the coalition in Fightback. But because the Government has that deficit level, it is obvious that it will have to increase taxes somewhere if it is to have any credibility with its personal income tax proposals. Therefore, there is this question of hidden taxes on the agenda by the Government. In an answer by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in Parliament last week in response to this question of extending the prescribed payments system to the taxi, tourism and fishing industries, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have said that we will tell you in due course, sooner rather than later.

In other words, he has not denied that there will be the extensions of those taxes to those industries—they were all mentioned in Question Time—and, beyond them, to other rural industries with the impact that will have on cash flow. Has there been any recognition in the Budget of the short term problems facing farmers, particularly as this is the worst income year ever? In spite of it being the worst year ever, expenditure in primary industry is down $97.8m. The Budget figures reveal that, in broad terms, primary industry received $1,760m, but that includes $774m of the farmers' own money for the payment on their research levies and so forth and $438m on the diesel rebate. The allocation for primary industry was $551.7m, which, as I said, is down $97.8m. So there is no great hope in the Budget for farmers in the short term or in the long term.

PARA.TAB: Some problems in agriculture are unable to be solved by government, such as natural disasters—particularly the drought at present—and corrupt world trade. But country people do judge a government on what it can do to alleviate these problems. This Government has removed drought, even severe drought, from the natural disaster arrangements. It has put it in the catch-all of rural adjustment and, as there is already a budgetary limit on the rural adjustment scheme, there will not be too much assistance for drought. With corrupt world trade and access to markets, the point is being made repeatedly by the coalition that, for the last 10 years, the Government has put all its faith in the GATT round of multilateral negotiations and turned its back on better bilateral access, whether it be for agricultural or other products that we export. In countries such as Malaysia, Taiwan, the PRC and Indonesia, there is example after example of restrictions against our products which this Government has done nothing to overcome.

The overall impact of a government on a community—and I am talking here of the rural and regional community—is not restricted to one Budget. It is on record that over the past 10 years the Government has systematically transferred government assistance and resources out of regional Australia, whether it has been on roads, tax incentives or the new assets test, which was unfair in equity terms for education and welfare. Those rural industries with tariff assistance had those tariffs reduced without at the same time micro-economic reforms being put in place to provide competitiveness. The dumping and countervailing procedures against those unfair practices were made softer rather than tougher at a time of corrupt world trade. This made it hard for many of our import industries. Then year in year out there was the relentless increase in taxes on inputs, particularly in the form of fuel tax.

The Government has done these things, but sometimes governments recognise that they have made mistakes and do something to redress the balance. What about this Budget? Has the Government recognised any of these errors? Certainly the Government has put some one-off payments into drought relief—$14m into both Queensland and New South Wales—but it has not made the decision that it should have taken to put drought or severe drought back into the natural disaster arrangements. The Government is talking about arranging seminars on risk management for farmers. How realistic is it for someone who is on a nice safe salary, whether in Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne or Canberra, trying to tell a Mallee wheat grower about risk management. When one considers the combination of corrupt world trade, government inputs increasing growers' costs of production, and the effects of the weather and the soil, I cannot think of anybody in Australia who is now more adept at risk management than a Mallee wheat grower. In my view, the present position is absurd. It would be better if more practical forms of assistance were provided for these people.

I am concerned about the rural adjustment changes that are still to be completely announced. There will be even less flexibility under the new arrangements than there was in the past, particularly in relation to corrupt world trade—which, for example, could apply to wheat because of the EEP subsidy proposals of the United States. Following one or two years of a wheat war, an otherwise viable wheat grower might not be able to match rigid criteria because of the lack of flexibility. I hope the Government will recognise special situations where criteria have to be flexible.

The household support arrangement for farmers at the bottom end of the income scale—that is, those who need money to put groceries on the table—is still unfair compared to the rest of Australia. Basically it is still a loan arrangement. The Government said it would overcome this problem by bringing in some special arrangements under Jobsearch for unemployment benefits. When Jobsearch was announced in December last year, the Government indicated that about 5,000 people would qualify. The rural community said, `Well, that is not adequate. The figure needs to be more than that'. But since that scheme commenced nine months ago, not 5,000, or 4,000, or 3,000, or 2,000, or 1,000 have actually qualified. As of Budget day, 672 had applied and only 285 had obtained any assistance under the scheme that was supposed to overcome those problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame, shame!

—And shame it is. This Government has done nothing for the very poor people in Australia. But certainly through its household support and Jobsearch changes, it has made life worse for those in the farming community.

PARA.TAB: The Government did not bring in an adequate income equalisation scheme. If the Government had retained a decent IED scheme, there would not have been quite the call that there is now for government assistance, because there would have been self-insurance by the rural community. The new proposal is still not realistic. It does not take into account the majority of farmers on low taxable incomes, because they have very low incomes—full-stop.

Mention has been made of the Government's commitment to land care and natural resource management. I acknowledge that there is a program, but there is also perhaps not a deliberate sleight of hand, but a situation nevertheless which in reality is not what it appears to be according to Budget announcements. For example, we are told that $74m will be provided this year for these schemes. According to the Budget, that is a big increase on last year. If we go back to last year's Budget Papers, the Government was to allocate $71m but spent only $60m. Hence, in theory, the big increase this year, when in reality there has been virtually no increase whatsoever. I hope that this year the $74m will be allocated.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is sleight of hand.

—It is sleight of hand. In relation to regional employment and the problem of high unemployment in regional Australia, the Government has announced for this year its $250m scheme with local government. Local government is a most appropriate group to administer that type of assistance. I acknowledge that in my electorate all 19 councils qualify and that approximately $5m will be provided. But those local councils say they have a dilemma. If they go back to an employment arrangement such as the old red scheme—having supervisors, having the unemployed and not being able to provide facilities at good cost benefits and/or of long term value to the community—they will face the dilemma or the choice of using private contractors. In that way there will be a better cost benefit delivery, where facilities of long term benefits will be provided, but as a result of which basically no-one who is presently unemployed will be employed. I acknowledge that in some cases it will mean that some who were to lose their jobs will maintain those jobs, but very few unemployed will be employed. The overall point for regional Australia is that there is no substitute for genuine jobs through a more competitive Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is one thing for me or anyone else in the coalition to criticise the Government and its policies; it is another thing for us to say what we would do. We are in a very strong position with regard to policy. The goods and services tax element of Fightback alone means $1 billion in cost savings for Australian farmers. Where there is corrupt world trade, it is difficult in the short term to increase the price farmers receive, but their viability is determined by price minus cost. It is mainly government that has put on those costs and it is government that can remove them.

According to Treasury, there will be a cost saving each year of $1 billion, or an average of $8,000 per commercial farmer; $1.3 billion for the food processing industry; $670m for the timber industry; and $1.1 billion for the road transport industry. According to work carried out by the independent consultants ACIL and also by Treasury, farm families will be better off throughout their income scale because they are part of farm business to start with. Secondly, petrol for private motoring will be considerable cheaper. Thirdly, family allowances will be bigger and better. There will be the most generous form of assistance for those with private health insurance; and, particularly important to country people on low income levels, the income tax threshold will be increased.

The unfair assets test will be replaced with realistic and uniform tests, whether in the education or welfare areas, and in extreme circumstances only the income test will be applied. We will provide a decent IED scheme. Severe drought will be back in the natural disaster arrangements, together with what every committee on drought, including the Government's own committees, has recommended—better right-offs for fodder and water conservation as incentives against drought.

We have a far quicker and tougher policy on fair trade than the Government. We are committed to bilateral, hard-nosed negotiations with other countries. We will provide resource security for forestry. We will make those improvements to the labour market which will mean that no longer will it cost twice as much to slaughter a steer or a sheep in Australia as it does in an abattoir in New Zealand or the United States. I was told recently by some commercial forestry people that it would cost three times as much per tonne to export woodchips through a Sydney wharf than it would through a New Zealand wharf.

But, in the cynical politics of this Government with regard to country policies and people, there is nothing more cynical than its sugar policy. Labor removed the embargo on sugar imports. Labor tried to bring in a certain tariff reduction regime, which the Opposition in the Senate slowed down. Labor broke that Senate arrangement so that as of 1 July this year it is $55 per tonne specific duty rate or about 22 per cent ad valorem. The Industry Commission has recommended that from 1 July 1998 it be a nil tariff. We have said that as part of our general tariff reduction policy, along with the textile and motor vehicle industry, the tariff will be 5 per cent in the year 2000. That is far softer than the Industry Commission report. It means that we have, in effect, rejected the Industry Commission report. Labor has not at this stage rejected the Industry Commission report on the sugar industry.

Fightback will help the sugar farmer and the sugar miller, just as it will anybody else. Labor has done nothing to make coastal shipping competitive and the sugar industry in Australia faces the spectre of sugar from Thailand coming into Western Australia or South Australia cheaper than it can come in from Queensland. Labor cannot do anything about that, only the coalition can. Because of the coalition's commitment to providing greater independence for the Reserve Bank, it can guarantee lower interest rates and inflation rates, which is important for the sugar industry. We in the coalition are committed and have already announced our policy on far tougher fair trade policy than Labor has. There has been some debate about sugar imports into Australia. Australia is a very efficient producer of sugar. Therefore, with the exception of that coastal shipping problem that the industry faces under Labor, any sugar that comes into Australia will do so on an unfair or dumped basis. In that situation, the tariff level that will be there—around 15 or 20 per cent or whatever is determined at that time—will do nothing to protect the domestic sugar industry because some countries will provide export subsidies of up to 200 per cent tariff equivalent.

At this stage Labor has given no indication that it will reject the Industry Commission report and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has indicated that not only will tariffs be in the Government's decision making over the next few months but also other elements that have traditionally been the responsibility of State governments. We will not accept the recommendations of the Courtice committee. It is a political committee.

In conclusion, I remind country people that the Cattlemen's Union passed a unanimous vote of condemnation of the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) because of his failure to deliver to them. That shows the reality of what an important segment of country industry feels about what Labor can provide for rural people generally. In particular, I remind the sugar industry of the recommendations of that committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1980s saw the worldwide ascendancy of neo-conservatism. Springing from populist anti-big-government roots and explicitly in favour of nurturing wealth, neo-conservatism found its intellectual voice in spokesmen such as Gilder who asserted, `to help the poor and middle classes, one must cut the taxes of the rich'. Wanniski popularised the Laffer curve—the theory that tax cuts were essential for economic progress. Reagan, Thatcher and a host of neo-conservative leaders coasted to victory on platforms of smaller government, lower taxes and assaults on organised labour. George F. Will, a conservative colonist, but with an eye for the truth, wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: If Marx had been scribbling away in the Library of Congress as the Reaganites marched into Washington, he would have said: "The class struggle is about to intensify. During the Reagan Terror, labour will lose ground to capital".

By the mid-1980s, neo-laissez-faire governments dominated the Western world—Reagan in the United States, Thatcher in the United Kingdom, Nakasone in Japan, Lange-Douglas in New Zealand—each implementing the politics of deregulation, privatisation and small government.

PARA.TAB: Predictably these ideas proved to be convenient fantasies. In practice the rich got richer and inequality grew—trickle down simply did not trickle. Not surprisingly Australia's Labor governments in office during all but the first two years of the 1980s were influenced by the mood of the times and by the dominance of neo-conservative ideology throughout the Western English speaking world and because of that adopted significant elements of the neo-conservative agenda—lower taxes, smaller government, privatisation, deregulation and a retreat from the interventionist industry policy to the level playing field.

However, Labor's instincts, and its relationship with the broader labour movement, led it away from the worst excesses of the Reagan and Thatcher administrations. Labor moved to implement its policies in step with the ACTU and the broader labour movement rather than seeking to smash trade unionism, as had Reagan and Thatcher who seized upon symbolic disputes with the air traffic controllers and the miners union respectively. The ALP also articulated a social justice strategy to maintain key social infrastructure such as Medicare, unemployment benefits and indexed pensions and targeted social expenditure better to ensure the ongoing viability of key income support programs which would otherwise have been at risk.

As we emerge from the 1980s, neo-conservatism worldwide looks increasingly discredited. In retrospect, the 1980s have been revealed as a decade of wasted economic opportunities in which the Bonds and the Skases rose as bubbles on a whirlpool of speculation and fortunes built not on enterprise but on deals. The economic bubble burst. The boom of the 1980s has been followed by the recession of the 1990s, and once secure administrations which had adopted neo-conservative ideas now appear on very uncertain electoral ground.

Perversely, in Australia the incumbent government which is now reassessing the virtues of neo-conservatism and sloughing off its infatuation with laissez-faire ideology faces its electoral challenge not from the Left but, from the Right. The Liberal-National parties manifesto, Fightback, places the current Opposition unambiguously in the mainstream of 1980s neo-conservatist thinking. It proposes slashing personal income tax by about 30 per cent; reducing the top marginal rate from 49c to 42c in the dollar; introducing a 15 per cent goods and services tax; cutting the public sector by approximately $6 billion; the abandonment of the arbitration system as central to industrial relations by replacing it with individual contracts, low minimum wages and lower youth wages and the emasculation of the union movement. While everyone else, including former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser who now lines up with Bill Kelty to argue against inflexible right wing ideologies, can see the harm that so-called economic racialism has wrought, Dr Hewson is unbending. He rejects the criticisms from the car manufacturers and from BHP—indeed, he rejects any criticisms.

Similar to the few remaining adherents of hard-line communism who claim that state socialism was never correctly applied, Dr Hewson dismisses the failures of Reagan, Thatcher and Douglas as failures of application rather than failures of the theory which underlaid their thinking. What is needed, he contends, is the policy courage to press ahead with an unbending right wing agenda.

Intelligent people reshape their theories when those theories collide with reality. That is the essence of the rational, scientific mind—establish a hypothesis, test it and reject it if it fails. But the Right in Australia appears to be dominated by a narrow, inward-looking zealotry. At a time when organised labour has proven itself to be as rational and as interested in improving the operation of Australian industry as anyone, the Liberal and National parties—State and Federal—are planning an unbridled attack on the working conditions of organised labour. In simple terms, the conservatives have chosen the APPM style of labour relations rather than the ANM style.

Tasmania provides an interesting example of conservative thinking. In Tasmania the Liberal State Government has put forward a draft Industrial Relations Amendment (Enterprise Agreement and Workplace Freedom) Bill, which is a masterpiece of corruption of the English language. The State Government appears to be waiting until after the Federal election to have the Industrial Commission determine the new Tasmanian minimum wage. But there is no doubt that this H.R. Nicholls inspired legislation will impact severely on working conditions in our State. It is so in every other State, as well as Federally. The conservatives are abandoning any pretence at moderation.

In New South Wales the Greiner and Fahey governments have sought to deregister unions such as the BWIU, refused to recognise union participation on industry bodies and rejected the Federal Government's tripartite industry reform process. In Victoria, Kennett has unveiled draconian proposals for labour market reform. In Queensland, the Nationals have proposed laughably low minimum wages for men and lower minimum wages for women. Federally, the Dr Hewson offers the youth of Australia a $3 per hour minimum wage. In short, the neo-conservative agenda is a fully deregulated New Zealand-style wages system.

All of this will be accompanied by a massive wealth transfer from the poor to the rich and job shedding from the public sector. Income tax rates will be reduced for high income earners and the sting in the tail comes with the 15 per cent GST, which is a tax on everything. A consumption tax is inequitable. It impacts when people spend and, as all data consistently shows, the proportion of disposable income consumed declines as income rises—that is, the poor spend all they earn but the rich can save and invest. A consumption tax is therefore regressive, hitting the poor harder than the rich.

The trifecta is labour shedding. The United States, Britain, Japan and Taiwan have begun to implement counter-cyclical policies to stimulate their economies out of recession. The Keating Government has done likewise with the spending initiatives announced in the One Nation and Budget statements. But flexibility is not in the armoury of Dr John Hewson and the army of New Right zealots which now surrounds him on the front bench—amongst them, McLachlan, Kemp, Costello, Howard, Beale and Carlton. With them, Fightback has assumed the status of a holy gospel—not a word to be changed, even though the world has changed drastically since Fightback was conceived.

Public sector job cuts in a recession must inflict terrible misery. We see that misery in Tasmania, where the Groom Government has broken its word not to impose involuntary redundancies. The 600 Department of Construction workers now facing the sack are the innocent victims of a stupid policy which will see 1,100 Tasmanian workers retrenched this year from the public sector. The logic of the Tasmanian Government in the middle of a recession is that cutting the public sector will free up resources for the private sector. This might conceivably make sense in an overheated economy, but with the State just edging out of recession it is madness.

I asked the Parliamentary Library to model the impact of a cut of just 1,000 in public employment in our State. It used the model developed by Chris Murphy of Access Economics. Two quarters after a cut of 1,000 workers is implemented, the total number of unemployed will increase by 600. Eight quarters—or two years—after the cut, the total unemployed will still be 300 higher than it would otherwise have been. That is a road to ruin.

This is nothing, however, to the massive public sector cuts that would be imposed if Dr Hewson's neo-conservatives were to implement Fightback. The States would be cut back further and the Commonwealth's own programs would be slashed. Massive job shedding, on a scale far exceeding anything seen to date, would be inevitable. Industrial confrontation, tax transfers from the least to the most well-off and job shedding—if we strip the policies of their rhetorical shells these are the neo-conservative answers for Australia's problems in the 1990s. They are not my answers, they are not the labour movement's answers and they are not this Labor Government's answers.

This Government has always been at the leading edge of social change. It therefore knows that a simple retreat to past certainties is no longer possible. It is committed to serious analysis of its policies, methods and objectives, as we in the political wing of Labor must be. But we remain forward looking, not backward looking, and committed to policies of change, growth and renewal—not to the repetition of past mistakes. The Australian people will be spared the misfortune of the implementation of Fightback as it becomes increasingly clear that the Opposition simply has no faith in the Australian public. In fact, in today's press there was a very interesting analysis of Dr John Hewson's mind set.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! The honourable member for Denison has consistently referred to a number of honourable members incorrectly. The Chair would be most grateful if you could refer to honourable members by their correct title.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. In this morning's press there was an interesting example of the mind set of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) contained in an article in, I believe, the Financial Review. It was a detailed analysis in which the Leader of the Opposition was quoted as having expressed the view that if the Australian public rejected him or could not see the merit in the arguments he was advancing they did not deserve his government. It is interesting that a political leader of this country would claim that it would be the fault of the Australian people if they rejected him rather than his fault that he failed to persuade the Australian people of the merits of his argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to say a little about defence, but I have to confess that I have left my notes on defence behind. In any case, I want to begin by talking somewhat about the issue of car tariffs because that is an issue which, as a South Australian member, is close to my heart and close to the hearts of my constituents. In light of that, I thought it would be appropriate to use this debate as an opportunity to express some of my views on that issue.

PARA.TAB: I begin by saying that I do not think any reasonable person in this Parliament would ever argue that there was another member of the Parliament who did not want to see the Australian car industry prosper. Nobody in this Parliament has some sort of passionate desire to close down the car industry. I am included in that group; I want to see the car industry grow. I want to see our car industry become an international industry that we can be extremely proud of. I want to see it become one of the really rapid growth car industries of the world, and I think we in this country have the opportunity to achieve that.

A couple of years ago the Industry Commission did quite a lot of work on the car industry. It concluded that Australia could be one of the three most competitive countries in the world in which to invest in order to manufacture passenger motor vehicles. That must be our objective; that is what we have to try to achieve. I am not a defeatist about this. I believe our car industry can do it. Fightback as a document offers the car industry a large number of very major benefits and an opportunity to move down the path of becoming internationally competitive.

Tonight I want to make the House aware of some of the data that we on this side of the House have received from people in the car industry which illustrates the point that I am making—that under Fightback very real benefits will accrue to the car industry which simply are not available under the present Government's programs. First of all, the car industry—and these are the industry's own figures, not mine—estimates that the abolition of payroll tax, which for the industry is a very real burden given the size of the companies, would reduce the cost per car, based on a $15,000 wholesale price car, by between $350 and $400. Clearly, that represents a considerable saving.

Secondly, the abolition of the wholesale sales tax would reduce the cost of producing a car by between $150 and $220. The benefit to the industry in terms of reduced costs from abolishing fuel excise would reduce costs by between $50 and $70 per car. That clearly indicates the very substantial benefits from the tax reform aspects of Fightback alone which the car industry would obtain which simply are not offered by the Australian Labor Party. If one takes the total benefits of those three tax measures, in terms of the reduction in cost per car that would be between $550 and $690.

The argument that the car industry puts is that the difference between the 15 per cent tariff, which is the Labor Party's tariff, and the 5 per cent tariff, which is the negligible level by the year 2000 proposed by the coalition, is in the vicinity of $1,000 per car. That means that it would be possible to import a car for $1,000 less under the coalition's proposal than it would be under the Labor Party's proposal. That disbenefit, if you like, to the car industry must be offset against the cost savings of between $550 and $690 per car as a result of the tax changes. That means that the actual net loss, to use the car industry's figures, taking just those two factors into account, is between $310 per car and $450 per car.

Even if one were to accept those figures—and, as I will explain in a moment, we do not—the proposition that to effectively give imports a relative benefit over the position that would otherwise apply under the Labor Party of between $310 and $450 per car is hardly a difference in price which is likely to have a big impact on demand for cars. But the argument is more complicated than that. Remember that we are not going to continue with the Government's superannuation guarantee charge. We will retain what is already in place at the time of our election but we will not continue with that process, so the car industry will never end up having to pay the 9 per cent superannuation guarantee charge which is the Labor Party's policy; it will end up paying only the current charge. It is hard to work out precisely what benefit that would be per car but it might be in the vicinity of $30.

The figures I have quoted do not include any recognition of the reform to the industrial relations system that has been proposed by the coalition. We estimate that the benefits of that reform will be in the vicinity of $250 per car. So, taking the superannuation guarantee charge and the industrial relations reform into account, we are very nearly at a completely neutral position in terms of per car costs. But that still has not taken into account a range of other micro-economic reforms that the coalition is deeply committed to—waterfront reform, reform of our extremely antiquated and expensive transport system, reductions in energy costs, reductions in telecommunication costs, and so the list goes on.

To take the issue of waterfront reform, it is worth remembering that both importers and exporters—car manufacturers are both of these things—have said, and this has not been disputed by the Government, that the so-called waterfront reforms under the present Government have not yielded a saving of one single dollar; they have not been helpful at all for the car industry. If one takes all of those things into account, there is no doubt that the car industry's position will, in net terms—net all of those benefits in the Fightback package and the process of micro-economic reform by the coalition—be better in terms of costs and relative costs to imports than it currently is.

But the debate goes a bit further than that because the Fightback package also changes the whole dimension of the economics of the demand for cars, and one has to take that into account as well. Approximately 50 per cent of all cars manufactured and sold in Australia are sold for business purposes, to business purchasers. For those particular consumers of cars—and that is around half the consumers of cars—all the Federal taxes that currently exist on those cars will be abolished. There will be no sales tax for those people any more because that will be abolished. There will be no fuel taxes on those cars either, and the GST will be fully refunded for business purchases, business inputs, which means that the cost of 50 per cent of all cars sold in Australia will be substantially reduced. Those cars will be purchased tax free, compared with the current arrangement under which they are purchased subject to sales tax. That will reduce the cost of the average business car by in the vicinity of $2,500.

Although elasticity of demand for cars, according to the Industry Commission, is not very high, it has to be concluded that that $2,500 per car reduction in cost of purchase by businesses—I repeat, 50 per cent of all cars sold—will increase demand for cars. So too will the very substantial reduction in fuel prices brought about by the Fightback package. Remember that for ordinary consumers—that is, the 50 per cent of private motorists who buy cars—the price of petrol will reduce by 19c per litre. For businesses, the other 50 per cent of consumers of cars, the price of fuel will reduce by 26c a litre. To put it very simply, the cost of running a car will be very much cheaper than is currently the case. So the amount of money that either businesses or consumers have to devote not only to buying but to owning and running a car will be very much less than is currently the case, which I would have thought anyone could see would lead to an increase in demand for cars.

So the car industry gets two basic benefits, a substantial reduction in costs and a substantial improvement in demand for motor vehicles which, at a time like this, I would have thought was a wonderful message for people in the car industry to hear. Car sales are at an extremely low level at the moment, and the abolition of the sales tax in particular on business cars, reducing the price of those cars by some $2,500 on average, will be a very major contributor to an improvement in demand. The point I make here is that, in contrast, the Labor Party—and indeed it has boasted it has done this—has reduced the level of protection on cars from an effective rate of 243 per cent to 15 per cent. In other words, it is in the process of overseeing an enormous reduction in tariff protection. But what has it done to reduce the burden of government costs and charges and the inhibitions to reducing the cost of producing cars? The answer is that it has done absolutely nothing. It simply has not achieved the sort of micro-economic reform which is necessary to go with those sorts of tariff reductions.

During 1991 alone, the recession in particular has been responsible for the loss of some 46,682 jobs in the motor vehicle industry in Australia. There are now 66,000 jobs in car manufacturing in Australia, including the component manufacturing side, but let us remember that in 1991 alone, under Labor, 46,682 jobs were lost in the car industry. What gall those opposite have, accusing this side of politics of not wanting to retain jobs in the car industry when they themselves have thrown so many people out of work in that extremely important industry for Australia.

The last issue I want to raise is why some of the car manufacturers are concerned about this process of reducing tariffs. I am not entirely unsympathetic to their concerns because in years gone by, and in particular over the past 10 years, manufacturers have been told they will have to face reductions in tariffs but government has done nothing to reduce their costs.
