They hope that in the future that contribution of government to the industry will be improved very substantially, but they are not sure.

Some of this debate seems to have got a little out of hand, because so many of the cost advantages that the Opposition proposes for the car industry have not been fully taken into account. I believe that by substantially reducing the cost of manufacturing cars in Australia and by going through the process of micro-economic reform in the vital way it has to be done in this country, we will be able to achieve the objective of turning our car industry from being the relatively struggling industry it is today into an extremely profitable and dynamic industry for the future. This industry will be export oriented, and will be able to afford to be export oriented by being internationally competitive.

I noticed this afternoon that on a radio program in Adelaide Mr Ray Grigg, general manager, operations, for Holden's Motor Co., made some interesting comments about the car industry. It is worth reflecting on these comments. In answer to a question on the issue of reducing tariffs, Mr Grigg said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . from all our numbers that we've put together, that we can see that we can survive, as long as there's a realistic pace of duty reductions from the present levels, provided we have support of a really efficient national economy.

That is a fair enough comment. Who could dispute that? That is a commonsense, ordinary, logical comment for him to make. The fact is we do not have an efficient national economy by any measure in the OECD and indeed by comparison with other rapidly industrialising countries. It is about time people faced up to that obvious reality. Mr Grigg went on to say:
And I think the key really is to ensure our viability is the linkage between the rate of tariff reduction and microeconomic reform.

Certainly that has to be achieved. I congratulate Holden's on making the fundamental point that this country must achieve the micro-economic reform that has been promised for so long and has never been delivered.

PARA.TAB: The Automotive Industry Authority's annual report, which was published last week, said that if we do not start doing something about reforming our micro economy—and one could add bringing our taxation system into the 1990s and out of the 1930s—then our car industry simply will not survive. It does not matter what level of tariffs we have, we must ensure that the car industry becomes more competitive through changes to the tax system and micro-economic reform. Mr Grigg and other people in the car industry have made that point very clearly. I think that will be a very important challenge for this Parliament in the years ahead. To reiterate the point I made: the car industry will not survive if micro-economic reform and tax reform is not achieved over the next eight or nine years. If it is achieved then we can turn that car industry into one of the most dynamic car industries in the world.

In the last two or three minutes I want to make a couple of points about the defence budget. First of all, I draw the attention of the House to a statement made by the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, in the Senate on 11 December last year. When making a very political point designed to attack the coalition, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: All Ministers who become Minister for Defence have an obligation to the future of the defence forces—
I would not argue with that—
I want to see a secure and proper future for the defence forces and not some cheap opportunist political trick to rip money off defence to no effect.
He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: I believe that we are at our absolute minimum in respect of defence expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is what the Minister said on 11 December last year, how does he explain that in the defence budget it is proposed that defence spending be cut by $50m a year each year from 1993-94 onwards? We have a range of other objections to the way in which the defence budget has been handled. There is once more a cut to the combat capability of the Australian Defence Force. There has been no effort at all to reduce the bureaucratic and non-combat costs, when I would have thought it made perfect commonsense to bring us at the very minimum into line with comparable defence forces around the world.

PARA.TAB: We are also very concerned that the defence budget is being used, to some extent, to finance so-called make work schemes instead of being used to ensure that we improve the effectiveness of the combat capability of our Defence Force. We are very disappointed to see that Labor is continuing with its Ready Reserve program, which is proving to be a massive cost blow-out. The cost of the Ready Reserve at the moment is running at 71 per cent of the cost of regulars, which is a massive blow-out from the original figure of around 40 per cent. Not only will the Ready Reserve fail to improve the combat capability of the Defence Force by definition in that it replaces regulars, but it will also reduce the combat effectiveness and the Government will save very little money in the process. That does not make much sense.

There are a range of other things I would like to say about the defence budget but time does not permit me. I conclude by saying that the Government spends something like $75m on defence cooperation with our regional neighbours, which is only slightly more than it spends on the telephone bill for the Department of Defence. That says something about the Labor Party's priority for the defence of this country and the need for our country to work more closely with our regional neighbours in order to underwrite the security of our part of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1992-93. Mr Deputy Speaker, that was an appalling performance by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). Here we have the shadow Minister for defence, with such a major departmental responsibility, and in a speech lasting 20 minutes he spent only two minutes on defence. Why? Because every debate that takes place nowadays sees an attempt by those opposite to justify their insane scheme called Fightback. What does the shadow Minister for defence spend 80 per cent of the time allotted to him on? He can choose how to spend his time, and tonight he spent his time on the car industry, on Fightback and on the GST.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The fact that I forgot my notes should be included in the honourable member's remarks.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it adds to the problem. In other words, the honourable member cannot speak on his portfolio area without notes, and he is so incapable he even forgets those. I just wanted to make the point that it was an appalling performance but I will come back to his comments later.

PARA.TAB: The national Budget in Australia should essentially be about Australia's asset—its people. Australia is a country with people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you work that out, after about 60 years in the Parliament?

—The honourable member will understand that shortly. We have seen in recent years this debate about economies moving towards non-human terms—it is dehumanised and mechanistic. The parameters and details all ignore people. I find it fascinating that we hear `people' being used in some pejorative sense. Rather than the economy being to help people, it is being put forward by so many of the commentators, and certainly some of the economists, as people being the victims of the economy.

PARA.TAB: Fundamentally, the Budget should be a human document, and this one is. It is about jobs, activity and where things are happening. In the same way as an economy should be talked of in human terms, so should the question of change in a society. In our modern electronic age it is very easy to talk about change. We can modify a computer program in a matter of seconds and it will apply instantly right across the country and across the world. It is very simple to do that. We can drive along in our cars, get to a corner and turn left or right, very simply, and we are going in an entirely different direction. It is so easy.

They are the kinds of changes that people keep talking about. That is the kind of methodology that we keep hearing for the mechanistics in this community. But the fact is that real change is about people—about people changing, people adapting. In a sense, that cannot be hustled, it cannot be hurried and it cannot be accelerated by pushing a foot down, turning a wheel or pushing a button because it is about people absorbing and adapting and modifying their behaviour, understanding and knowledge base. Those who think they understand how fast a community can change are deluding themselves and others. What we are seeing in the world, but particularly in Australia, is a massive degree of change taking place.

There are some who argue that we could change much faster and that the way to make change happen faster is to accelerate the forces of change—put more pressure on people. Sure, people would change faster, but it would not be change; it would be collapse. That kind of change is not progress; that kind of change is chaos—and that is what we hear about so much from the other side. At the same time we hear so much talking down of Australia. We are being insulted daily as being incompetent. We are being told how hopeless we are and how we have done so badly. Mind you, most of it was done when those opposite were in government. We hear from those opposite criticisms of people who rent and all the other pejorative things; they blame society for what they see as measurements in the economy.

The fact is that the Australian community is changing, and in many ways much more rapidly than most of the world. This Budget does reflect that. I draw attention to page 2.37 which looks at the composition of exports. We see the change that has occurred in the last 10 years in both elaborate and simple manufactured exports from Australia. That massive change is occurring in our community, in our society, and is reflected in the Budget and in the economy. The fact that we are now exporting more manufactured goods—things that we make or grow—is a substantial change. There was a manufactures surplus of $3.9 billion in the last financial year. That would have been unheard of 10 years ago. The growth in services is also encouraging.

That also brings us to the question of where the economy truly is and where it can best go. The event since the Budget which has been exciting and very positive has been the modification of the exchange rate of the Australian dollar. In theory a nation's currency reflects its cost of production. In Australia its currency has not reflected that; it has reflected its resource base and its stability. In other words, we have been marked up by the world as being a stable society and in turn our currency has been given a higher value. The adjustments that have occurred in recent weeks are very positive and will be very productive. For those manufactured exports that we have seen in the last two to three years the change in currency essentially improves the profitability of those companies that have been exporting.

There has been a revolution going on inside Australian factories. But one only knows about it if one goes in them. Hence to many of the economists and commentators—certainly most of those honourable members opposite, if not all of them—what is happening is invisible; they do not see it. They do not go inside the factories to find out what is taking place. From the outside they look the same; there are the same buildings with the same names on the doors. But inside there has been dramatic change which is why so many of them are now exporting.

I recall back in 1983 going around the major companies in my area, such as BHP, Tubemakers, Goninan, Commonwealth Steel and a whole host of major Australian companies. Quite frankly, most of them were not exporting and back in those years had no hope of exporting. Now virtually all of them are exporting. A fundamental part of their business plans is now exports. Last year BHP Newcastle exported 40 per cent of its steel products. As we all know, that was not at a highly profitable rate. But if it were to export the same volume at the same overseas price in the current year, it would make 10 per cent more in profits. That is why the exchange rate is so important. What we are seeing is a potential for a massive uplift in company profits for those companies exporting.

Of course, that addresses one of the concerns that most of us would have had in terms of recovery. As we come out of recession, there is a real danger that those companies that have been exporting and doing it so well will tend to cater more for the domestic market and drop off export activities because of the lack of profitability. Of course, the change in the dollar value means that that will not happen; they will maintain their exports because it is worth while doing so as they are now so profitable. That is why this current thrust of economic policy has to be sustained where it is. That is why we must maintain our support for the workplace changes that have taken place and which have allowed these companies to become so productive, and maintain the economic and financial support for those companies, particularly the ones relating to depreciation mentioned in One Nation and also referred to in the Budget.

The difficulties that companies have found in lifting our trade, particularly into Asia because we all understand the difficulties of culture, language, habits and attitudes—are not easy ones to overcome. As a country that has predominantly exported to the English speaking world for most of its life, to adapt as well as we have done to export to Asia has been a tremendous performance. I really get annoyed when I see our companies being bucketed indirectly, and even directly at times, by those opposite. They really do put down our people. We have damned good management in our companies these days and our work force is as productive as any in the world. One has only to go to factories in Sweden, Germany or England, as I have, to see the difference and to recognise that we are as capable as any in terms of production, and we are doing it.

Recently, an Australian company has been to Canada to look at alternative production technologies and methodologies. What it found was that in general the Australian companies are as good as those in Canada. But the end result of that process has been a change in this company that will make it the best in the world, way ahead of almost any other. That has been agreed to and is under way. Certainly, that company's performance in the last six months has been spectacular. That sort of thing has been happening all over the place. There have been no massive headlines; there has been no big story and no hysteria about it. People have been going about their business properly and appropriately. What is more, they are getting results.

So to my mind the decline in the value of the dollar has been not a blessing but a constructive rebalancing of our economy. One must take into account the Budget projections in what I see now as a different light in terms of the dollar value. I therefore expect that our companies will maintain their directions and their emphasis on exports.

I mentioned earlier that that change has been designed in human terms and has to be measured in human terms; otherwise it will introduce chaos. The boundary between orderly change and chaos is a very fine one. One often does not know where that boundary is until it has been exceeded, although in many cases one can see the potential.

The Opposition has been putting forward in this debate—and in virtually every debate, as I mentioned earlier—a rationale to support its Fightback! document. I do not blame those opposite in a way because it is pretty hard to support the policy and they need all the air time they can get. The reasons for that are that the document itself has some deep and fundamental problems. Certainly, it would become a major impediment for the kind of growth that I was speaking of and the maintenance of the export drive that has been going for the last three or four years.

The first problem with Fightback is the uncertainty. The document is absolutely vague. We keep hearing about it being definitive and detailed, but in so many areas it is not just vague but obscure and misleading. The honourable member for Mayo just spoke about savings and excise. The document also talks about a road users charge: detail, unspecified; value, unspecified; impact, unspecified—and, therefore, uncosted. How on earth can any sensible businessman or normal citizen form a judgment on such a major policy area which is so vague, obscure and misleading?

There is a lack of clarity about exemptions, for example, in the building industry. What about the plumber who puts plumbing into a school or a hospital, compared with the plumber who puts it into a normal business or a private house? How does the tax affect plumbers' costs? The one who puts it into the school, quite logically, is exempt. Therefore, he cannot recover his tax inputs, which means that he has to charge more.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't understand it.

—I understand it better than most. What I am talking about is lack of clarity. That is what the building industry is on about right now. Why is it so concerned if the document is so clear and so wonderful? Why is it asking for dramatic changes to Fightback?

PARA.TAB: Health care is another area in which there is a lack of clarity. There is puzzlement as to whether wheelchairs should be or will be taxed. There is puzzlement about the medications a pensioner gets on a script which can also be bought over a counter. If they are on a script, it is `health'; if they are purchased over the counter, they may just taste nice and have no health impact whatsoever. Can people choose their own exemptions by taking vitamin E or vitamin B1 because they want to and not because they are required to by a doctor for their health? Which one is exempt? Both? Neither? That is the kind of lack of clarity I am talking about.

The pharmacists understand all this very well. They know exactly how it is all going to work, as do other businesses. What happens when we tell shopkeepers that they will have to get a new cash register on which to do their calculations because the old one probably will not be any good? There is no compensation. They will have to buy it. We will see a cash register-led recovery. There will be a massive growth in imports. We do not make them; we import them all. We will see literally millions of them.

There is one simple sum that needs to be understood. At the moment we have 75,000 collectors collecting $9 billion. Under Fightback we will have one million to 1 1/2 million collectors collecting $27 billion. In other words, we will have three times the revenue for 10 to 15 times as many collectors. This is supposed to be an efficient tax. Perhaps it is efficient for the government, but it certainly will not be efficient for business, because most of those people cannot claim a thing. They do not pay payroll tax. They are not involved in wholesale sales tax now. They are not involved in the training levy. They are not involved in any of those savings we hear about. For them it is all on-costs. It is all a new charge.

We will see an army of collectors, ranging from the mums in the tuckshops to the football clubs, from the barber to the taxi driver, and—an important one—the hairdresser. Let us not forget the child-care centres. All over Australia, millions of them will be conscripted into an army of collectors. Their lives will be dominated by suddenly having a position of collecting public money, which means that they must be accountable; they can be scrutinised by the Audit Office. We know what that means. If they are behind or make a mistake, it is their problem. If they give credit and go broke, tough luck.

Do we then need to go to the next logical stage: the stage the Italians have reached? We hear about the black economy that this is going to be so good for. It is so good for the black economy that the Italians have brought in laws requiring customers to have a docket within 100 yards of where they bought their goods. We see children in Italy being convicted of the crime of not having a receipt. Will we reach that stage as well? Fightback does not say. It lacks clarity. There is massive confusion as to what all that actually means. The other aspect is the impact on normal people; those people for whom we see so little thought from the Opposition. We feel sympathy for the unemployed. The Budget reflects the great concern for the unemployed being canvassed in political circles in Australia. Their level of expenditure is so limited—they spend virtually all they get; and in many cases more, by borrowing—that all of it would be impacted by a GST. The idea that somehow they can make up for it on savings on wholesale sales tax!

I had not realised before the honourable member for Mayo spoke that cars in Australia will be taxed at different rates after the Opposition introduces its GST. It is a whole new business dodge. Cars will be tax free for business people—the Jaguars and the Rovers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all tax deductable now.

—The business pays for them. It is a whole new thing. Do we see the fringe benefits tax being increased accordingly to make up for it, or does Joe Blow, who has to buy a car to get to work, pay a different price from the guy who drives a company car because it is more convenient and cheaper? We just heard there would be a different price. We would go back to the old system of differential pricing. From all the experience of the last eight years, the Opposition has learnt nothing. The sense of fairness in Australian taxation will go out the window.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members contend that all this revolutionary change and radical ideology will somehow solve the recession. I have news for them. They should go to Europe and look there. They should talk to the French about how the VAT helps them avoid a recession and how it helps to employ people. They should talk to the Brits. What we are seeing here is a revisiting of Thatcherism, but it is much more extreme than Thatcherism. No way would this end a recession. If anything, it will make it worse.

What we will see is two years of people waiting, business not investing and exporters not exporting. People will be waiting to see how it is going to work. The confusion, lack of clarity and sheer outrageousness of it mean that Australia will stand still for at least two years. Whilst the recession is now ending, the recovery is coming through and exports have been going up, that will all come to an end while people wait to see what is going happen. What the Opposition is putting forward is a stagnation. It is much more than a double dip. If the Opposition is successful, the stagnation that will come will mean two years of uncertainty, confusion and chaos—and Opposition members are talking about these massive changes somehow helping the economy!
The Budget is a good Budget. It is about people, and it will help people. It is good for the nation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a very good example of the Government's misinformation campaign about the coalition's Fightback package; a very good example of the way this Government and its members are prepared to distort the proposals being put forward in a very positive and constructive manner by the coalition to try to rebuild Australia's rather shattered economy. It also shows us an abysmal lack of understanding not just of the coalition's tax changes but of the existing tax system.

PARA.TAB: I suggest to the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) that he sit down and read what the Fightback package is all about and what the tax changes are all about rather than reading his dot, dot, dot press releases from the Labor Party headquarters that just enable him to put his name into the appropriate place without having to do any thinking about it.

The standard of the speech we just heard reflects the standard of the Budget which was delivered in this House a couple of short weeks ago. The fact that the Budget sank without trace within 48 hours of its launch by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) is indicative of the fact that the business community, and the broader community at large, saw this Budget as nothing more than an effort by a rather desperate government to try to buy votes by creating thousands of short term artificial jobs with hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money.

This Budget provides no real prospect of long term jobs as a result of any of the initiatives in the Budget. The Budget spends much of the taxpayers' money in creating short term jobs. Interestingly enough, the creation of those jobs will all fall within the next couple of months. They must all be in place by January next year. That is sufficiently well timed to ensure that unemployment figures come down as a result of the artificial jobs being put in place prior to the March election next year. It is nothing more than a rather cynical exercise to try to reduce the unemployment figures, even though it will be for a short period. It is sufficient to bring the unemployment figures down prior to the next election, which will give the Government some desperate hope of re-election.

The Budget really does not do much at all other than to create the biggest deficit that Australia has ever seen—some $13.4 billion. The real deficit in this Budget is more than $13.4 billion; it runs at around $20.9 billion. We should take into account the fact that this Government is selling several billions of dollars of government assets and is treating those asset sales as if they were normal revenue. By doing that we would find the true Budget deficit, the operating deficit of this Government for the next financial year, is $20.9 billion. There has been some very clever artificial constructive—

TALK.START.PARA: —Pushing one pay period through.

—Yes, pushing one pay period through, which saves around $700m, as the Leader of the National Party points out. The Government is also taking the sale of Australian Airlines—which I think occurred today—as normal revenue. The sale of Australian Airlines is achieved by selling it to the Government's other airline, which happens to be Qantas Airways Ltd. Qantas is borrowing $400m to pay for Australian Airlines. Yet the Government is treating the sale of one of its airlines to another one of its airlines, which is using borrowed money to finance the whole deal, as normal operating revenue for the current financial year. That example highlights the creative accounting that this Government has engaged in and, coupled with the other example that the Leader of the National Party has pointed out to me by way of interjection, it shows the very cynical ends that this Government will go to in order to paint a different picture from the reality that exists today.

PARA.TAB: The Government engages in many attempts to distract Australians' attention from the reality of the day: we have seen the Government engage in an attack on the monarchy in an attempt to introduce a republic and we have seen the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) denigrate the Australian flag, both in Australia and overseas—one of the most disgraceful acts of any Prime Minister in the course of his tenure of office as Prime Minister. In the last few days we have seen the Prime Minister try to distract the nation's attention further by suggesting that the Senate ought to be abolished—yet another attempt by this Prime Minister to take us away from the real issues that concern the average Australian.

The real issue that concerns the average Australian, which the Government had hoped would be addressed in this Budget, is the nearly one million people who are unemployed as a result of the recession that we `had to have', the recession that was engineered by none other than the man who stands in this House as the Prime Minister of Australia. He engineered this recession, he told us we had to have it and the responsibility of this recession rests fairly and squarely on the shoulders of our Prime Minister.

The principal issue Australia faces at present is how to create lasting jobs for the one million unemployed and how to deal with our growing foreign debt with a net value today of around $150 billion. When this Labor Government came into power in 1983, net foreign debt was around $22 billion. In 9 1/2 years it has blown out from $22 billion to $150 billion. It is a disgraceful legacy that this Government will leave to future generations of Australians. They will not only have to pay the interest on that foreign debt; they will have to try to reduce the capital over the years ahead.

This Government is responsible for record bankruptcies and has caused hardship to nearly one million Australians and their families. This Budget does nothing to address the root causes of Australia's problems. What does it do for farmers? There is absolutely nothing in the Budget which farmers can point to and say, `This is good for me. This will enable me to expand my operations, which will enable me to pay back some of my debts and try to create a few jobs in my community'. There is nothing in the Budget for a farmer or for small businessmen. There is not one iota of hope in this Budget for small businessmen.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't mention farmers once in the Budget, did he?

—As the honourable member for Maranoa points out, one would think that small businessmen do not exist. If honourable members listened to the Budget Speech of the Treasurer, they would have heard that small businessmen get nothing out of this Budget. The only thing they get out of this Budget is the prospect of increased interest rates, because in this Budget year the Government will borrow about $18 billion in order to fund its operations. By borrowing $18 billion and by undertaking the sorts of policies that it does, small businessmen, farmers and businessmen generally can expect to see interest rates increasing. Indeed, we have already had two banks increase interest rates over the last couple of weeks since the Budget came out. That is an indication of things to come. As a result of this Government's decisions small businessmen and farmers can look forward to business costs going up, the superannuation guarantee levy and a direct burden on the costs of businesses—
—And hidden taxes.

—And hidden taxes, as the honourable member for Murray points out. Within 24 hours the Opposition was able to highlight to the people of Australia—it has been picked up by economic commentators around the country—that this Budget is full of not only increased costs through the superannuation guarantee levy but also hidden taxes.

PARA.TAB: We must also remember that, in the next few months, there will be an increased cost to businesses again as this Government does a deal with its old pal and running mate, the ACTU. Honourable members should wait and see. Wages will increase within the next few months as this Government does a deal with the ACTU to trade off its continuing support for the Labor Party to get the sort of assistance—material and otherwise—that it needs for the next election campaign. Costs are increasing for farmers and for businesses and job prospects are decreasing. That is the net result of the Budget that was delivered by the Treasurer a few weeks ago.

As we debate this Budget tonight it is important that we recognise the incredible hardship that exists in the community. There are extraordinary things going on in my own electorate. I have been talking to farmers and small businessmen over the last few months. I have asked them how their businesses are going and whether they are able to keep their head above water. Nearly everyone—whether they be farmers or small businessmen—has said, `We're hanging in there by the skin of our teeth. We don't know how much longer we are going to survive'. I was at the Harden Show last weekend and I spoke to some of the farmers there. They said, `Maybe we'll survive until Christmas. With luck, if wheat prices do not collapse, we might survive another year'. That example, coupled with the numerous examples there are in talking to small businessmen, indicates how tenuous it is for many small businessmen and farmers.

People say to me, `Farmers had a few great years in the latter 1980s. Wool prices were up and wheat prices were good. Surely farmers were able to overcome their economic problems during those years so that they could weather a prolonged recession such as the one the ex-Treasurer and now Prime Minister has given us'. Had we not suffered the impost of high interest rates during the latter 1980s that would have been the case. High interest rates meant that rather than farmers and small businessmen reducing their debts, their debts were either staying the same or even increasing.

The policy of the man who now stands here as Prime Minister was to increase interest rates to the point where they nearly strangled the Australian economy. The direct consequence of that is that many of our farmers and small businessmen today are in very bad shape as a result of the recession. We are now seeing record bankruptcies and farmers are walking off their farms. In many cases, farmers are trapped on the farm—they are unable to make the place pay, are unable to sell it and are unable to walk off it—with nowhere to go because of the circumstances

SPEECH.PARA: that prevail. Many things have been undetaken by this Government to make the lot of farmers harder.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they abolished IEDs.

—The honourable member for Maranoa points out the abolishment of IEDs. That was one of the silliest decisions this Government ever made. Had it not undertaken that, at least there would have been some glimmer of hope for some farmers out there today.

PARA.TAB: Of course, there is a glimmer of hope. It comes in the form of the coalition's Fightback package. Many farmers and small businessmen in my electorate are looking forward to the day when that can be implemented, because the NFF—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about road user charges.

—Well, I will get on to that. If the honourable member wants to talk about road user charges, there are a lot of things that we can talk about in terms of road funding. We can talk about the reductions in transport costs that will be generated as a result of the Fightback package—reductions in transport costs that go beyond anything that this Government has ever done. All that this Government has done since it got into office is put up the cost of transport, put up the cost of operating a truck and reduce the amount of funding that has been put into the roads budget by about 30 per cent in real terms. That is the legacy that this Government has left to this country.

PARA.TAB: The hope that we will give transport operators, small businessmen and farmers is highlighted in the NFF's analysis of the Fightback package in which it undertook a review of the effect of Fightback on the operating expenses and income of a farm. It is interesting to note that in that analysis the NFF highlights the fact that as a result of the implementation of the Fightback package farm incomes will increase by about 22 per cent in, say, a beef property in Queensland.

In my territory, in southern New South Wales, the NFF did an analysis of how the Fightback package would affect a wheat and sheep farm. The NFF says that a wheat and sheep property's net income would increase by 15 per cent. In anybody's terms, 15 per cent is a significant increase for a farmer in my electorate. That is the net consequence of the implementation of the coalition's Fightback package. I believe that it is that type of initiative that we need to see coming from this Government.

We need to see the abolition of payroll tax, the abolition of fuel excise and the abolition of wholesale sales taxes. It involves reform of our Australian taxation system to put incentive back into the system and to give people the opportunity to save money. It will give them the chance to have more money left in their pay packet at the end of the fortnight. That is the sort of thing that the NFF in its analysis of our Fightback package recognises is the net result of the coalition's activities.

I take the opportunity also to point out a particular concern about the city of Goulburn. In the next couple of months the city of Goulburn will see the opening of the bypass. In many ways this will be a welcome event as the 3,500 trucks which have travelled down the main street of Goulburn every 24 hours for the past few years have caused a great deal of difficulty for the city, a city which seeks to make itself an attractive place. Also the heavy traffic has put at risk the lives of many people in the city, who fear that one of those thousands of trucks might tip over and cause all sorts of injury and damage.

The bypass is a good thing. Unfortunately, with the bypass will come a reduction in income for the city of Goulburn. We all expected that to be the case, but the unfortunate aspect of the reduction in income resulting from the bypass is that it will be coupled with the worst recession we have had for 60 years. As a result of that many small businessmen in Goulburn are telling me that the reduction in income that they will experience as a result of the bypass will be the last straw for them. In good or reasonably good years they could have weathered the reduction in income as a result of the bypass. But the bypass coupled with a recession will cause a major problem for employers in Goulburn.

One of the interesting things we saw in the Budget a couple of weeks ago was this Government going about the business of handing out large amounts of money to local governments. But it did not do it to every local government; it did it on a rather ad hoc basis. We noted that millions of dollars went to the electorate of the Prime Minister. Indeed, not a single cent came to the city of Goulburn, which has some 2,300 people unemployed. That is really unusual.

In another part of my electorate, in Nowra, the city of Shoalhaven, with 3,697 unemployed, received a sum of $2m. Yet Goulburn—a smaller place than the city of Shoalhaven—with 2,301 people unemployed did not get a single cent. Why is it that unemployed people in Goulburn do not rate one single dollar of extra assistance, yet unemployed people in Nowra rate $2m worth of extra assistance? I think that this is grossly inequitable. I think that the people of Goulburn and other towns in my electorate who got absolutely nothing have a right to ask why it is better to be unemployed in one town rather than the other.

I suggest to the House tonight that in light of the fact that we have a recession—one engineered by the Prime Minister, who is personally pleased with the fact—and the fact that the city of Goulburn has a bypass that will be opened in the next couple of months and that it will have a deleterious effect on the income of that city, I think Goulburn has a right to claim a portion of that local government money that has been distributed around Australia. If Nowra is entitled to $2m and in view of the number of people unemployed in Goulburn, then on the basis of equity Goulburn is entitled to $1.25m of local government assistance to try to help overcome the effects of the recession, particularly in light of the opening of the bypass.

I put it to the House tonight that that type of initiative should be undertaken to offset the effect of the recession, to offset the effect of the bypass, and to ensure that equity becomes part of the system of allocating funds to local government bodies to try to assist unemployed people in our community. The unemployed in Goulburn have just as much right to assistance as do the unemployed in Nowra. If the Government is interested in equity it should heed my suggestion and put $1.25m worth of funds into local government in Goulburn to try to assist the unemployed and to put some capital into the community to help overcome the effect of the bypass and the recession.

With those words tonight, I think one can conclude that the Budget delivered by the Treasurer has been even less well received than the Budget delivered by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) just 12 months ago. The Budget delivered by the honourable member for Werriwa just 12 months ago was one of the worst delivered by any government in Australia. I think that the Budget delivered by the current Treasurer beats even that sad track record. We will not see productivity in Australia improving. We will not see our competitiveness improve as a result of this Budget. We will not see any long-term job prospects created as a result of this Budget. All we will see is a short term cynical exercise in buying artificial jobs to help get this Government re-elected.

I think that it is about time that the people of Australia woke up to this con trick. This Government has been conning them for 9 1/2 years. Let this Government not con them any longer. Let us see the Government go and a coalition government come into being. Let us see those initiatives that will create real, long term, lasting jobs for Australians so that we can reduce our foreign debt, keep people in jobs and see our standard of living improve. That is what we will get from a coalition. We have not had it from this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget will provide jobs. Indeed, the Budget is about jobs. It is a Budget which will open up a new horizon of opportunity for the employment of hundreds of thousands of Australians. It is a Budget which has been designed by a caring Government, committed to uplifting the economic prospects for all Australians.

PARA.TAB: It is a Budget shaped to protect and defend the most vulnerable of our fellow citizens. For those Australians seeking work, this Budget introduces employment measures costing $1.2 billion over the next two years. These measures will provide real opportunities for the unemployed to obtain work and to widen the opportunities for all Australians to lead worthwhile lives.

Contrary to what the Opposition would have us believe, with its false claims, mean-minded and denigrating comments, the programs and initiatives contained in this Budget have been welcomed by the Australian people. The speech by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in reply to this Budget was an extraordinary exercise. It was characterised by sneering abuse of genuine initiatives designed to uplift the economy.

There was also a menacing attitude in the Budget response by the Leader of the Opposition. It was a menacing attitude to the unemployed, the youth of Australia, students, manufacturers and others. There were no constructive suggestions. It was just an abusive attack. It was a rehash of the dangerous dogma contained in the manifesto that those opposite call Fightback.

It should be made widely known to every Australian that the dogma contained in Fightback is to the Leader of the Opposition, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) and their supporters in the Liberal and National parties what the dogma contained in Karl Marx's Das Kapital was to the communists. The followers of Fightback are zealots in their blinkered and slavish loyalty to the Fightback creed. Examples of this occur almost every week. Their attitude is characterised by arrogant declarations of opinions, aloofness and bone-headed obstinacy not to listen to any advice, let alone good advice.

Car manufacturers, mining companies and other employer groups are not the only targets of attack by the Opposition. Unfortunately, it will be the ordinary Australian who will have to live day by day, week by week, with the policies of the Liberal and National parties in the unlikely event that they win the next Federal election.

I began my remarks by correctly identifying one of the fundamental objectives of this Budget, and that is the generation of new jobs. Since the election of this Government in 1983, more than 1.8 million new jobs have been created. Government policies with respect to labour market programs and services have been instrumental in achieving this magnificent outcome, and the progress goes on. This financial year, for example, the Federal Government has budgeted to spend $1,185m to provide 428,000 places through a number of labour market programs to assist disadvantaged job seekers. These programs include wage subsidies, vocationally oriented training courses, Skillshare, land care and environment action programs and many other assistance packages which will bring about new opportunities for the job seeker.

By way of contrast, the Opposition's policy in Fightback proposes to amalgamate the Commonwealth Employment Service with the Department of Social Security. In other words, the Commonwealth Employment Service office would be abolished. In my electorate, the Townsville office of the Commonwealth Employment Service would be abolished. So too would the Aitkenvale office of the Commonwealth Employment Service. The Ingham office of the Commonwealth Employment Service would cease to exist. Job applicants would be compelled to seek out private employment contractors and such like in their scramble to find work. The wage subsidies program would be abolished and expenditure on vocationally oriented training courses would be cut by $58m. The cuts on these two programs, on the basis of 1992-93 Budget figures, would represent a drop of $340m or 135,000 places.

Even more menacing for the unemployed, the Jobsearch allowance and the Newstart allowance would be abolished for those who have been unemployed for nine months. The unemployed would be provided with a training voucher. That is what Fightback would mean to them. After the completion of their training course, there would be no offer of a program place, unlike the Government's accredited training offer.

Let us consider the attitude of some private employment agencies to the disadvantaged in the labour market. No-one seriously believes that all job seekers would be treated equally. Do honourable members believe that women, the disabled, Aborigines and the long term unemployed would have equal access to the job market? The answer is no. The Commonwealth Employment Service currently places over four times as many people in jobs as private agencies. The advantages of a Commonwealth agency such as the Commonwealth Employment Service would be gone. Fightback would victimise the unemployed. Fightback would compel many to pay fees to private employment agencies—together with a 15 per cent goods and services tax. It would create a new and permanent underclass of embittered Australians, and all the while the unemployed would continue to pay Fightback's 15 per cent tax on food, rent, clothing, transport and almost everything else.

It seems that this crazy decision in Fightback to abolish the Commonwealth Employment Service is part of the coalition's decision to cut $10 billion from Federal Government spending. Also, why does Fightback propose to end the Jobsearch allowance after nine months? This is a truly heartless and malevolent proposal. The Opposition proposes that persons who have been receiving the Jobsearch allowance for nine months will be required to apply for the more restrictive special benefit. It is apparently lost on the Opposition that Australia has done remarkably well in minimising long term employment without requiring benefits to be terminated. This is another example of Fightback policy craziness and if it were ever implemented it would, in my view, cause a spectacular rise in crime. Australian cities would no longer be as safe as they are now.

I now turn to the issue of higher education. Since 1983 student numbers at Australian universities and the former colleges of advanced education have increased from 348,600 to about 560,000. A tiny fraction of this number are overseas students. Importantly, this Labor Government has increased funding by $1.25 billion and additional funding of $314m is planned over the next two years. In my electorate, James Cook University has been a major recipient of increased recurrent funding as well as being the beneficiary of a huge capital works program. New buildings at James Cook University are sprouting up all over the campus. Whereas there were about 3,000 students in 1983, there are now about 8,000, and by 1996 it is planned that there will be 11,000 students. When this number of students is reached, the participation rate will approximate that of the national average. So for years James Cook University was starved by conservative governments of essential funding for capital works and student places. The result was that thousands of North Queenslanders were denied the career opportunities provided by a university education.

One would expect that, with such a disgraceful record, the Liberal and National parties would make amends and design a policy to take full advantage of the innate abilities and ambitions of qualified Australians wishing to achieve a university education. But Fightback contains no hope for them. The policies of Fightback provide for a voucher system of funding. According to the shadow Minister for education, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), the Opposition's policy is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to allow all universities to determine fees for all courses and all students.

He has described this as a key element of the Opposition's policy. So the financially disadvantaged would be denied equity in access to higher education. It is false for the Opposition to claim that up-front fees would open up more places at universities. Fees for a three-year arts degree are about $25,000, and for a six-year medicine degree the cost is $130,000.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition says that it will provide scholarships and affordable loans, but does anyone seriously believe the promises of scholarships when the Leader of the Opposition has pledged to cut $10 billion from the Federal Budget? Furthermore, loans would be made available on a commercial basis—that is to say, at commercial interest rates. The question must be asked: would there be a loss of students in relatively expensive courses such as engineering, science and agriculture? This is at a time when there is a crying need for more engineers and scientists in Australia. More ominously, the voucher system proposed by the Opposition would effectively remove control over admissions policies from universities. This situation would be untenable. It is obvious that the Fightback program of the Liberal and National parties does not recognise the element of public good in higher education. The fundamental outcome of Fightback would be to restrict the benefits that higher education brings to the Australian economy, to Australian society and to Australian culture.

Another misleading claim by the Opposition is that it would exempt or zero rate educational institutions from its goods and services tax of 15 per cent. The exemption does not apply to the provision of food or beverages to students, nor does it extend to the activities of university companies. James Cook University has formed such companies, and they have an important role in commercialising the results of research conducted at that university. These companies would bear the full brunt of the coalition's consumption tax of 15 per cent, and I have no doubt that as a consequence their activities would be severely curtailed.

James Cook University is also active in the export of educational services. There is now a risk that these could also be targeted and slugged with a consumption tax of 15 per cent. The Financial Review of 1 September 1992 reported that a technical committee working out the details of the Opposition's consumption tax is considering recommending that the goods and services tax on educational export services should apply. This means, in effect, a 15 per cent tax on overseas students revenue raised by universities. On the basis of 1990 revenues from overseas students, this would cost Australian universities around $21m a year. Ominously, the Opposition has so far failed to reject this proposal.

The Federal Opposition's onslaught against higher education does not finish at this point. Fightback promises a review of Austudy, with intended cuts of $114m and a 6 per cent increase to compensate for the goods and services tax. Families in North Queensland with children intending to proceed to university would be aghast to learn that the Liberal shadow Minister has described the proposal to replace Austudy grants with loans as `unambiguously progressive'.

James Cook University, which has a particular responsibility for the education of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, could be forced to abandon its programs for Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders because the coalition has a firm proposal to save $13m by abandoning eligibility for income support under Abstudy. I have no doubt that, were that policy to be introduced, participation by Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in higher education would sharply diminish.

In summary, the policies of the Liberal and National parties on higher education would destroy equity of access, reduce institutional autonomy, and place impossible financial burdens on students. In the final analysis, the higher education policies of the Opposition would diminish both the higher education system itself and the system's contribution to the broad Australian society.

I now turn to the issue of transport. Recently the Government announced the largest ever Federal government annual road funding program. In 1992-93 a total of $2.3 billion in Federal funds will be spent on roads. This is an outstanding achievement. Federal Government road funding this year will not only dramatically improve Australia's land transport infrastructure but also provide employment for up to 50,000 people. If Australia is to improve its international competitiveness, it is fundamental that it possess an efficient road transport system. The allocation of $2.3 billion of Federal road funds this year is proof of this Labor Government's determination not only to maintain but also to rehabilitate the national highway system across Australia.

This year the Federal Government's road allocation to Queensland is $373.7m, which is a 37 per cent increase on last year's amount. In addition, local governments in Queensland will receive $68m from the Federal Government for road works. This is a proud achievement of the Federal Labor Government. It is an achievement which is unmatched by any government in Australia's history.

Each of these guaranteed commitments to road funding could be either abandoned or placed in grave jeopardy if the coalition were to win the next Federal election. The Fightback! document pledges a future Liberal-National Federal government to reduce road funding to 1991-92 levels, with funding to be reviewed at some later date. This is $900m less than the Labor Government's existing program. Every Australian motorist and road user should write to the Leader of the Opposition and ask him how he is going to meet the $3.9 billion shortfall in revenue under his Fightback manifesto.

People should also ask the Leader of the Opposition how he would implement his policy to impose road user charges. They should also ask him to guarantee that the States will not be forced to hike up car registration charges and fuel franchise fees because of his policies. Under the user pays pricing principles favoured by the Leader of the Opposition, the cost of registering a four-cylinder Holden Commodore in Queensland at September 1992 prices, including third party insurance, would jump from $397.70 to more than $1,000. This alone would provoke outrage from motorists in North Queensland.

Will the Leader of the Opposition guarantee in writing that there will be sufficient funds to meet the necessary additional construction and maintenance costs of roads for which the Federal Government is responsible without increasing his 15 per cent goods and services tax? I do not expect the Leader of the Opposition to be in a hurry to answer these questions, because the fact is that the Fightback manifesto of the Liberal and National parties would result in the biggest slug on motorists ever perpetrated by any Liberal-National government, or indeed by any government.

TAB.TAB: For Australian road users, and particularly road users in North Queensland, the Opposition's policy would doom many North Queensland transport operators and inflict prohibitive freight costs on the delivery of goods to North Queensland. The people of North Queensland reject out of hand a road policy which is based on a road user charge—a move which would cancel out the removal of the fuel tax. Because of Fightback, the people of northern Australia in particular are confronted with a threat to their standard of living. People should be made aware of that. The price of Fightback is too high for Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity, in the first debate on the Appropriation Bills since I was appointed shadow Minister for sustainable development and the environment, to give some indication to the House of, firstly, my personal approach to this portfolio and, secondly, the Opposition's approach to the subject of sustainable development and the environment. I say without qualification that I am delighted to be in this portfolio. It enables me to pursue lifelong issues in which I have had a deep interest long before they were recognised under the descriptive word `environment'. Ever since childhood I have enjoyed the Australian bush. I have enjoyed bushwalking. As I got older I developed aesthetic sensibilities, with a taste in music, theatre, opera, architecture and landscape, and continued these interests over the whole of the period to the present day. So it is a delight to be able to carry out professionally some of the things that hitherto I have enjoyed privately.

PARA.TAB: One of the things I would like to make quite clear to the House and to anybody who has an interest in this portfolio is that if people come to me on these issues they will certainly be dealing with somebody who feels passionately about them and has thought about them deeply over a very long period, and certainly for many years before they became a matter of high political interest.

That has not always been the case in Australia. We did not have in earlier days an enormously good record, for example, of preserving our built heritage. It is a very great sadness to me that in my home city of Sydney a number of buildings were demolished in the earlier part of this century, and until comparatively recent times, that certainly should not have been demolished. It is a very sad thing to have happened to those wonderful colonial buildings. Fortunately, over more recent years—and over the last 20 years, in particular—there have been quite substantial changes in people's attitudes to these things, and there is public support for preserving what is good, and, certainly, for trying to improve environmental standards across a broad range of human activities.

I would like to look a little at the history of this issue, because it is commonly assumed that the political attention to it has been very recent. I can remember 20 years ago, when I took over from Sir John Carrick—then Mr Carrick—as the General Secretary of the Liberal Party in New South Wales, the appointment by the then Liberal Government of the first Federal department to include the term `environment'. The Hon. Peter Howson was the Minister in that area. I recall visiting the well-known conservationist Vincent Serventy to seek his advice on improvements to the environmental policies of the McMahon Government in the lead up to the 1972 election. Indeed, Mr Serventy wrote to me on my recent appointment, reminding me of that particular meeting. A lot of the advice that he gave me is certainly still very sound, and I intend to follow it.

I will briefly draw to the attention of the House some of the achievements of the coalition in the area of the environment. I mentioned already that we set up the first Federal department to include the environment in 1971. We were responsible for the development of the national conservation strategy for Australia, and we made the first grants to significant voluntary conservation organisations.

In relation to Antarctica, we were responsible for the Antarctic Treaty Act of 1960, and, much later in the period of the Fraser Government, the introduction of the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act of 1980, and the Antarctic Marine Living Resources Conservation Act of 1981. We were pioneers in the preservation of whales. We commissioned the Frost report, and introduced the Whale Protection Act of 1980.

In 1982 we introduced the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Imports and Exports) Act and the Migratory Birds Ordinance of 1980. We attempted, with some success, to arrive at satisfactory arrangements with the States on these matters, with the offshore constitutional settlement of 1980 and, earlier than that, in fact, with the Environment (Financial Assistance) Act of 1977.

In relation to national parks, we were responsible for proclaiming the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. We also prevented sandmining on Fraser Island. We proclaimed the Kakadu and Uluru parks. We proclaimed the Christmas Island National Park. We established marine nature reserves through the Coral Sea proclamations.

We were also active in the control of pollution. We introduced unleaded petrol to Australia. We also introduced the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act of 1981 and the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act of 1983. We actually proposed that for introduction, but it was subsequently passed by the Hawke Government. Earlier than that, we passed the States Grants (Air Quality Monitoring) Act of 1976, the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act of 1978, and the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act of 1978.

In the area of water management, we gave the Murray River Commission power over water quality management control in 1982, and we were responsible for initiating the bicentennial waters program. In the area of World Heritage, we secured the listings of the Great Barrier Reef, Kakadu Stage I, and the Willandra Lakes in 1981. We initiated proposals for the listing of the Lord Howe Islands Group in 1982, and the western Tasmanian wilderness in 1982. We did all this with the consent and cooperation of the respective State or Territory governments.

On other matters, we commissioned major Federal environmental impact statements. In particular, I mention Fraser Island and the Alligator Rivers system. We established the Office of the Supervising Scientist to ensure the safety of the mining of uranium. We set up the national soil conservation program in 1980, and the national tree program of 1982. We set up the National Estate Register, and made the first listings in 1977.

That is a substantial listing of environmental actions by coalition governments. So anybody who comes along in more recent days and says that there has not been a very big commitment by the coalition to environmental issues simply does not understand the history; they merely look at the rewriting of history by the Labor Party.

I will now turn to more recent history, and look at the 1990 election. Leading up to the 1990 election, we had a spring cleaning of coalition policies on the environment, which was led by my then colleague Senator Chris Puplick. This required looking back on our achievements in the environmental area, which were substantial. We were looking in a progressive way at what we should be doing for the future.

In the course of that review, Senator Puplick consulted with all groups in the community which had an interest in the environment, whether they be environmental bodies, miners, foresters, or anybody who was likely to have an impact on the environment. He initiated a long-ranging debate within the coalition as to what our policies should be, and we all agreed on a progressive, but realistic, set of policies. All the environmental groups, in particular, were consulted, and they all knew the criteria on which we based those policies.

On the other side of politics, Senator Richardson was the Minister responsible in this area. He put to the conservation movement a set of policies which, quite honestly, could never realistically be delivered. We suffered enormous political damage in that campaign.

The Australian Conservation Foundation, led by Mr Philip Toyne, actually endorsed for the very first time a political party—the Labor Party—on the basis of the proposals put to it by Senator Richardson. We had to stand firm on our policies, because we did not believe, for example, that it was realistic to propose some kind of Whitlamesque overriding of the States in this area, since the States had substantial constitutional powers in the area of the environment. We were quite honest with all the groups that we spoke to. We said the same thing to everybody, regardless of from which direction they came.

In the election, we were chopped off at the knees by leading members of conservation groups. Of course, the preferences of people supporting those policies went mainly to the Labor Party and, since it was a preference election, they probably had something to do with the outcome of the election.

What happened after the election? As we pointed out to these various groups, they were, indeed, disappointed. In many respects, the Labor Party—the Labor Government—backed down on those commitments. One important backdown was the establishment of the intergovernmental agreement on the environment between the Commonwealth and the States.

We had made it quite clear in the election campaign that it was not possible to have sensible environmental management without a cooperative attitude on the part of the Commonwealth towards the States. The States have the capacity in their constitutional powers to influence almost every major environmental decision. It was just not real life to suggest that the Commonwealth, by using external affairs powers or whatever, could override these State responsibilities.

There had to be cooperation, and the Labor Government realised that. It set up the inter-governmental agreement, which may or may not be perfect, but it was certainly an endorsement of the position that we had taken quite honestly before the election. Of course, it was a great disappointment to certain elements of the environment movement who had believed Senator Richardson. Senator Richardson's successor, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly), has been put in a very awkward position. She has had to try to meet the needs of the constituency that had been created to try to fulfil unreal expectations and, of course, has necessarily disappointed the people who had those expectations. Therefore, there is not a very high degree of confidence amongst the environmental movement in the Labor Party or in the present Minister.

The other problem that has occurred is that issues relating to the environment are a matter of great contention and public difference between two Ministers in the Cabinet—the Minister for the environment and the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths). It seems that the way in which the Government operates is to have two Ministers, each with separate clientele, who have arguments in a semi-public fashion. That is very destructive way of dealing with environmental issues.

Our approach is quite different. We believe that it is important to get all the criteria on the table and to bring all the people with an interest in these subjects together in a cooperative fashion to get as much agreement as we possibly can. I am reminded of the advice given to me by Vincent Serventy some 20 years ago, that in any contentious issue involving the environment if one gets all of the interested parties around the table one can usually get, amongst reasonable people—and most of them are reasonable—agreement on at least 90 per cent of those issues. The Government then has to make a decision on the remainder.

That is the way in which we propose to go about it. It is quite wrong to bring about an atmosphere of conflict in these issues because it damages not only the path of economic progress, which is desperately important to us at the moment, but also the environmental considerations when genuine environmental considerations can be discredited in such a public argument.

When we come to office we propose to set up a department of sustainable development to consult with all interested parties prior to Cabinet consideration. Of course, we believe unashamedly in the need for economic growth. During the worst recession in Australia for 60 years job creating enterprises must get off the ground. We see no reason why these cannot get off the ground whilst maintaining the highest environmental standards. We propose to do this through the department of sustainable development by bringing all of the parties together to get as much agreement as we can and sweep away bureaucratic obstructions. Where necessary, the Government will take decisions to get those projects ahead, achieving at the same time a balance between the need for economic growth and the need for the highest environmental standards.

The other thing we want to do is to promote growth in industries that take advantage of the expanded world market for environmental goods and services. The coalition's Fightback plan is designed to encourage investment in growth industries in Australia. There are a number of these. Communications is one such industry, but certainly environmental goods and services is another. All the elements of Fightback which attract and encourage international and domestic investment in Australia—low inflation, low taxes, a flexible labour market, low costs of services provided by instrumentalities such as those providing telephone services, power, water, transport, port facilities and so on—will be of enormous value to those firms wishing to pursue environmental goods and services for their export potential.

So it is good business for Australia, as well as being aesthetically essential, for us to be a showcase environmentally around the world. If we have very high environmental standards, if we do things well here, if we control pollution well and if we attack our biggest single problem of land degradation well, then the people who have that expertise to tackle those problems and make us an international showcase will be able to set up companies to exploit those opportunities in world markets. So there is a link between the Fightback plan for development of industry and our objectives of very high environmental standards.

Quite simply, we are proposing an unashamed pursuit of sustainable development—economic growth with high environmental standards. There need be no conflict between the two. It is quite possible to advance the cause of human progress here and to create lasting jobs in the whole of the community by pursuing at the same time objectives of economic growth and high environmental standards. It is that objective to which we will dedicate ourselves.

I look forward very much indeed to continuing my meetings with environmental groups, people in the business community, miners, foresters, the people involved in pollution control and the pollution control industry—all of those people who contribute in some way to the improvement of our environment. I look forward to meeting with all of them and to accepting their advice about how we should proceed, whilst balancing the various views and applying a criteria of excellence in the way in which we deal with these things. Certainly, in the process I will derive a great deal of personal enjoyment from being in a field in which I have had a very longstanding private interest.
Debate (on motion by Ms Fatin) adjourned.
Motion (by Ms Fatin) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring to the attention of the House a very important and historic event which is taking place in Cowra tomorrow evening at 5.30. The event to which I refer is the official opening of the world peace bell by His Excellency Rear Admiral Peter Sinclair, the Governor of New South Wales, in Cowra. The world peace bell is made from coins and medals of the member nations of the United Nations which have been melted down to form a very large bell. The purpose of the bell is to show concern about the evils of war and to try to promote the importance of peace—a most worthy goal that I am sure all honourable members would agree is one which is deserving of support by all good and sound citizens of the world.

PARA.TAB: Most nations of the world which have peace bells have housed them in their national capitals. However, the World Peace Bell Association has awarded a peace bell to Australia. It is a gift to the Australian people, yet rather than establishing the peace bell in Canberra—which is, of course, our nation's capital—or in any of the other State capitals, Cowra has acquired the honour of being the caretaker and the home of the bell.

The reason for this is apparent to anybody who understands the history of Australia during the Second World War, because Cowra played a very special role in that history. Cowra was the home of a prisoner of war camp with some 1,100 prisoners. On 5 August 1944, 234 Japanese prisoners of war were killed at the camp. There were 108 prisoners injured and four camp guards were killed in what become known as the Cowra break-out. Indeed, all of the Japanese prisoners of war who escaped were rounded up in the days that followed and returned to the camp.

Rather than treat that experience that they went through during the Second World War as a bitter experience, and in turn be embittered by it, the people of Cowra decided to turn to their former foes and to embrace them as their friends for the future. They did that in a rather meaningful form by the creation of the Cowra Japanese Gardens, and also through the establishment of very close personal relations with Japan. Student exchanges have been going on now for over 20 years, and of course there is a continual flow of official and unofficial visitors.

As part of this process, Cowra decided to dedicate its annual festival, the Festival of the Lachlan Valley, to the theme of the promotion of international understanding.Over the last nearly 30 years we have had a parade of nearly 30 guest nations as part of that festival to promote international understanding in Cowra. This was recognised by the director of the multilateral disarmament section of the Department of Foreign Affairs, John Okley, when he visited Cowra on holidays in September 1988. While visiting the Japanese Gardens he made the passing comment that this would be a perfect home for the world peace bell. The current Shire President, Rod Blume, who was then the Chairman of the Cowra Tourist and Development Board, heard of this comment. He contacted me and said, `We only know that it was a person from Foreign Affairs on holidays. Can you find out who it was?'. We found out who it was and the Cowra Shire Council undertook the task of trying to persuade everybody that the world peace bell, which was being offered to Australia, should be located in Cowra.

After a great deal of discussion, when all the State capitals of Australia, plus of course Canberra, lobbied to get the bell, the decision was finally made that Cowra would be the home of the bell in recognition of the fact that Cowra, more than any other community in Australia, had shown by its own example over nearly 30 years that it had a commitment to the aims of the World Peace Bell Association—that is, the promotion of peace through international understanding—over and above any other community in Australia. May I take this opportunity to congratulate the people of Cowra and their leaders. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday, in the grievance debate, I raised an issue of considerable concern to both myself and many of my constituents: investment advisory services. Since my speech last Thursday there have been a number of comments made in the media about the criticisms I made. I would like to take this opportunity in the few minutes available to me to make a few points with regard to the criticisms. A number of people have tried to cloud the issue with other points, but the essential themes that were raised in my speech regarding investment advisory services have not been counteracted and there has been no refutation of the major points that I made.

PARA.TAB: I would like to go over some of the points that I made in that speech and clarify some of the points that have been made in response by some commentators. One of the messages that have come through quite clearly from what I had to say last Thursday, and it has clearly not been refuted by any of the commentators, is that all investors should take very careful note of the expertise, the qualifications and the independence of those people who claim to be expert independent financial advisers. The point I was making in my speech on Thursday was that there are a lot of people who have set themselves up in business as financial planners or investment advisers but have very few, if any, actual qualifications to carry out that task.

Although I have been criticised by some and accused of conducting a witch-hunt against certain people, none of the commentators have been able to refute the fact that most of the people who set themselves up as financial advisers do not have any academic qualifications. I believe it is very important, if one is going to be involved in giving people advice about where they should place their money in investments—we are talking about some people who may have received superannuation pay-outs of $200,000 to $300,000 and are seeking to place that money in secure financial situations so that they can live off it in their retirement—to make sure that the people providing that advice have very sound qualifications.

The fact is that just doing a part time course at a TAFE college, where they can get some 30 hours in some of the specifics about financial planning or buying stocks and shares, does not give those people the broad understanding of the workings of the economy or of the rigours and constraints that are required of an accountancy degree or a commerce degree. I believe they are fundamental foundations that all financial planners must have before they can set up as financial advisers.

Any other profession or trade has rigid qualification requirements which must be satisfied. Consumers do have safety in the knowledge that anyone who calls himself or herself a doctor, a solicitor, an accountant, or even an electrician, plumber, or carpenter, has satisfied certain qualification requirements and is registered to perform that task. If consumers have some problem with poor service that they may have received from that practitioner, then they have a body that they can go to to seek some form of redress.
