In fact, they can seek to have that person struck off the register if the required task is not being performed. Yet people who are placing all of their life savings in the hands of some of these financial planners have no such guarantee about the qualifications of the people who are doing that job, and they have no redress if those involved carry out their tasks in a very poor manner and fail to give the proper information about the risks that are involved in financial planning. That is the key question.

There are a vast number of financial planners who do the right thing and have the proper qualifications and are trying to achieve a certain good quality of investment advice, but there are too many others who are not doing that. We have no way of actually being able to control this situation. None of the allegations or comments about my speech last Thursday have been able to refute the point I was making; that is, that consumers have no redress or protection at the moment. Although there is an association that is attempting to introduce a code of ethics into this industry, it has no capacity to prevent people setting themselves up and calling themselves financial advisers without the necessary qualifications. I think that is a very important point. The other point which I made in my speech, which has also not been refuted, is the incentive that exists currently for advisers to downplay or ignore risks with certain investments to gain maximum commission. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Brotherhood of St Laurence is very active in Ballarat, as it is right throughout Australia. It has been my great pleasure to be involved on several occasions with the goal setting course that is run by the Brotherhood. I have met with a large number of young men and women in the electorate to chew the fat over a number of concerns that they have. Indeed, I have a letter here that they have asked me to submit to the Parliament. I will not have time to read it all tonight but I will attempt to do so. The following young people have asked me to bring this message to the Parliament: Bradley Mendelson, Michael Waight, John Withers, Deidre Scott, Kelli Roberts, Sandra Whiting, David Shafton, Jason Shanahan and Mark Randall.

PARA.TAB: These are young men and women who really do know what it is like to be unemployed. They know what it is like to speak amongst themselves and they know what their ideas are for a better Australia.

I have had a large number of phone calls tonight from people in Ballarat who I think really saw today's Question Time as one of the most obscene attacks we have seen on the democratic process. It was an extremely disappointing day, in my view, for the democracy of this country—
Mr Bevis interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —For those opposite to laugh at what happened today—I thought I knew them better—is, unfortunately, a reflection on them. Today we saw what I believe was the greatest abuse of Question Time since I have been in this place. After reading part of this letter, I hope that the message will sink in. This is the message from the young people we are relying on to be the leaders of the future, the young people to whom we are saying, `Get a job, get some training and we will assist you wherever possible'.

PARA.TAB: It is about time we started acting as a parliament that had some obligations to these people. The performance at Question Time today was the most atrocious we have had in the 2 1/2 years I have been a member. The message reads:
We would like to take this opportunity to let the Parliament know we the unemployed in Ballarat are feeling and hurting.

We don't profess to know how all unemployed feel but we have ourselves and see in the faces of people in the street the feeling of Frustration, Betrayal, Defeat and the never ending ? of how am I going to survive in this economic environment.

Some people like us are motivated enough to try and get training for the future, but many especially the young and people over 50 just give up. Unless they are lucky enough to have received decent redundancy package, own their own homes and are free of debt (eg) loans, the burden to go on is too great and they lose all hope. This does not only apply to the unskilled people. Highly paid Professional and Trade people also find themselves in this predicament. Many have never been unemployed.

We feel it is time Petty Party Politics as well as side issues such as changing our flag are put aside and Parliament pull together to help the country back on track. We are not blaming any of you for the problems because issues overseas have a major part to play in our problems and how they are overcome.

The public need to be shown that Parliament is doing something concrete for the country and is not the "Circus" the media would like us to believe it is. Bring to the public eyes the work being done by non-partisan committees banish the sensation seeking comments to the back page. The latter plus the way the media play them up creates cynicism and harms the morale of an already moral shaken society.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a very valuable lesson for every member in this House. These young people are saying that they feel frustration, betrayal and defeat. As members of parliament, we should be ashamed that we have let this country get to the stage where our young people are expressing those sorts of sentiments. I say to the House: let us wake up and take account of what these young people are saying and give them some hope for the future because they are our future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on two very important events which occurred this weekend in my electorate, in Logan City in particular. The first one is of great importance and will have a great impact on the families in our electorate—the opening of the Logan Women's Health Centre. For five years we have been attempting to establish a women's health centre in our area. Only with a State Labor government were we able to get the necessary supplementary State funding and a commitment from the State Government to enable the centre to open.

PARA.TAB: The management committee is headed by Helen Bell and Helen O'Loughlin has become the centre's director. The centre has been placed with a range of labour market and young offender programs. It is situated near the railway station and the bus station because we believe it is particularly central to the women in Logan City.

Honourable members would be interested to know that the Logan Women's Health Centre has a beautiful logo, which was done by a group of young women artists. The logo consists of a butterfly emerging from the women's symbol. We hope that the symbol will become extremely well known throughout the length and breadth of Logan City and will provide opportunities for women to emerge as butterflies, in the sense that their health is important and something which is rare. As most members of this House would know and understand, women take control not only of their own health but the health of their family. It is important and central to the well-being of the family that women look after their health and care for themselves. Health is a particularly important asset.

The establishment of this centre is also a translation of social justice on the ground by this Government. This Government is not just talking about things: it is actually translating social justice into action. I extend my congratulations to the management committee, the director and the staff of the Logan Women's Health Centre. I know that they will become very busy and very important.

The other important event which occurred in Logan City on the weekend was the opening of the child-care centre at Logan TAFE. This is the first child-care centre to be opened at a TAFE in Queensland. This required the establishment of a State Labor government to ensure that the moneys provided by the Commonwealth Government could be taken up.

This particular child-care centre is important in two ways: it provides child-care for students in the community at the TAFE and also provides a valuable teaching resource and work experience for students doing the child-care diploma and certificate. This centre provides a break in the barriers for people who want to access TAFE courses. There is no point in providing courses for people if we do not take down the barriers for access to such courses and programs.

The child-care centre is again a tangible factor. It ensures that people with commitments and responsibilities for children can access the courses that are provided by the Logan TAFE college. It provides realistic and valuable experience for students studying there and means that we can do some work with children. I draw the attention of the House to the translation of social justice into action by this Labor Government through the child-care centre at Logan TAFE and the Logan Women's Health Centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to bring to the attention of the House some thoughts of the late Jack Fullerton. Norma, Jack's widow and one of my constituents, has been kind enough to pass on to me some of Jack's notes about our society. These thoughts preceded the immense problems we are now experiencing. Some years ago Jack could see how our society was developing and this concerned him greatly.

PARA.TAB: He decided to promote the idea of Wake Up Australia: wake up to what is happening in our country; wake up all Australians, and alert them to the fact that we are responsible for this great continent; wake up and realise that this is a land of wonderful opportunities, largely going to waste through lack of effort and responsibility; wake up Australians to the fact that a fair day's pay is the reward for a fair day's work and ignore all the rorts so prevalent today; wake up Australians and take an active part in your union. Attend the union meetings; make sure all union decisions are in the best interests of the members; make sure all the ballots are fairly conducted and that there is no intimidation. Wake up Australians and see that the underprivileged in our society are adequately taken care of; be sure every individual contributes just a little more, whether he is employed on the factory floor, as a public servant or as a politician. We must start right now or the world will leave us behind.

Well, Jack, you were right, only the world has left us behind, so let us now wake up Australia. Jack Fullerton could obviously see how the nation was developing and how we can only reach our full potential with an effort from everybody. When we look at the condition of the nation at the moment, it is an absolute disgrace. Our once great agricultural industries are far from healthy. Our mining industries are expanding overseas and not here, mainly due to government red tape and on-costs. Our manufacturing industries, despite the claims by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), are in deep financial trouble and will need years to recover. Our service industries are a mixed group as far as prosperity is concerned. However, the big service industries, such as banking and insurance, are decidedly unhealthy.

Overall, it is a very grim picture and all Australians should wake up, as Jack Fullerton suggested. The message that I am sure Jack would have embraced enthusiastically today is that of Fightback, with its personal incentives, lower tax rates and employment agreements. Interestingly, it was the Prime Minister who, as Treasurer, embraced so fervently the principle of a GST. At various times in his career the Prime Minister has endorsed most elements of Fightback, and these elements apply equally as well today as they did years ago.
Mr Ronaldson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct. Our problems are just the same in nature but more acute and need more dramatic actions—dramatic in the way that is planned for the car industry under Fightback. The Prime Minister is offering a 15 per cent tariff by the year 2000 and some very doubtful results from award restructuring. Fightback offers 5 per cent by the year 2000 but a wealth of positive changes, including to payroll tax and wholesale sales tax—the two really big items as far as the car industry is concerned.

PARA.TAB: Apart from making cars cheaper, the number of cars sold will obviously increase dramatically. With increased volumes, prices will drop even further. Just think of all the parts manufacturers working feverishly to keep up the supply, particularly those in the electorate of Ballarat. Fightback will be the greatest boon to the car industry in its history.

The Prime Minister is taking a tremendous risk in making this an election issue. When the facts become widely known, those people in the industry will embrace Fightback. If only the Prime Minister over his years in Parliament had realised that Australia needed awakening, not recessing—a recession which at various times we were promised we would not have but eventually had to have. Now the blame is with the gall of the coalition members who have the hide to ask the Prime Minister what he intends to do. After all, the recent financial statements have not worked. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time has arrived in Australian sports administration where the managers of our major football codes need to understand that the games are no longer one-city based. Australian rules is no longer a Melbourne event and rugby league is no longer a Sydney event. The performance of the West Coast Eagles in the Australian rules competition has demonstrated quite conclusively the high quality of Australian rules football in the west. The dominance of the Brisbane Broncos in the rugby league competition has demonstrated similarly that rugby league is no longer, if it ever was, a Sydney game. Indeed, it is not just Brisbane in the rugby league that has demonstrated that the top quality teams are now outside of the traditional Sydney area. Tribute should be paid to Newcastle and to the Illawarra Steelers, both of whom have done exceedingly well this season; of course the Illawarra Steelers are still in the competition.

PARA.TAB: As the member for Brisbane, it was a matter of great joy for me to see the Brisbane Broncos succeed so convincingly yesterday in the major preliminary semifinal and to go straight into the grand final in a fortnight's time. The Brisbane Broncos, in achieving that, have established a record not seen in the Sydney competition since 1951 when the Manly club was able to go into a grand final after only five years in the competition. Indeed, when Brisbane does win the grand final in a fortnight, that will be a feat not matched since 1942 when the Canterbury side won a grand final after entering the competition in 1938.

The performance of the Brisbane Broncos is a tribute to a lot of people. Obviously, the major credit goes to those on the field. There needs to be some recognition of the contribution of the club management and the coach who have provided outstanding leadership and organisation, throughout not just this season but a number of seasons, to take Brisbane to a premiership so soon after entering the competition.

I read with some interest today the various commentaries on the game. Having watched the game and now read some of the commentaries, I feel some genuine pity for some of the Illawarra players who were faced with a pretty daunting prospect yesterday. Their half-back, Mick Neil, who I think is an outstanding player, had the rather daunting prospect of facing up to the world's best rugby league player, in top form, Allan Langer. I thought a very incisive and astute commentary on that came from the Australian reporter Jeff Wells when he had this to say, commenting on Mick Neil's misfortune:
For he had run into the game's number one player, Allan Langer, who had one of those days that Catholic schoolboys aren't even allowed to dream about.

Within a week we had been taught a sound lesson in the gulf between mere talent and genius. And that had been the point all along—until the Bronco's arrived this had been a finals series short on the best players and the best moves.

SPEECH.PARA: And so it had been. Allan Langer's performance was absolutely outstanding. It was one of the great performances. One of the amazing things about Allan Langer's game is that, although he is the smallest person on the field, he seems to have no difficulty at all in bringing down the biggest people on the field. He did that time and again yesterday in that semifinal atmosphere. I have no doubt that he will perform as well in the grand final.

PARA.TAB: Of course, a number of other players contributed to the victory in an outstanding manner. Willie Carne, Trevor Gillmeister and Terry Matterson all put in tremendous performances. It is pleasing to note that they were all part of the original team when the Broncos first formed. I know that they are excited about having joined the Broncos on day one and now steered it to a premiership final in a fortnight's time—and, I am sure, to a premiership win. It is a win which the people of Brisbane are dearly looking forward to and, dare I say it, in many ways it will help avenge those terrible years gone by when Queensland fans turned up at Lang Park to watch New South Wales players do us in every year. The Broncos have played extremely well this season. They deserve to win. They are the best side. In two weeks time, they will prove it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), that he owes the great success of the Broncos this year to the fact that the Panthers decided to reduce their effort part way through the season, in a very sad way.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know, I have lived in a number of beautiful places in this country, not the least being the electorate of Corio, where I spent 3 1/2 years attending the local high school. Then I moved up to the north coast, and now I reside in the Blue Mountains, which, as honourable members know, is one of the most beautiful areas in this country. It is a great honour and a privilege to serve the people of the Blue Mountains, not to mention the lovely area of the Hawkesbury, which makes up another part of my electorate.

On Friday I visited one of Australia's most visited and admired tourist spots: Echo Point at Katoomba. Everybody is familiar with the Three Sisters and the beauty and the grandeur that one beholds when standing on the parapet that looks out over the Jamieson Valley. On the left one sees the Three Sisters. On the right one sees the magnificence of the valley, the Castle and Orphan Rock. One sees the scenic railway disappearing up through the cliff and the sky-way crossing the valley adjacent to Katoomba Falls, with over 1,000 feet from the carriage to the bottom of the valley.

On visiting the kiosk at Echo Point, I was presented with a new book on the Blue Mountains that updates one of the very beautiful books on the Blue Mountains that was published some time ago. This book has been published by the Blue Mountains Tourist Authority in conjunction with the National Parks and Wildlife Service of New South Wales. It truly is a magnificent book promoting a very special part of the world. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware of the beauty of Echo Point, Blackheath, Govetts Leap, Wentworth Falls and Leura.

In October each year seven or eight of the most beautiful and magnificent gardens that one would want to see anywhere, the Leura gardens, are open for about 10 days for the public to visit. I think they are the only ones whose beauty may eclipse the Floriade of Canberra. The people of that area open their gardens and charge a small admission for people to visit them. The proceeds go towards the amenities for the local hospital.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be very interested to see some of the other views depicted in this book. There is a view of the Kanangra Falls, another beautiful part of the mountains. I mentioned the Blue Mountains earlier; you would be very familiar with the lovely scenery in the Blue Mountains. I commend this exhilarating area, with its magnificent climate, to all honourable members and honourable senators. If we took a survey of this House and the other place we would probably find that quite a few honourable members and honourable senators spent their honeymoon up there. It is a favourite place for honeymooners and I commend it to them.

One of the other interesting things about the mountains is the town of Faulconbridge, which not so long ago was declared by the World Bureau of Meteorologists to have the most equable climate of any place in the world where records are kept. That is only about three kilometres from where I live, but it is 200 feet higher. The same claim cannot be made for the beautiful town of Springwood, where I have my electorate office; nevertheless, it is quite an achievement to have in that area a township that has almost the perfect climate. I commend this book, The Blue Mountains of Australia. Every dollar that is obtained from the sale of this book goes towards the preservation of some of the magnificent tracks that I commend all people listening to visit during their time in that area. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, you will know that I am what one would describe as a very equable sort of person. I do not get overly excited. But there is one thing that does rile me. That is when I am faced with institutionalised hypocrisy, deceit, sanctimonious claptrap and downright lies and distortions. I think that if one looks at the history of royal commissions in this country, one can see that all these things are very evident.

PARA.TAB: I have commented on the absurdity of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I know very well that, had the question been put to Aboriginals as to whether they wanted royal commissions or houses, houses would have won hands down. I want to deal with the situation in Western Australia because the distortions there have been appalling. No matter which way we add up the losses of the Western Australian Government, we cannot get to a figure of more than about $400m. The figure of $1 billion which was flaunted through the West Australian is an indictment of the integrity of that newspaper; a newspaper that sat on its hands all through the excesses of the 1980s and now adopts the most sanctimonious of attitudes.

I want to dwell on the treatment that has been handed out to Brian Burke. It is well known in Western Australia that I was not a supporter of Brian Burke; I was one of the very few who opposed the Burke style of government. However, it is true that under the Burke Government a lot of things were done and an enormous number of people did benefit. I find the treatment handed out to the ex-Premier unspeakable. The anti-corruption squad for the police force, a very political body, charged Mr Burke with malpractice in reference to his travel expenses. If Mr Burke is guilty of this charge, there is no doubt that so is every Minister of every government in Australia that has ever existed and 90 per cent of first division public servants. It is an absolute nonsense and I am sure it will be proved so.

It certainly is convenient for somebody in the short term to be persecuting Mr Burke in this way. But I remember the days of the black October stock crash when we saw the stock market reeling. It was in the light of that that the Burke Government was asked over a weekend to intervene to save the Rothwells Bank, a bank which the auditor assured us was financially sound but had a cash flow crisis, a view that was supported by Alan Bond and Mr Holmes a Court, both of whom were supposed to know something about cash.

As it turned out, we know from subsequent events that that bank was actually broke in 1986. In 1986 it declared its record profit and paid a record dividend. In 1987 it declared a bigger profit and paid a bigger dividend. It is against that background that the Burke Government had to act over a weekend.

Had that Government decided that it would let Rothwells fail, the consequences would have been these: the Government would have had to find between $70m and $100m. Catholic Education had its money in there. Obviously it had to pay its teachers. The State has a statutory obligation to educate children. It would have had to have a massive expenditure either to build schools to accommodate them or to bail out Catholic Education. Clearly, there was no alternative.

Most of the right wing shires had their Federal road money in there. A Labor government certainly could not have said, `Sack your day workers; there will be no roads this year'. The Spastic Welfare organisation had its money in there. That amounted to over $70m, and other people were bound to come out of the woodwork. The Government held Rothwells together so that all the small investors got their money back. It saved 9 1/2 thousand jobs at the time and stabilised a very precarious stock market situation. I think they were worthy aims.

It is interesting to note that Senator Crichton-Browne, one of the few Liberal senators that know anything at all about the economy, said to me—and I add that he has kept his word—`You'll never hear a word out of me about Rothwells because any government would have done the same under those circumstances. The Government would be the last to know. If it happened tomorrow another government would do the same'. I would like to enlarge upon this because I think it is a very important business. I feel ashamed of the way that Brian Burke has been treated, and I will be using the forms of this House to try to redeem his name at another time. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the two or three minutes remaining in the adjournment debate, I wish to say a few words about our defence forces. I was prompted to rise on this matter tonight because, as honourable members will know, we have had a visit today from a parliamentary delegation from the United Kingdom. As some honourable members in this chamber will be aware, in a previous life I served in the Royal Air Force in the United Kingdom before I finally saw the light and came to this wonderful country. I became an Australian, and I am certainly here for good.
—It's a pity they don't buy anything from us.

—I am being serious; I am not scoring political points. I want to make the point that I have maintained a number of useful contacts with personal friends since I left that organisation some 15 years ago. We exchange Christmas cards and letters.

PARA.TAB: I was reminded today of a letter that I got last Christmas from a friend who has now risen to a very senior rank and who wrote to me about the performance of our forces in the Gulf war last year. From his position at the Air Force Operations Desk in London directly controlling many of the Gulf war activities, this senior British officer said to me about our ships and our Navy:

SPEECH.PARA: The Aussie ships were a revelation compared with the rest of the UN Armada (land or sea). They were effective, integrated and on station the moment they arrived in the Gulf—most impressive and certainly was one in the eye for the others.
It seems to me that we should all say a hearty `well done' to the officers and men concerned in our defence forces. All too often these days it is a pretty thankless task in the forces, with
budget cuts from parties of whichever political persuasion. There are often morale problems, there is a lot of criticism, and they tend to be a political football.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't procrastinate.

—I am not procrastinating; I am making the point that the people in our forces do a good job. They cannot fight back when they get criticised in here. When they go out and perform well in the service of this country, we should accept that they are doing a good job. What is wrong with saying that they have done a good job when they should do? In spite of the comments from the other side, I repeat that we should sing the praises of our forces when they are in the service of this country overseas.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 27 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was any experimental or research role carried out by the Australian-built Endeavour ultraviolet telescope on its flight during January 1992 aboard the US space shuttle Discovery; if not, why not.
(2) Was there a research role for the telescope; if not, what was the purpose of its mission.
(3) What criteria were used to determine the success of the purpose of its mission.
(4) Did the telescope complete all its mission objectives during the flight; if not, why not.
(5) If the mission was not completed were its objectives compromised; if so, why; if not, why not.

(6) Were officials of the (a) Australian Space Office and (b) Australian Space Board (i) advised or (ii) aware of concerns that the chosen shuttle flight might not be appropriate in all respects for the telescope's mission; if so, what are the details.

(7) Were concerns of the nature referred to in part (6) raised (a) by prime contractors associated with the construction, engineering and design of the telescope and (b) in any space industry and research-related forums held in 1991.

(8) What were the temperature and light parameters (a) beyond which the operation of the telescope would not be considered reliable or effective and (b) which were anticipated to apply to the shuttle flight chosen for the telescope's mission.
(9) How does the flight angle of the shuttle affect temperature and light parameters.
(10) What is meant by the thermal profile of a shuttle flight and how is it affected by the flight angle of the shuttle.
(11) In what way could the thermal profile of a shuttle flight have affected the operation of a telescope similar to the Endeavour.
(12) If the telescope failed to complete its mission, did the (a) thermal profile or (b) flight angle of the shuttle flight play any role in that failure.

(13) Were any concerns voiced formally or informally before the shuttle flight; if so, were any officials associated with (a) the administration of the Endeavour project or (b) the project in general aware of those concerns.
(14) Who was responsible for choosing the shuttle flight.
(15) What other options were available.
(16) Why was the shuttle flight chosen in preference to later flights.
(17) What were the assumed advantages of the chosen flight.
(18) Did later flights offer operating parameters, such as thermal profiles and flight angles, which were more conducive to ensuring the effective testing of the telescope.
(19) What advice did NASA officials provide on the relative appropriateness of various shuttle flights.
(20) Did NASA at all times accept the Australian Space Office's choice of flight.
(21) How did the relevant technical parameters of the chosen flight vary from those of later flights.
(22) What were the direct and indirect costs of the telescope's flight aboard the shuttle.
(23) What method does NASA use to determine charges for carrying out missions aboard shuttles and how was it applied to the telescope's flight.
(24) What is the relationship of space-based research activities in Australia to space industry objectives pursued by the Australian Space Office.

(25) Are the Australian Space Office and the Government's space program being reviewed; if so, (a) what are the terms of reference, (b) when will it be completed, (c) will the conduct of Australian Space Office officials in all aspects of the administration of the Endeavour project be considered; if not, why not and (d) when will the report of the review be made available.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The lid of the canister (known as a GASCAN) containing the telescope did not open due to the operation of a safety device triggered by over-temperature conditions experienced in the Shuttle cargo bay.

(2) The primary objective of the mission, as determined by Mount Stromlo & Siding Spring Observatories, was the engineering validation of the performance in space of the ultra-violet detector system, as a demonstration of Australian technical and industrial capacity, and as a potential partner in a major international space project.
A secondary, scientific objective was to make measurements of the ultraviolet emission from selected celestial objects, eg. the Large Magellanic Cloud.
(3) The success criterion for the mission was the successful calibration of the detector system against the galactic ultraviolet background emission.
(4) No. The observational program was inhibited by the telescope's safety device.

(5) The achievement of the objectives was compromised by the inability to undertake the observational program. Nevertheless, the payload survived the mission and operated as designed within the prevailing circumstances.

(6) The Australian Space Office and the Australian Space Board were aware of concerns raised by some individuals about perceived limitations of the selected shuttle mission. Those concerns focused on two specific areas:

(a) It was alleged that the orientation of the orbiter during the mission was such that the cargo bay and therefore the Endeavour telescope would be pointed towards the earth for the whole mission. This concept is incorrect and apparently arose from a misinterpretation of the `tail down' orientation of the orbiter.
(b) It was alleged that the scientific objectives had been compromised, both by the supposed orientation of the orbiter, and by the lack of targeted observations in the flight plan.
In order to achieve the secondary objective of the mission, it would be necessary to point the telescope at selected celestial objects, with an accuracy of about 1 degree.

NASA had made it clear from the outset that they were not prepared to accept this pointing requirement as a condition of flight. Such a requirement exceeds the normal conditions for acceptance of a GASCAN mission. The pointing requirement was deleted from the formal Payload Accommodation Requirements document by the Director, Mount Stromlo & Siding Spring Observatories in 1986.
(7) Discussions on these issues were held at various times between officials of the Space Office and the prime contractor, Auspace.
Such concerns were aired publicly on at least one occasion, and received substantial press coverage.

(8)(a) The control system of the payload was set to inhibit operation in conditions of excessive light, ie., to protect against an inadvertent initiation of the observational sequence, and of excessive temperature in the environment of the payload. The limit was set at 50 degrees Celsius.
(b) At the time of the offer of a flight on STS-42, the mission environment was expected to be within the range of operability of the Endeavour payload.

Following acceptance of the offer, further detailed information on the flight profile was provided, which could be compared with the thermal characteristics of the payload. On the basis of this analysis, it was concluded that the expected thermal environment predicted by NASA was compatible with successful operation of the payload.

(9) The temperature and light conditions in the cargo bay to which an experiment such as Endeavour would be exposed depend on a combination of the orbit of the orbiter, and the orientation of the orbiter in space.

The prime factor which affects the temperature in the cargo bay is the proportion of time that the cargo bay itself is exposed to sunlight. That proportion is controlled by the passage of the orbiter through the sunlit and dark hemispheres, with a period of about 90 minutes, as well as the orientation of the orbiter itself, as determined by the flight angle and roll angle.
(10) The thermal profile of the flight refers to the temperature conditions expected to be encountered through the mission.

The flight angle is not the prime determinant of the thermal profile. In the case of STS-42, the flight angle was always perpendicular to the earth's surface. The temperature in the cargo bay was determined primarily by the proportion of the time that the cargo bay was exposed to direct sunlight.

(11) The effect on any experiment of the thermal conditions encountered during flight depend very much on the experiment, and no general statement can be made. However, for any electronic system, there is an optimum operating temperature range, beyond which the performance of the system is degraded. Under extreme conditions, the system could sustain physical damage.

(12) Analysis of the data recorded by the telescope during the flight show that the temperature experienced by the Endeavour payload exceeded, by a substantial margin, that predicted on the basis of the expected thermal profile. The flight angle is not the determining factor as explained in (10) and (11) above.
(13) Concerns were raised as described in the response to (6) and (7) above. Officials of the Space Office were aware of those concerns.
(14) The decision was made by the Deputy Executive Director of the Space Office.

(15) The only other option available at the time would have been to reject the offer of a flight on STS-42, and seek a later opportunity. As STS-42 provided adequate opportunity to meet the primary objective of the mission there was no reason to incur further delay.
(16) STS-42 was not chosen in preference to other flights. It was accepted as the first flight which provided adequate opportunity to achieve the primary objective of the Endeavour project.
(17) Flight STS-42 was the first available flight providing adequate opportunity to meet the primary objective of the Endeavour project.

(18) No specific information was available on other flight opportunities. The availability of space for canisters such as the one housing Endeavour is often not clear until late in the process of manifesting the Shuttle payloads.
(19) NASA officials made no judgements on the suitability or otherwise of flight opportunities.
(21) See responses to (15), (16), (17) and (18).
(22) There was a charge of $US20 000 for payload, plus a surcharge of $US7 000 for the use of the special canister equipped with a motorised door assembly.

Other costs, directly in support of the flight totalled $794 044, which included refurbishment of the payload and visits by contractor personnel to the US for the integration of the payload into the NASA-provided GASCANs, the launch of the Space Shuttle orbiter carrying the payload, and the subsequent de-integration of the payload from the GASCANs.
(23) NASA has a set fee schedule for canister projects. This schedule is reflected in the fees outlined in (22) above.
(24) Participation in space-based research activities can provide valuable opportunities for the development of space technology and capability in industry.

(25) A review of the National Space Program was recently carried out pursuant to a requirement contained in the decision of Government made in the 1988/89 Budget context, and which provided ongoing funding for the National Space Program.
(a) The terms of reference are as follows:

1. Assess the performance of the Program against its objectives (as they have evolved since the Program's inception), including the direct and indirect benefits which have or will flow from the Program.
2. Assess the relevance of the Program's activities in meeting its objectives.
3. Assess the appropriateness of the current space policy and program for meeting Australia's future needs for space industry development, and for access to space goods and services.
4. Develop recommendations for future directions for the Program, including for the policy environment.
(b) The report of the Expert Panel was provided to the Australian Space Board on 15 June 1992.
(c) The Panel did not comment specifically on the management of the Endeavour project.

(d) The report of the Expert Panel has been considered by the Australian Space Board, and appropriate recommendations have been passed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The report has been published.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 2 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How will the draft Broadcasting Services Bill provide a better service and more choice for the public.
(2) Will there be more operators in the radio industry instead of multi-station ownership which is preferred by the industry; if so, why.
(3) Will multi-station ownership be allowed in regional areas where the market may not be large enough to support competing services.
(4) How will the introduction of new operators affect the profitability of existing operators, particularly in regional Australia.
(5) Will the proposal in the draft Bill that licence fees change from an ongoing fee to a lump sum payment result in a financial drain on existing and new operators.
(6) What sum will regional radio and television operators pay under the lump sum payment provision.
(7) How will the proposed Australian Broadcasting Authority determine the suitability of a licensee.
(8) What fee will be charged for regional AM radio stations to cross over to FM.
(9) Will criteria apply to regional radio stations crossing from AM to FM; if so, what criteria.
(10) What rules will apply to broadcasting during the changeover period.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 will reduce barriers to the provision of new services, requires less detailed regulation and avoids unnecessary regulatory intervention. The Act encourages the provision of new and innovative services and allows for these to be delivered by a range of existing and developing technologies, yet maintains certain obligations on broadcasters as an integral part of national identity and culture and of our democratic society.

(2) The Act facilitates new entry (more operators) and multiple radio station ownership. Radio ownership and control is significantly liberalised under the Act, with many restrictions lifted (including: foreign ownership, and national limitations) but existing cross-media limits have been retained to encourage diversity of media ownership.
A new limit for radio will be the two-to-a-market maximum ownership (section 54) replacing the one-to-one market limit.

More operators per market will minimise undue concentration of ownership, but the Act permits economies of scale to be realised from a degree of multiple ownership. Allowing multi-station ownership without allowing new entrants would lead to a concentration of ownership
(3) A provision exists so that if there is only one commercial broadcaster in a licence area—the existing licensee may operate a second service (see section 39).

(4) There may, initially, be an adverse impact on the profitability of existing commercial radio services, but radio broadcasters will be able to offset this by operating two stations in the same market which should allow economies to be achieved.

Additional competition will foster greater choice and diversity of services and provide a spur to achieving greater efficiency in the broadcasting industry. More diverse and better quality programming will benefit consumers.

(5) The Act makes no reference to the payment of licence fees changing from ongoing instalments to a lump sum, although the possibility is mentioned in the explanatory papers which accompanied the exposure draft of the Bill. However, the Act does provide for a price based system for allocating commercial broadcasting licences (see section 36). The licence fee regime to apply under the broadcasting services legislation has yet to be settled by the Government.
(6) See answer to question 5.

(7) The question of a licensee's "suitability" will be determined by the ABA (Australian Broadcasting Authority). The ABA will decide whether allowing or continuing to allow a company to provide commercial or community broadcasting services would lead to a significant risk of an offence against the Act or regulations being committed, or a breach of the conditions of the licence occurring [sections 41(2) and 83(2)]. Sections 41(3) and 83(3) specify factors which the ABA is to consider when deciding whether or not such risk exists.

(8) When the new Act enters into force, regional AM radio stations wishing to move to FM will have to do so by obtaining a licence through the competitive price-based process to be determined under the Act. Alternatively, if they operate in a solus market, and at least 2 other commercial radio broadcasting licences that are broadcasting services bands licences are available, they will be eligible to acquire a second licence (see answer to question 3). The specific fee regime has yet to be determined (see question 5 and 6).
(9) See answer to question 8.
(10) The Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments Act 1992) governs the transition to the new broadcasting regulatory regime.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 25 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to community concerns that X-rated pornographic and R-rated violent material may be broadcast when pay television is introduced.
(2) Are there any indications that individuals or companies will apply for a licence to broadcast the material referred to in part (1) when pay television is introduced.
(3) Will the Government ensure that such material remains restricted; if so, how.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: The Broadcasting Services Act 1992, which was passed by the Parliament on 26 June and will come into effect on 1 October 1992, contains detailed provisions at Schedule 2, Section 10 (1)(f) and (g) restricting the broadcasting of `X' and `R' rated material on Pay TV.

Section 10 (1)(f) requires that subscription television (Pay TV) broadcasting licensees will not broadcast any material that has been refused classification, or has been classified as `X' by the Office of Film and Literature Classification. Section 10(1)(g) provides that access to programs classified as `R' will be restricted by technical disabling devices, such as PIN numbers or smartcards (similar to credit cards) that are acceptable to the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA). This would allow parents to control access by children to programs.

The Act further provides at Schedule 2, Section 10 (1)(g) that licensees will not be permitted to broadcast `R' rated material until the ABA has completed extensive, Australia-wide, qualitative and quantitative research on community standards of taste and decency in relation to classifications for Pay TV, and on what levels of violence and depiction of sex should be allowed. The ABA will decide whether to approve the broadcast of `R' rated material when it has evaluated the findings of that research.

However, these provisions cannot come into effect until the Parliament has also approved legislative provisions for the introduction of Pay TV. These provisions were removed from the Bill introduced into the Parliament, and referred to the Senate Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services. That Committee is scheduled to report back to the Senate by 10 September 1992.

The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 also requires that Codes of Practice will be required to be developed by all broadcasters in the area of program classification. The Codes must be registered with the regulatory authority and if they are not operating to provide appropriate community safeguards, mandatory Program Standards may be introduced by the authority. The ABA will have significant powers to deal with breaches of Standards and the provisions of the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 2 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Who owns the land at South Boulder, in Kalgoorlie Boulder, which was originally purchased for the use of ASH Aboriginal Enterprises.
(2) Is the property currently occupied; if so by whom.
(3) Who owns the title of the land.
(4) Have the premises been let since the failure of ASH Aboriginal Enterprises.
(5) What rental payments (a) Have been made in the past and (b) are currently paid.
(6) To whose benefit (a) has the rent accrued in the past and (b) are currently paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Aboriginal Self Help Enterprise (ASH) owns two blocks of land on Oroya Street South Boulder. One is freehold, purchased through a former Department of Aboriginal Affairs grant. The other was a Crown Grant made to the organisation on 20 January 1983.
(2) The land is presently occupied by the ASH Enterprise Manager, Mr Neil Dimer, who is also a Director of the organisation.
(3) The title to the land is held by ASH Enterprises.
(4) Verbal advice received by ATSIC officers indicates that ASH Enterprises has in the past leased or rented part of the property to private mining firms. No verified details of income are available.

(5) and (6) ATSIC has advised that no funds have been provided to ASH Aboriginal Enterprises by either ATSIC or previously the Department of Aboriginal Affairs since 1984 when the enterprise was wound down. Details of any rents received are not available to ATSIC.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Institute of Health and Welfare Board

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 18 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: What selection criteria are used to choose members of the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare Board and what is the reason for each criterion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare Act 1987 provides for Institute Board members in five main categories:
(1) Ex officio members: Director of the Institute, the Australian Statistician and the Secretary to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.

(2) Three representatives of the State and Territory Governments, one from each of the Departments covering health, community services/welfare and housing assistance matters. The Australian Health Ministers' Advisory Council nominates the health representative, the Standing Committee of Social Welfare Administrators nominates the community services/welfare representative, and State Housing Departments nominate the housing assistance representative by consensus.
This provides for an appropriate State Government input to the work of the Institute.

(3) Four members whom I nominate from people recommended by ten bodies which are listed in the Schedule to the Act. These organisations nominate people whom they consider have knowledge of the needs of consumers of health, welfare, and housing assistance services, or who have expertise in research into public health.
(4) Direct Ministerial nominees—the Chairperson and three members.

Members in categories (3) and (4) are chosen for their particular expertise, taking into account the need to have a Board which is well balanced and possesses the specialist knowledge necessary to guide the Institute in its work.
(5) An Institute staff representative who is elected by the staff.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 18 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the current waiting time in the provision of service by the National Acoustics Laboratories (NAL) to (a) adults and (b) children.
(2) What sums were (a) allocated to and (b) spent on actual running costs by the NAL in 1991-92.
(3) What percentage of the NAL budget is allocated to the provision of hearing aids.
(4) What is the NAL's actual expenditure on the provision of hearing aids.
(5) How many hearing aids did the NAL provide to (a) adults and (b) children in 1991-92.
(6) What does it cost for the NAL to fit a hearing aid to (a) an adult and (b) a child.
(7) Has the NAL recruited audiologists from overseas; if so, (a) how many and (b) at what cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) At each of Australian Hearing Services' (AHS) (formerly NAL) 48 permanent hearing centres, waiting times for
(a) adults are less than 10 weeks; and
(b) children requiring a hearing aid are less than four weeks.
A system is also in place whereby any client assessed by the referring medical practitioner to require an urgent appointment is seen within approximately one week (or on the same day if critical).
(2)(a) $30,355,245 (excluding $8,832,655 property operating expenses).
(b) $30,102,414 (excluding $8,161,292 property operating expenses).
(3) 33% (covering hearing aids, accessories, spare parts, batteries, special hearing devices).
(4) $19,548,019 (covering hearing aids, accessories, spare parts, batteries, special hearing devices).

(6)(a) An extensive cost attribution exercise was conducted in 1990 to ascertain the cost based on commercial accounting principles of fitting a hearing aid to an AHS adult client. The cost was assessed at $476 for a monaural fitting and $742 for a binaural fitting. At 1992-93 prices, these costs are, respectively, $507 and $790. Approximately 65% of adult clients are fitted monaurally and 35% binaurally.

(b) The cost exercise for children was not as rigorous as the attribution process for adults. The available data is, however, sufficient to allow a close approximation. The approximate cost for children (1992-93 prices) is $799 for a monaural fitting and $1,198 for a binaural fitting. Approximately half of AHS child clients are fitted monaurally and the remaining half binaurally.

There are a number of factors which combine to produce the significantly higher costs for children, including greater time spent in assessing the degree of hearing loss, more extensive follow up procedures, difficulties in fitting hearing aids, the incidence of children with multiple disabilities and generally higher costs of attending children in remote Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.
(7)(a) 12 (recruited to two-year fixed term contracts in 1990-91 because of inability to recruit qualified Australian staff)

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 19 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: Further to the answer to question No. 1327 (Hansard, 26 March 1992, page 1331), what progress has been made in persuading countries in the Asian region to ratify ILO freedom of association conventions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: As a member of the ILO, Australia is aware of a number of activities undertaken by the ILO to promote the adoption of international labour standards and to encourage member States to ratify ILO Conventions. These include seminars at regional, sub-regional and national levels; short study courses; and the provision of Regional Advisers to help governments in the African, American, Caribbean and Asia-Pacific regions to fulfil their obligations under the ILO Constitution in respect of international labour standards.

In the case of freedom of association conventions, no new ratifications by countries in the Asia region have occurred since the response was provided to question No. 1327 (Hansard, 26 March 1992, page 1331).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 19 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) claim $159000 as the cost of overheads for the control tower at the aerodrome at Port Hedland, WA.
(2) Did Air Traffic Services (ATS) claim $79000 for the facilities referred to in part (1).
(3) Are the costs of maintenance, electricity, water, fringe benefits tax, travel, accommodation, labour on-costs and other expenses for the facility listed and costed separately.
(4) What are the actual overheads for the facility.
(5) Did ATS list $79000 for return on assets as a cost of running the facility; if so, why.
(6) Is the CAA making a profit on running the facility; if so, why.
(7) Is it a fact that overheads and return on assets total $317000 of the total running costs of the facility.
(8) Is it also a fact that the net operating loss is reported to be $122000; if so, is there an excess of $195000 which could be returned to the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice provided by the Civil Aviation Authority:

PARA.TAB: (1&2) In calculating the total cost of running the Port Hedland control tower, the CAA allocated direct costs (such as the salaries of the Air Traffic Controllers), and overheads. These overheads were divided between corporate overheads external to Air Traffic Services Division, which amounted to $159000, and overheads which formed part of the cost of running Air Traffic Services Division, which amounted to $79000. Corporate overheads comprise part of the costs of functions within the CAA which do not directly earn revenue, but are necessary to support the operations of revenue earning divisions; these functions include pay section, computer services and accounting and financial services. Air Traffic Services Division's overheads include the cost of training Air Traffic Controllers, airspace design and administration, all of which are necessary to keep controllers in the towers.
(3) The items listed by the honourable member were individually costed and listed as direct costs.

(4) The actual overheads for the facility are an allocation of the costs of all non-revenue earning divisions and functions needed to support revenue-earning divisions as mentioned in the answer to parts (1) and (2) of the honourable member's question.

(5) The CAA, like all Government Business Enterprises, is required to earn a return on assets employed. At present, the target rate of return is 7.5% per annum. The $79000 referred to by the honourable member represents 7.5% of what was calculated as the value of the assets employed in operating the control tower. The actual value of the relevant assets is presently being re-assessed, but in any event, 7.5% would remain the target rate of return.
(6) The CAA is not presently making a profit on running the facility.
(7) The sum of overheads and return on assets is $317000.

(8) The CAA has calculated that it will make a net operating loss of $122000 per annum on the Port Hedland tower. The CAA has conducted a cost-benefit analysis of the Port Hedland tower, and concluded that continuing the tower service is not justifiable on safety and economic grounds, and hence that the entire operating cost of the tower ($845000 pa) is an unnecessary impost on the aviation industry; this is why the CAA believes the tower should be closed down, and this view is shared by the principal operators at Port Hedland.
